IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Initiatives such as the National Plan to Address Alzheimer's Disease (AD) call for greater attention to increasing enrollment into clinical trials and other clinical research; an outgrowth of the National Plan is the National Strategy for Recruitment and Participation in Alzheimer's Disease Clinical Research which enumerated four goals, one of which is focused specifically on the need to “build and improve research infrastructure of registries in order to recruit and retain more and more diverse qualified study participants.” The objective of this proposal is to develop, deploy, optimize and automate new website design/content, infrastructure and functionality to support and sustain online recruitment, engagement, and retention of adults interested in participating in AD-focused studies, creating a sustainable and enduring resource to researchers by building off of our successful Alzheimer's Prevention Registry (APR), an online registry launched in 2012 with >350,000 members, including ~90,000 enrolled in its GeneMatch (GM) program launched in 2015.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder is reported in 1/8th critically ill patients. Sepsis kills more than 250,000 patients in the US each year and alcohol use disorder is independently associated with increased mortality with sepsis. Results from this research may improve our understanding of how alcohol consumption increases mortality in sepsis and develop novel therapies to treat sepsis.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult hippocampal neurogenesis is a unique form of brain plasticity important in certain forms of learning, memory and mood regulation; aspects of brain function that are dysregulated in fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASDs). Here, we will investigate adult neurogenesis as a therapeutic target in a mouse model of prenatal alcohol exposure, which may lead to new avenues for improving treatment in FASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple myeloma (MM) is an incurable hematopoietic malignancy that progresses from benign monoclonal gammopathy precursor conditions. Oncogenic mutations in MM are similar to those found in the precursor conditions, and it is not clear what ultimately drives tumorigenesis. Understanding these mechanisms may lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent cancer development in these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: The University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus Computational Bioscience Program (CPBS) is an independent, Ph.D.-granting and postdoctoral training program based in the University of Colorado School of Medicine, with a 20-year track record of innovative and effective training of pre- and post-doctoral fellows for research careers. We are a second-generation biomedical informatics teaching program, informed by the experience of the many training models that have come before us. Our program is designed to produce graduates with depth in both computational methods and biomedicine, an intimate familiarity with the science and technology that synergizes the two, and the skills necessary to pioneer novel computational approaches to significant biomedical questions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral weight loss interventions for obesity reliably result in weight loss and health benefits. However, the extent of weight loss they produce is typically limited to ~7–10% of total body weight and weight regain is common, limiting their ability to modify disease risk in a sustained manner. To address these limitations, the proposed research seeks novel mechanisms underlying the changes in appetite and metabolism that contribute to the occurrence of involuntary weight loss plateaus in free-living participants undergoing a behavioral weight loss intervention.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The KPMP Kidney Tissue Atlas is a unique resource that will form the foundation for precision medicine for the kidney health community. Our tissue interrogation site has established the critical need for localizing molecules linked to metabolism at a spatial level to identify pathways critical for disease understanding. With the next phase of KPMP, we have added new expertise, improved spatial resolution, greater coverage and deep pathway interpretative ability to bring forth new biomarkers and support precision therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Swallowing problems in Alzheimer’s disease cause significant health and quality of life issues. This translational research establishes whether tongue exercise started earlier or later in the disease process significantly improves swallowing function and changes AD-related pathology in tongue muscles and associated brain regions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol intoxication leads to the impairment of cerebellar-dependent tasks, with those in the motor control domain attracting the most interest due to the potential dangers associated with impaired motor coordination. In chronic alcoholics alterations in cerebellar function persist in the absence of alcohol consumption, but, while the molecular mechanisms underlying the effects of acute alcohol exposure on cerebellar physiology have been extensively investigated, the effects of chronic alcohol exposure on the cerebellum is understudied. The experiments outlined in this K01 application tackle this long standing gap in the alcohol research field using a well-established mouse model of alcohol dependence combined with ex-vivo electrophysiology, dendrite and spine morphology analysis and epigenetic research methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The triple-negative breast cancers (TNBCs) are highly aggressive and recurrent. Targeted therapy and combined chemo-immunotherapy have great potential to treat metastatic and heterogenous TNBCs. This project will develop and fully evaluate a humanized anti-CD276 antibody-drugs conjugate (Hu276-DualADC), which carries both highly potent payload to kill cancer cells and toll-like receptor agonist to activate effector immune cells in tumor microenvironment, and in combination with PD-1-targeted ADC for TNBCs treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Central Asia (CA) represents the most rapidly growing HIV epidemic region worldwide, concentrated in people who inject drugs (PWID) and their sexual partners, and scaling up opioid agonist therapies (OAT) in this region is the most cost-effective strategy to prevent new HIV infections, and more effective when combined with antiretroviral therapy (ART). We propose to use the Network for the Improvement of Addiction Treatment (NIATx) implementation strategy to scale-up OAT in three diverse Central Asian countries (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan) and guided by the Exploration-Planning-Implementation-Sustainment (EPIS) framework. Understanding the trajectories of implementation and scale-up in this context may emerge through creating communities of practice, especially when cohesion and competence evolves, and may guide other healthcare delivery challenges in the region (e.g., HIV, TB); as well as build important regional expertise and understanding implementation trajectories should help support OAT program sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to predict disease in solid organs is markedly hampered by the clinical impracticability of routine biopsies for several organs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Hong Sun, MD, PhD PROJECT NARRATIVE Light alcohol consumption not only lowers the occurrence of ischemic stroke but also improves the outcome of ischemic stroke in people with risk factors for cardiovascular disease. We aim to develop novel strategies for the prevention and treatment of ischemic stroke by uncovering how alcohol alters the occurrence and outcome of ischemic stroke. Studies planned in this renewal application will focus on light alcohol consumption-induced generation of new blood vessels and neurons in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this project is to define mechanisms of immunity and pathogenesis of human metapneumovirus (HMPV), a leading cause of lung infections. We found that virulent strains of HMPV induce types I and III interferon, which exhibit discordant roles in protection and disease. The knowledge gained from these experiments will guide develop of therapeutics and vaccines for HMPV and will increase our understanding of how interactions between respiratory viruses and the immune system contribute to disease and protection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies hold immense potential to provide cures for many cancers and metastatic disease, but the complexity of activating and sustaining anti-tumor immune responses will necessitate combinatorial treatment regimes and a better understanding of how the tumor microenvironment (TME) affects response. Here we develop a in vitro model of the tumor-immune circuit which allows precise control over spatial, molecular, cellular, and mechanical aspects of the TME that affect response to immunotherapy, and use it for both mechanistic studies as well as high-throughput predictive screening of immune therapies in a tumor- or patient- specific manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: FOX CHASE CHEMICAL DIVERSITY CENTER, INC
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of mid- to late-life cognitive impairment and dementia, afflicting ~30 million people worldwide. TDP-43-associated AD (AD-TDP), also called Limbic-predominant Age- related TDP-43 Encephalopathy or LATE, is a recently recognized AD subtype that may be treatable with TDP- 43 targeted therapy. We are developing small molecule inhibitors of nucleic acid binding to TDP-43, which are also TDP-43 aggregation inhibitors, showing therapeutic-like effects in three biological models, to treat AD- TDP and related disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to provide new evidence on the relationship between parental income and children's mental and physical health and well-being through the Y Combinator Research (YCR) Basic Income randomized controlled trial, which will randomly assign 1000 individuals to receive $1000 per month of supplemental income, with a control group receiving $50 per month, for three years. We will survey participants about their children's physical and mental health, development, prosocial behavior, stress, household environment, parental relationships, food security, expenditures on activities and enrichment, and access to and use of medical care. Our study will provide new, timely, and policy-relevant estimates on the impact of parental income on child health and well-being and the mechanisms through which this relationship operates.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One in eight women in the United States have infertility. In-vitro fertilization (IVF) is an effective treatment but can lead to high-risk twin, triplet, and higher-order multiple births. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses unanswered questions about the impact of insurance coverage for IVF on the health of women and infants, and results from this study will provide patients, employers, and policymakers with actionable knowledge that will help them make evidence-based decisions about insurance coverage for IVF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) is a worsening problem, particularly in West Virginia, and current treatment methods are only about 50% effective. Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) is a procedure that implants an electrical device in the brain and uses low electrical currents to change brain pathways. For this proposal, a DBS device will be placed in the reward center of the brain to evaluate the impact on OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We will conduct studies to better understand the function of atrial macrophages in order to advance our long- term translational goal to one day develop macrophage-targeted therapeutics as a new option for atrial remodeling, fibrosis and atrial fibrillation. We will study the role of macrophages in a new mouse model of atrial remodeling that combines clinical risk factors using different cell and gene depletion strategies in combination with single-cell RNA-sequencing. The acquired mouse data will finally undergo rigorous examination for translatability to humans using patient samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The mission of the Institute for Integration of Medicine and Science is to improve human health and well-being and reduce disparities by developing and disseminating innovative, measurable, patient- and community- focused best practices of clincial and translational science. Working synergistically with our partners and collaborators, we will accomplish this by strategic resource deployment, focusing on prevalent challenges in our region, including: 1) the health needs of our underserved Hispanic and rural populations, 2) the special health issues facing military and veteran populations, 3) rate-limiting barriers to translational science progress, and 4) limitations in the translational science workforce required to fill in critical knowledge gaps and improve health in South-Central Texas and the US. Successful strategies for mitigating clinical translational roadblocks and resolving health disparities will be disseminated to our regional partners, as well as the National CTSA Consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Familial Natural Short Sleep (FNSS) is a rare Mendelian form of sleep where affected individuals have a lifelong requirement for sleep that is significantly less than the average person. Identification of genes/mutations in these families will help us understand the biology and molecular basis of sleep. Ultimately, understanding of such biological pathways may lead to novel targets for developing better drugs to improve sleep quality and efficiency.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Enabling technologies are critical for the understanding of the biochemical and physical basis of disease as well as its diagnosis. The COBRE Center for Molecular Analysis of Disease Pathways pursues health-related research that is focused on the development and application of these technologies to understanding disease processes. PHR: The Nutrition Obesity Center at Harvard (NORC-H) includes a rich network of collaborating scientists performing translational studies in metabolism, utilizing advanced imaging, ‘omics, and metabolic phenotyping techniques. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because the mechanisms identified will lead to the development of (bio)chemical strategies to manipulate Zn regulation in Gram-negative bacteria, which are related to many human pathogens. These strategies can be used to effect limitation of the essential micronutrient Zn, increase the toxicity of excess Zn, and thus restrict the growth of invading pathogens. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of NIGMS's mission that pertains to laying the foundation for disease treatment and prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative These studies test the potential contribution of nanoparticle air pollution (AP) exposures, and of specific AP contaminants to neurodevelopmental disorders. It will also extend current studies to determine the relevance of the mouse model, the basis of sex differences in such effects, and how nanoparticles reach and are processed in brain. It will then extend studies to post-mortem brain tissue from individuals diagnosed with neurodevelopmental disorders to assess potential vulnerability of developing brain to AP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While genetic profiling studies have proposed that a step-wise acquisition of mutations drives acute myeloid leukemia (AML) development, the impact of this mutation order on leukemogenesis has not been fully delineated. The proposal described herein aims to interrogate the clonal architecture of AML, particularly NPM1-mutant AML, at the single cell level to identify precise mutation order and common co-occurring mutational patterns which lead to clonal dominance for the development of novel sequential mutagenesis models of AML. These studies will generate accurate models of leukemogenesis to uncover molecular dependencies as clinically tractable targets of NPM1-mutant AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed training program will establish a nurturing, rigorous doctoral bridge program for transitioning Master’s students at Fisk University to Ph.D. programs at University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, specifically in the areas of biomedical data science, computational biology and biophysics. Students will receive interdisciplinary training encompassing technical, operational and professional skills acquisitions through rigorous course work, multi-layered mentoring, support, and inclusive activities that promote improved self- confidence, science identity, and competency. The results of this program will significantly increase the number of successful under-represented doctorate researchers in the workforce of data science and quantitative biology that currently have the most pronounced disparity within the biomedical sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is caused by parasites of the genus Plasmodium and over one billion people are at risk of infection every year. Unfortunately, the rapid development of resistance to all current antimalarials highlights the urgent need to develop new drugs with different mode of actions to overcome this pressing problem. This work aims to optimize two novel, inexpensive and effective classes of antimalarials that target multiple life stages of the parasite. In addition, the proposed studies to uncover how these antimalarials work will reveal valuable information to define unknown cellular (on and off) targets in malaria parasite that in turn will aid the development of safer treatments to circumvent drug resistant malaria in the campaign for disease eradication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding human health and disease requires a deep understanding of gene function for all human genes. The lab mouse is genetically very similar to humans and is used to study the causes of common and rare human diseases. We provide access to millions of data points about mice that have had a gene removed, the data analysis discovers new gene functions and improves our understanding of normal and disease processes with the prospect of improving diagnoses for rare genetic disease and illuminating the causes of common diseases such as heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mammalian cells are constantly exposed to multiple, simultaneous signaling cues, each activating distinct transcriptional programs. Signal stimulation leads to the assembly of megadalton-sized enhancer complexes as membraneless structures called condensates. Our research program will examine the role of nuclear bodies and enhancer-bound condensates in coordinating genome-wide transcriptional programs and how this mechanism opens up novel regulatory paradigms in spatial gene control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The successful cryopreservation of proteins requires the use of cryoprotectant molecules as co- solvents to prevent the formation of crystalline water, which can led to protein denaturation. This SC3 grant is centered around developing novel methods for the cryopreservation of biomolecules by exploiting the glass polymorphism in water, i.e., the existence two amorphous phases with different properties. Because our studies are based on non-equilibrium Molecular Dynamics simulations, these results will provide a fundamental understanding of the atomistic mechanism of protein preservation in glassy water without the use of co-solvents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Children aged 6 and 11 were resuscitated from cardiac arrest and found by our medical centers to have life- threatening heart rhythm abnormalities, and genetic testing found DNA variants altering a calcium-sensing protein called calmodulin (a known possible cause of these abnormalities); however, these variants were of uncertain significance. Because we had previously generated a ‘variant effect map’ of calmodulin by testing nearly all possible amino-acid-changing variants, functional evidence was immediately available to provide certainty to these patients’ diagnosis and enable genetic testing of calmodulin for other family members. Our CardioVar team proposes to generate variant effect maps for more than 25 key cardiovascular disease genes, providing systematic evidence of variant function to assist real-time clinical diagnosis and illuminate molecular mechanisms of cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects 37 million Americans, costs tens of billions of dollars annually, and can lead to progressive kidney failure, cardiovascular disease (CVD), and early mortality. In this proposal we seek to continue to serve as a CKD recruitment site to obtain, in a safe and ethical manner, kidney tissue from individuals with hypertension or diabetes to advance our understanding of CKD and develop new treatments. The kidney tissue samples will be used to create a kidney tissue atlas that includes information on the proteome, metabolome, and transcriptome of individual kidney cells, their spatial distribution, the inter-cellular pathology of CKD, and importantly how these factors vary in different stages and types of CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapy has produced highly durable responses with minimal side effects in renal cell carcinoma, though only a subset of patients respond and there are no current ways to predict response. This proposal identifies a biomarker to fill this void, and seeks to fundamentally understand how this biomarker predicts response. This knowledge will then be implemented to expand the patients who may benefit from immunotherapy, improving patient outcomes and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Powassan virus is a tick-borne flavivirus that is becoming more common in the United States and can cause neuroinvasive disease such as encephalitis, meningitis, or paralysis. However, disease severity varies dramatically among people and it is not well understood how host genetic differences contribute to the outcome of neuroinvasive flavivirus infection. We will use genetically diverse Collaborative Cross mice to understand how polymorphisms in host antiviral response genes influence the disease caused by Powassan virus and other neuroinvasive flaviviruses such as the mosquito-borne West Nile virus and Japanese encephalitis virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Minimal residual disease (MRD) after upfront treatment of multiple myeloma (MM) is used to identify complete response patients at high risk for progression/relapse, however the standard-of-care for MRD assessment by bone marrow aspirates and imaging are not complete and prone to false-negatives. This work seeks to integrate serial epigenetic profiles in circulating cell-free DNA with imaging data to develop, validate, and clinically translate the composite model for MRD detection and tacking of MRD. Successful completion of this study will allow for timely implementation of additional therapeutic strategies and reduce morbidity and mortality among MM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The autoimmune disorder systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) affects as many as 1.5 million Americans, the majority of which are young women of color, and available treatments do not effectively control SLE morbidity and mortality. SLE is inherited, and we have used a combination of genetics and functional studies to identify HIPK1, an enzyme previously studied in the context of cancer, as a potential regulator of lupus susceptibility. The work proposed will establish decisively whether HIPK1 is involved in the development of SLE, and whether drugs that modulate HIPK1 activity represent a new therapeutic approach for management of this significant human health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular mechanical properties such as contractility play key roles in development and are often altered in diseases, thus targeting the altered mechanical properties of cells holds great potential. However, diseased cells often exhibit different mechanical phenotypes and can switch between these different phenotypes during disease progression, which allows them to resist and escape therapeutic targeting. This project develops an engineered high-throughput platform to isolate and characterize mechanically distinct cell subgroups based on cellular contractility, thus providing a versatile tool to understand the effect of distinct mechanical phenotypes on the progression of human diseases such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reprogramming B cells to produce therapeutic antibodies or other transgenes could provide new treatments for infectious and genetic diseases. The current methods for B cell engineering, however, use nucleases like CRISPR/Cas which have potential safety issues, and require first removing B cells from the patient, which is very expensive. Here we explore a potential strategy for editing B cells without the need for nucleases, improving safety, while using a well established, one-size-fits all gene therapy system, thereby reducing cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In addition to genetic driver mutations, activation of emergency myelopoiesis pathways in leukemic HSPCs contribute to the development of myeloid malignancies. The lack of a comprehensive understanding of how the specific biology and underlying molecular regulation of emergency myelopoiesis are altered in different leukemic contexts represents one of the major barriers to developing new therapeutics to treat myeloid maligan- cies. The overall goal of this project is to identify the transcriptional, epigenetic and metabolic mechanisms con- trolling emergency myelopoiesis and driving the overproduction of blast cells and clonal dominance of malignant HSPCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: NARRAVTIVE The translational machinery is a major target of current antibiotics. However, the need for new counter measures has become even more urgent with the rise of multi-drug resistant bacteria and a severe shortage of new antibiotics. Our proposed studies of translation quality control mechanisms in bacteria offer the opportunity to gain novel insights and a deeper mechanistic understanding of a unique bacterial surveillance system mediated by tmRNA and its protein co-factors. A systematic understanding of this extraordinary bacterial system, essential for survival and virulence of many pathogenic bacteria, should pave the way for future development of novel antibiotics and improving current antibiotic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cancer-causing oncogenes are controlled by stretches of DNA called promoters and enhancers, which loop together in complex patterns in 3D space to control expression of genes. Understanding how enhancers and promoters work together to regulate oncogenes will not only help us understand the basic biology of how gene regulation occurs, but will also help us to understand how specific enhancer variants carried by individuals may contribute to their cancer risk. We are employing new CRISPR-based technologies to understand at ultrahigh resolution how oncogene enhancers are co-regulated in multiple types of cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The cells of the developing fetus signal to each other, providing instructions that tell cells which kinds of tissues to form and how quickly and where to grow. We are studying a new type of cell- cell signaling used to control tissue growth and cell arrangement in humans, disruption of which leads to a number of human pathologies including the neurological disorders of Van Maldergem syndrome. Our investigations use the powerful and cost-effective tools provided by a “model” animal, the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster, where this type of signaling was first discovered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Few culturally tailored, evidence-based interventions exist to improve viral suppression and health outcomes in Latinos with HIV, who are disproportionately affected by the HIV epidemic. Drawing from successful formative work in a NIMH-funded K23 award, we propose a randomized controlled trial of ADELANTE, a community health worker-delivered, telenovela-based intervention to improve problem-solving and link Latino patients with HIV to resources for unmet needs. We will assess ADELANTE’s impact on viral suppression, health care utilization, and other health outcomes in Latinos with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is accompanied by the gradual deterioration within each individual cellular compartments/organelles as well as the collapse of the interconnections among them, leading to the establishment of different hallmarks of aging. We recently discovered an unexpected crosstalk between mitochondria and the lysosome (vacuole in yeast) that explains age-associated vacuole/lysosome de-acidification and provides a novel interconnection between age-associated mitochondrial dysfunction and lysosome defects that conserved from yeast to human cells and cause many age-related diseases. In this grant, we will integrate the complementary expertise, techniques, and model organisms from multiple labs, including yeast, human cells, and C. elegans, to investigate how aging affects the mitochondria-lysosome/vacuole contact and validate whether this mitochondria-to- lysosome axis plays a critical role in lysosome acidification in cellular senescence and animals during aging and in longevity paradigms in turn leading to new therapeutic targets for many age-related diseases with lysosome defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular dysfunction is commonly observed in the small vessel disease, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, and contributes to the neuropathology of Alzheimer’s Disease. Utilizing live-imaging and transcriptional studies in mice, I seek to identify how perivascular fibroblasts support the brain vasculature and how their loss in cerebral amyloid angiopathy contributes to vascular dysfunction. Identifying how perivascular fibroblasts support brain vascular function is crucial to develop therapies that improve vascular function and limit tissue damage in Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic social isolation induces detrimental health effects by altering health-critical behaviors. In this proposed study, we plan to elucidate the genetic, molecular, and cellular pathways underlying the timekeeping mechanisms during chronic social isolation and investigate how chronic social isolation alters metabolism. The study will provide novel insights into social isolation, chronic stress, timekeeping mechanisms, fundamental behaviors, and metabolism at the intersection of genetics, biological timing, and molecular biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic brain injury may accelerate the development of Alzheimer’s disease, yet its underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here I address this unmet need by investigating trauma-induced hippocampal microvascular injury using advanced neuroimaging methods, including brain MRI and laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) imaging. My goal is to explore the role of hippocampal blood-brain barrier leakage in the acceleration of amyloid-beta and phosphorylated-tau pathology, white matter degeneration, as well as memory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will characterize interpersonal processes (dominance and warmth) during parent- adolescent dyadic discussions about alcohol use using the Continuous Assessment of Interpersonal Dynamics (CAID) observational coding system, and will test whether these interpersonal dynamics and parenting style impact parental alcohol-specific socialization. Dominance and warmth dynamics and parenting style are expected to render parents’ efforts at harm reduction (discussing potential harms of drinking and allowing children to sip/taste alcohol) more or less effective. The current study will include a longitudinal sample of early adolescents and a parent to better understand the impact of parental alcohol-specific socialization on early adolescents’ alcohol attitudes and beliefs and trajectories of drinking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The goal of this research is to develop a novel image-guided low intensity focused ultrasound (LIFU) based therapeutic modality for effectively treating alcohol use disorder (AUD). We propose to assess behaviors related to affect and to alcohol-seeking in order to identify the neurological processes on which LIFU is exerting its effects, and to examine the molecular effects in the brain following LIFU treatment in order to identify both the network response to LIFU, and to determine whether there are any adverse effects on neuronal function following chronic LIFU treatment. For these studies, we will use male and female crossed high-alcohol-preferring mice, in order to identify whether there are sex-dependent differences in the effects of LIFU on alcohol-seeking, or in the neuronal effects of LIFU.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of the disease tuberculosis (TB), is estimated to infect one-fourth of the world's population, resulting in approximately 1.6 million deaths each year. There is a critical need to better understand the mechanisms of TB immunopathogenesis, as such mechanisms can be targeted to improve host control of Mtb infection. The work proposed in this R01 renewal will further elucidate the mechanisms by which inducible Bronchus Associated Lymphoid Tissue (iBALT) - containing granulomas confer protection against TB and will test approaches for clinically improving iBALT formation and limiting neutrophil accumulation. The knowledge to be gained from these studies is significant, as it will advance the development of new therapeutics and vaccine strategies for limiting TB reactivation and progression to TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The use of hMSCs to treat diverse diseases has recently shown an exponential increase in demand; therefore, it could become a big problem if the cell manufacturing field cannot accommodate the production line to supply future needs. Currently, many of the static in-vitro substrates, conventional culture, and bioreactors systems have offered a substantial benefit for generating high cell numbers, but with limited therapeutic capabilities. This proposal aims to address that limitation by designing a dynamic composite of electrospun- fibers encapsulated in a hydrogel that replicate the dynamic mechanics and topographical structure of native ECM toward high hMSCs production with relevant therapeutic value.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Entrance into adolescence is marked by increased reward seeking and impulsivity, in both human and animal models. This project will investigate how functional and anatomical development of the medial prefrontal cortex contributes to adolescent behavior. Revealing age related differences in neuronal circuits is critical to understanding why animal’s propensity to exhibit certain behaviors change with age and could provide insight into possible biomarkers and predictors of for non-normative behavioral development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is the most common metabolic complication of pregnancy and is associated with an increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes and future type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). The proposed studies will examine how human endocrine pancreatic function changes during and after pregnancy, and how women with and without GDM differ in terms of their glycemic control. The proposed work may identify pathways leading to GDM and postpartum T2DM which can be targeted in novel prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) with its associated fibrosis/cirrhosis is the major cause of liver- related mortality. Here, we investigate how ethanol ingestion produces hepatic mitochondrial depolarization (mtDepo) leading to mitochondrial autophagy (mitophagy), release of mitochondrial damage-associated molecular patterns (mtDAMPs) like mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), and profibrotic responses by collagen fiber- producing hepatic stellate cells. Success of this project will allow development of new mechanism-based therapeutics to treat and prevent alcoholic liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it proposes to test a new psychosocial intervention that addresses a critical intervention gap in current psychosocial care for patients living with advanced lung cancer, the most common advanced cancer associated with high rates of psychological distress and poor quality of life, and which disproportionately affects rural, socioeconomically disadvantaged adults. Because the intervention was designed with patient needs and clinical practice in mind, it could easily be implemented in routine advanced cancer care in both academic and community oncology settings and could be exported for use among the over 600,000 people living with advanced cancer in the U.S. Thus, the proposed research will support the National Cancer Institute’s mission of reducing the burden of cancer through high quality cancer care.

PHR: NARRATIVE Rhythms in biological functions are coordinated by timing cues, such as feeding-fasting and sleep-wake cycles, intimately linking function, metabolism, and the molecular clock. Obesity is associated with enhanced cardiovascular disease risk and a loss in feeding-fasting cycles. The proposed studies will define potential causes for obesity-dependent kidney disease and how timing of food intake is beneficial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Donor specific HLA antibodies (DSA) develop against short amino acid sequences (eplets) within the HLA antigen and lead to early graft loss in kidney transplant recipients. Identifying which mismatched eplets are most high-risk for DSA formation can help to avoid these in upcoming transplants and improve long-term allograft survival. This research will inform the development of a novel and adaptive allocation model aimed at reducing immunological burden, while optimizing racial and geographic equity, and ensuring optimal organ utilization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The routine use of race/ethnicity-based lung function reference equations biases medical care and perpetuates asthma disparities by masking genetic ancestry differences in lung function. While equations that use genetic ancestry, instead of race/ethnicity, more accurately predict lung function for populations disproportionately affected by asthma, whether genetic ancestry-informed lung function equations also better predict asthma- related outcomes remains understudied. We will use six large studies of Black and Hispanic/Latino individuals with and without asthma and build a new prospective cohort of re-contacted asthma case participants to evaluate genetic ancestry-informed equations for predicting asthma-related outcomes while disentangling the social and genetic determinants of genetic ancestry differences in lung function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multidrug resistance in bacteria poses a great threat to human health and is mostly spread by plasmids that maintain themselves in cells using negative feedback control systems. Feedback control is also common in the human body where compromised control causes a whole range of human disorders due to an inability to maintain constant conditions. In this grant we develop and apply mathematical theory and experimental methods to study the principles of feedback control, primarily as illustrated by plasmids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/ Relevance Gastrointestinal symptoms including nausea, dysphagia, constipation, and defecatory dysfunction are significant non-motor manifestations of Parkinson disease that impact quality of life. The degenerative changes in the brain that result from Parkinson disease are thought to originate from abnormal proteins absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract. Thus, by characterizing how those proteins in the lining of the stomach and intestines or changes in the brain centers and nerves are associated with gastrointestinal symptoms, the proposed studies will identify targets for treatment such as medications that neutralize the abnormal proteins or restore normal nerve functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The tumor-associated microbiome regulates pancreatic cancer progression but the exact mechanisms via which bacteria regulate tumorigenesis is still unknown. The proposed work will (1) determine the influence of tumor-associated bacteria on pancreatic cancer cells, (2) determine their ability to activate and differentiate pancreatic stromal cells, and (3) characterize the mechanisms of pathogenicity unique to pancreatic cancer-associated bacteria. Knowledge gained from our proposed experiments will provide insight into therapeutic strategies for gut microbial modulation in treating pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the approximately 50% of non-small cell lung cancer patients who have a charged HLA-B supertype allele, greater clinical activity of programmed cell death 1 (PD-1) inhibitors is seen when mutations generate peptides in which a wild type amino acid is substituted with an amino acid that has a charge opposite from the HLA-B binding pocket, presumably based on favorable binding. Utilizing specimens from our ongoing study of gene modified dendritic cells plus pembrolizumab, we propose to assess the ablity of these peptides to induce anti-tumor T cell responses in co-culture assays. We will also evaluate whether we would be able to pulse autologous dendritic cells with these peptides as a potential personalized immunotherapeutic approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: The nucleus serves as the point of convergence for forces experienced by cells and responds by regulating transcription that drive changes in cell states. How endothelial nuclear integrity is affected by physical forces, such as blood flow remains incompletely understood, yet these effects likely contribute to the initiation and progression of vascular diseases. The proposed work will involve in-depth characterization of changes in aortic endothelial nuclei under disturbed/oscillatory flow and the role of the viscoelastic intermediate filament, vimentin, in protecting the endothelial nucleus from the deleterious effects of fluid flow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need to determine sex/gender differences in cardiovascular, infectious and neurological diseases and related risk factors across the research spectrum to improve health, eliminate disparities and optimize health care. In order to most effectively tackle the significant problems in women’s health, including sex/gender differences, there needs to be a diverse workforce prepared to undertake interdisciplinary, collaborative research. To this end, the Tulane BIRCWH program will provide mentored career development for junior faculty to increase the number and diversity of highly trained independent investigators engaged in women’s health and sex/gender differences research in the fields of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), infectious diseases (ID), and neurosciences (NS) across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: There is an urgent need to train investigators with an understanding of how to conduct research to understand the sex/gender differences in basic disease mechanisms and to understand the heterogeneity of treatment effects by sex/gender in devices, drugs, and other treatments. By harnessing the incredible talent and leveraging the unique resources of the Tufts community, Dr. Freund and Dr. Jaffe have developed and further expanded the Tufts University BIRCWH Scholars Program. This tailored training program for Early Career Investigators focuses on sex and gender differences and women's health research and ensures the training of a cadre of investigators to become the future research leaders in this critical area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECTIVE NARRATIVE Despite the opioid epidemic causing over 46,000 overdose deaths in 2018, opioids remain important drugs for treating acute pain after surgery, and consequently put surgical patients at risk for their myriad of side effects and for chronic opioid use. As recent studies have implicated opioid-induced sleep disturbances as a contributing factor to opioid dependence and relapse, the proposed studies aim to better understand the neurobiological mechanism by which opioids disrupt sleep acutely and chronically. Together, these new findings may offer a new approach in treating those suffering from opioid addiction, and new insights into the role of acute opioid use in sleep disturbances after surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mission of the University of Wisconsin-Madison (UW) Building Interdisciplinary Research Careers in Women’s Health (BIRCWH) program is to provide interdisciplinary career development for a diverse cohort of early career faculty (scholars) and foster their successful transition to independent funding in women’s health and sex/gender differences research. The UW BIRCWH will realize this goal by 1) providing career development opportunities aligned with national goals; 2) offering competency-based, mentored research training; 3) creating alliances with programs designed to support underrepresented faculty; and 4) pioneering new approaches to team science and career coaching. Each scholar will emerge equipped to lead a funded interdisciplinary team engaged in groundbreaking research that will positively impact women, families, and communities.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: Project Narrative The UTMB BIRCWH program launches assistant professors into research careers in women’s health, studying health disparities, Hispanic health, aging, infectious diseases, and reproductive health to improve the health of women across the lifespan. We recruit early career investigators from diverse racial/ethnic backgrounds in a variety of disciplines; they are guided by senior faculty mentors with interdisciplinary expertise in clinical research, drug development, sociology, public health, nursing, infectious disease prevention, engineering, and many other disciplines. Our program’s goal is to increase the number of diverse and skilled researchers who collaborate across disciplines to improve the lives of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement: Ocular surface disorders are among the most common reasons for a visit to an ophthalmologist in the world and are frequently due to abnormal growth and function of the corneal epithelial cells. The research proposed here will identify the molecular factors and pathways important for normal growth and function of corneal epithelial cells, and their deficiencies that lead to sight-threatening diseases such as pterygium and ocular surface squamous neoplasia that if untreated cause corneal blindness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE As humans age, spatial memory gradually declines among healthy adults and those affected by neurological conditions like Alzheimer's disease, resulting in decreased individual independence and quality of life. To eventually develop therapeutics that prevent disease in and rejuvenate the aging brain, it is necessary to first understand the molecular, cellular, and circuit-level neurobiological mechanisms that drive cognitive decline. The proposed study will identify novel molecular drivers of aging in medial entorhinal cortex (MEC), a brain region critical for spatial memory, by correlating age-mediated gene expression changes in MEC neurons with differences in MEC neural activity among young and aged mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative  Alcoholic liver disease leads to cirrhosis and liver failure and is one of the leading causes of deaths worldwide. This project will characterize the hepatic mitochondrial response to ethanol, specifically ethanol-induced mitochondrial depolarization (mtDepo) with subsequent swift increase in alcohol metabolism (SIAM), as well as the recovery of hepatic mitochondria after ethanol by repolarization and biogenesis. Furthermore, the project will determine the possible roles of the adenosine nucleotide translocator, the mitochondrial ATP synthase, uncoupling proteins, and mitochondrial permeability transition pores in producing proton leaks to cause mtDepo after ethanol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This is a proposal to study the formation of nephrons that maintain bodily fluid homeostasis through blood filtration, reabsorption of needed compounds, control of blood pressure, and production of urine for excretion. Our over-arching goal is to broadly understand how physiologically important cell-populations form from precursors in the developing kidney and use these insights to generate replicate cells in human stem cell- based models. A better understanding of the genes involved in nephron development will aid in developing new genetic diagnostic tools for patients with kidney disease and novel regenerative therapies to replace kidney function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative This project seeks to validate an interventional radiology approach to non-surgically deliver and retrieve implantable microdevices (IMDs) designed to rapidly test multiple drug responses directly within a live tumor in its native environment. This approach is less invasive and more practical compared to current surgical methods of IMD delivery, and provides a more comprehensive and direct assessment of drug response compared to current biomarker-based personalization strategies. If successful, it could enable clinicians to screen and optimize personalized cancer treatments in nearly all patients with solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative for R01 application by Esposito  Circadian control of brain-peripheral immune response after stroke  The immune response to cerebral ischemia is a major contributor to neuroinflammation and brain damage while circadian rhythm and aging profoundly impact peripheral immune response in disease. Is it possible that circadian rhythm affects systemic immune response in stroke and if so, is it different in young and aged mice? Here, we propose that Astrocytic HO1 in active phase stroke (ZT13) amplifies endogenous anti-oxidative stress response in CLN, reduces splenic inflammation, and decreases brain endothelial inflammation, whereas in aged mice the brain to peripheral pathway might work differently. Addressing the cause of different response in aging vs young stroke subject might allow us to target specific pathways. This project should define new mechanisms that connect the immune response in stroke with circadian biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: This work will provide critical scientific insight into a novel adaptive resistance mechanism to anti-PD-1 antibody immunotherapy in cancer. These proposed studies are designed to characterize the NLRP3 inflammasome as a therapeutic target and biomarker capable of enhancing the efficacy of anti-PD-1 antibody immunotherapy. Therefore, this approach promises to provide a previously unrecognized immunotherapeutic target that will expand the cancer patient population responding to checkpoint inhibitor immunotherapy as well as a biomarker allowing for improved patient selection and more optimal tailoring of immunotherapy regimens to specific cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We have achieved in nonhuman primates and in initial clinical trials the induction of transient hematopoietic chimerism and long-term I.S.-free renal allograft survival, following combined MHC mismatched kidney and BM transplantation. The proposed research studies will evaluate novel conditioning modalities aimed at improving the consistency of tolerance induction as well as eliminating the genotoxic components from our current regimen, by using a unique mAb107 directed against the archetypal innate immune receptor CD11b, and ImmTOR, nanoparticles containing rapamycin, that potently modulate innate and adaptive immunity towards the allograft. Our preliminary studies indicate that these approaches will provide safer and more effective recipient conditioning, which will make this tolerance strategy available to many more transplant recipients. Our NHP model has been proven to provide strong correlations with subsequently observed outcomes in humans. Thus we anticipate that the results of these studies will be directly applicable to clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative HIV infection of microglial cells in the brain causes HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder and represents a viral reservoir that is a barrier to cure the infection. This study exploits a novel experimental model system where primary human microglial cells and immune cells are xenografted into mice and altered to carry a genetic reporter system to identify actively and latently HIV-infected cells. The system will illuminate at single cell resolution the transcriptomics, epigenomics, and 3D genomic state of the HIV infected cells in the brain in response to antiretroviral treatment and after treatment with latency reversal agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMN) of the pancreas are radiographically identifiable cystic precursor lesions of pancreatic cancer that evolve from low-grade dysplasia to high-grade dysplasia to carcinoma. Through the use of spatial transcriptomics, we have identified sub-type specific (intestinal vs. pancreaticobiliary) epithelial markers of high-grade dysplasia. In this proposal we utilize this novel technology to precisely identify sub-type specific markers of high- grade dysplasia; to incorporate these cyst fluid markers into a recently developed preoperative prediction model; and to validate this improved prediction model on two large clinical and cyst fluid repositories that have been created by our group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Protein translation in the dendrites of neurons is critical for the plasticity that encodes new memories. We propose to determine the effect of pathogenic dementia-causing tau on the protein translation in dendrites and the downstream postsynaptic protein dynamics that regulate the strength of neuronal connections. This research could reveal new ways to restore impaired plasticity and memory loss in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application for an R35 Leadership Award in ADRD research from Dr. Kristine Yaffe proposes to create an exciting multidisciplinary program entitled, the UCSF Population Based Research for Alzheimer's Innovation or Pop-BRAIN. Under Dr. Yaffe and the Co-Directors' leadership, the program will focus on groundbreaking research related to the exposome for ADRD, its effects over the life-course, and how these different exposures may influence health disparities in ADRD risk to offer new avenues for prevention. The program will also foster the careers of junior investigators from a variety of disciplines focused on population health for ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE New oral chemotherapy treatments, such as cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitors (CDK4/6i) for women with metastatic breast cancer double progression-free survival and increases overall survival. Our study will test a new mobile health intervention that facilitates remote monitoring and patient-provider communication outside of clinic visits regarding the use of the medication among 390 English- and Spanish- speaking patients treated at community oncology practices across the country. We will use a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the impact of the intervention on a comprehensive set of outcomes, including rigorous measures of adherence and key patient-reported outcomes, such as symptom burden, quality of life, and survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of our proposed project is to address health inequities in breast cancer screening follow- up among underserved women. We will test whether a community services navigation intervention for women with abnormal results after routine screening mammogram improves follow-up. Outreach to underserved women, who represent a large proportion of late-stage and higher mortality breast cancers, will result in improved follow-up to breast screening leading to improved breast cancer outcomes and decreased health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  Alcohol drinking is a known risk factor of esophageal diseases, e.g., gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC). Using cultured cells and animal models, we will characterize the role of NRF2-ACSS2 axis in mediating alcohol-induced metabolic reprogramming in human esophageal squamous epithelial cells and the mouse esophagus. If successful, this work will lay down a solid mechanistic foundation for NRF2/ACSS2 inhibition as a novel mechanism-based prevention for alcohol-associated esophageal pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Quantifying disruptions in care and outcomes for non-COVID related disease is necessary for understanding the full impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on health care utilization and outcomes. We will measure the effects of the pandemic on diagnosis, therapy initiation, therapy adherence, monitoring, and health outcomes for patients with atrial fibrillation, a cardiovascular disease that affects over 5 million individuals in the US and quintuples the risk of stroke. Our findings will have major implications for the development of clinical guidance and policies that lessen disruptions in chronic disease care and prevent adverse outcomes in future crises.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is a devastating disease largely because it is diagnosed at a late stage when metastasis has already occurred. Our research has shown that pancreatic cancers change over time. The goal of this proposal is to determine the extent that these changes, known as subclonal evolution, can be quantified for clinical benefit and to guide therapeutic management.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer's disease and related dementias are characterized by the intracellular aggregation of tau protein. The goals of this project are to isolate and fully characterize tau aggregates from these diseases, and to provide them along with detection agents freely to the scientific community. The availability of well-vetted resources will catalyze research into how these diseases progress, how they may be diagnosed at early stages, and how they may be efficaciously treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The burden of increasing numbers of older adults in the United States continues to add to the societal burden of neurologic disease, but current treatments and prevention strategies are ineffective for many of these disorders. By supporting early translational research training and experiences for young physician-scientists, the R25 research education and research program continues to be an important mechanism for stoking the pipeline for physician-neuroscientists who will make important translational research discoveries that improve the future prevention and treatment of nervous system diseases. The translational neuroscience community at UCSF is positioned to expand the outstanding environment for the R25 program by virtue of our commitment to training physician-scientists, demonstrated track record of success, existing and anticipated future new facilities, and the research accomplishments of our faculty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will identify the strategies and underlying mechanisms by which HSV-1 circumvents eradication by the type I interferon response during primary infection, establishment of latency and latency reactivation in a mouse model of ocular infection. Recombinant viruses will be used to interrogate the mechanisms by which the latency-associated transcript (LAT) differentially subverts specific type 1 IFN responses including analysis of the roles of the newly identified small nuclear coding RNAs, which may represent actionable targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A diverse biomedical workforce with varied lived experiences is critical for facing complex challenges in biomedicine and public health. The proposed training grant will support minoritized students as they transition from Baltimore City Community College and the Community College of Baltimore County to Towson University where they will earn their bachelor’s degree while participating in research and professional development. This program aims to increase student retention and bachelor’s degree completion while facilitating their progression to advanced STEM education and careers in the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health in so far as the major goal is to shed light on the most salient causes of the reversal of the decline in midlife mortality for U.S. white non-Hispanics with a high school education or less. The findings will contribute to evidence-based social policies and treatment interventions with the most promise for halting increased midlife mortality in an understudied sector of the population at high risk for substance abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol use disorders have a significantly greater impact on women relative to men, which may result from sex differences in alcohol's impact on brain stress systems. This study will test for sex differences in the function and connectivity of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis—a region critically involved in stress—in early abstinence from alcohol. Such knowledge is critical for identifying novel brain targets and guiding the development of sex-specific or personalized treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. O6-Methylguanine methyltransferase (MGMT) is a DNA repair protein that converts O6-alkylguanosine residues arising from endogenous and exogenous genotoxins to guanosine. MGMT is ubiquitously expressed in healthy tissue but silenced in a broad range of cancers by promoter hypermethylation. This grant seeks to exploit MGMT silencing to develop targeted agents for the eradication of naïve and drug-resistant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this competitive renewal of the UC Davis BIRCWH program (PI, Dr. Nancy Lane), we propose to build on the experience and achievements of our previous 14 years of the program to advance, promote, and achieve interdisciplinary training and mentoring of team-based science for the next generation of researchers in women’s health and sex differences. Our BIRCWH faculty, mentors, and scholars will work to improve the health of women and to improve our knowledge and understanding of the mechanisms and manifestations of sex differences in health and disease as well as of the unique afflictions women face with the ultimate goal of more effective prevention, diagnosis, and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Up to 50% of people with HIV (PWH) in the US are food insecure, yet there is limited understanding of how food insecurity (FI) affects the development of cardiometabolic disease among PWH. We propose to explore how FI contributes to the development of cardiometabolic comorbidities in PWH longitudinally and to test a novel bilingual evidence-based intervention designed to improve insulin sensitivity among PWH with prediabetes or diabetes. The intervention harnesses both peer navigation and mHealth. We will conduct this study in a predominantly rural catchment area in the US South that includes Appalachia and has high rates of both FI and HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The engineering of tumor-specific bacteria is a transformative approach to cancer therapy, since bacteria can be genetically programmed to sense and respond to environments and locally release therapeutics. This proposal seeks to engineer genetically encoded encapsulation systems to improve intravenous delivery of therapeutic bacteria for breast cancer therapy. The objective is to create probiotic strains with multiple encapsulation systems, and combine them with previous attenuations tested in clinical trials, to improve colonization efficiency and efficacy while maintaining safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Over the past decade, it has become increasingly clear that the processing, turnover, and generation of lipids in the brain is altered in many aspects of brain disease. However, there is currently no brain-wide atlas of regional lipid distribution and lipidomics in the brain, which is relevant for the functional consequences of lipid metabolism and in the context of disease. Here, we propose to address this major gap by generating a mouse lipidomics reference atlas of the brain, and integrating it with the Allen Brain structural connectivity and gene expression atlases in mouse models of Alzheimer's disease and human brain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Neonates and infants frequently experience breathing interruptions, called apneas, and an impaired response to these apneas may begin a process that tragically ends in Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Autoresuscitation is the reflex process that allows babies to recover successfully from apneas, and serotonin, a neurotransmitter in the brain, plays an essential role organizing and driving this reflex, yet it seems likely that many babies who died of SIDS lacked sufficient serotonergic neuron function in the brainstem, which may be the reason that autoresuscitation fails in these babies. We have discovered a set of neurons, we call `para- serotonergic neurons,' that may transform into serotonin-producing cells as part of a compensatory neural adaptation to stress that promotes a normal autoresuscitation response and reduces the chance of SIDS, and we propose deep functional and molecular characterization of these cells, motivated by their potential as a therapeutic target for pediatric disorders involving cardiorespiratory dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Patients with chronic kidney disease have a higher risk for early death and kidney failure. In this study we will collect medical and socioeconomic information from patients, blood and urine samples and do a kidney biopsy to obtain samples of kidney tissue. The information will be used to understand what leads to the progression of kidney disease and to develop new treatments to avoid future complications in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A practical automated system for complex carbohydrate synthesis is currently unavailable. Iterative enzymatic assembly of carbohydrates is attractive for automation, the final roadblock is the lack of simple and efficient methods for rapid intermediate and product separation. Here we propose a DNA hybridization/dehybridization- based catch-and-release method to tackle the remaining challenge toward the automatic enzymatic synthesis of complex carbohydrates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our understanding of why patients with tuberculosis and type 2 diabetes mellitus have suboptimal systemic drug concentrations and poor clinical outcomes is limited. This project will examine the complex relationship between diabetes, drug pharmacokinetics, and the microbiome in relation to the treatment of patients with active tuberculosis. New insights into the mechanisms underlying low drug exposures in patients with tuberculosis and diabetes may ultimately lead to novel strategies targeting the gut microbiome, aimed at optimizing the clinical care of this devastating infectious disease throughout the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Even though chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects nearly 40 million Americans, advances in the treatment of CKD lag behind advances in the treatment of other diseases. The Kidney Precision Medicine Project (KPMP) aims to reduce the burden of CKD by facilitating the development of precision medicine approaches for the treatment and prevention of CKD. The University of Illinois at Chicago KPMP CKD Recruitment Site research team will make significant contributions to the operational and scientific missions of KPMP by accomplishing the following goals: 1) enroll a diverse cohort of 150 adults with CKD to undergo a research kidney biopsy and longitudinal follow-up and 2) implement a systematic evaluation of neighborhood-level measures of social determinants of health which will advance the long-term mission of KPMP to deeply characterize disease subgroups.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Preterm births are common and costly, and medical and public health experts recommend preventive health care as one strategy to reduce preterm birth rates. Considering that many interconception women with a history of preterm birth do not receive preventive health care but have frequent contact with pediatric health systems in their roles as mothers, we propose a pediatric-based nurse intervention as a novel strategy to reduce preterm births. We hypothesize that care coordination activities will increase receipt of recommended preventive care and that motivational interviewing will support positive behavior change, leading to improvements in subsequent birth outcomes including decreased repeat preterm births.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE During the previous funding period of this R01, we discovered that -contrary to established dogma- central tolerance mechanisms are not only efficient at removing newly formed autoreactive B-cells but also eliminate B- cell tumors that originate from early stages of B-cell development, including B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Here we test the overarching hypothesis that central tolerance mechanisms represent a novel class of therapeutic targets in B-cell tumors that arise from early B-cell development (B-ALL, CLL and MCL).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance) During face-to-face communication, speech is audiovisual: access to visual cues (i.e., lipreading) is particularly helpful in preserving speech recognition when the auditory components of speech are degraded by hearing loss, background noise, or distortion. The present study examines the extent to which visual speech cues facilitate real-time spoken language processing and downstream language comprehension in children with permanent sensorineural hearing loss who use cochlear implants, a population that is at risk for speech and language delay due to their altered experience with sound. The results of the study will provide a comprehensive model of real-time speech recognition, with and without visual speech cues, in school-age children with cochlear implants or with normal hearing as well as inform future studies spoken language interventions for children with hearing loss that vary in their inclusion of visual speech cues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The studies proposed in this application seek to elucidate at the molecular level how the reversible attachment of phosphate to the amino acid histidine in proteins regulates their activity. By analogy with addition of phosphate to serine, threonine and tyrosine, the phosphorylation of histidine is likely to play an important role in normal cell function and in human disease, and in particular cancer, and could serve as a new cancer therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anterior uveitis is the most common form of intraocular inflammation in children and can lead to permanent vision loss and disability if not adequately detected and treated. Current clinical evaluation of intraocular inflammation using slit lamp biomicroscopy is operator-dependent and semi-quantitative. We will evaluate the use of multiple instrument-based objective measures of intraocular inflammation in children, which can potentially enable better detection and monitoring of uveitis so that prompt treatment can be implemented to prevent blindness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our health depends greatly on a balanced gut microbiota, in which methanogenic archaea are sufficiently numerous to regulate hydrogen but not dominant to the point of causing gastrointestinal and metabolic diseases. Central to these archaeal energy metabolisms is methyl-coenzyme M reductase, a nickel enzyme that reversibly generates methane but does so through several intermediates with unknown active-site structures. Studying synthetic nickel complexes with high fidelity to the methyl-coenzyme M reductase active site will help us understand how methane is processed, and will teach us how to efficiently mediate C–H activation, a reaction that can expedite the syntheses of complex pharmaceuticals important to human medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to conduct the first multi-site clinical therapeutic trial in semantic variant primary progressive aphasia (svPPA), and thereby establish the methodology and infrastructure to support many future multi-site therapeutic trials targeting frontotemporal lobar degeneration with TDP-43 pathology (FTLD-TDP). Our investigation of the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and preliminary pharmacodynamic signature of Verdiperstat (BHV-3241), a novel myeloperoxidase inhibitor, will be an important first step in clinical research elucidating the potential pathogenic role of microglial oxidative species in FTLD-TDP. Additionally, our exploration of BHV-3241's effects on candidate fluid biomarkers of neurodegeneration, glial activation markers, and unbiased CSF proteomics, will potentially fill an unmet need for valid pharmacodynamic biomarkers of drug target engagement in FTLD-TDP trials investigating BHV-3241 and other therapeutic candidates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: Project Narrative This research project aims to better characterize the biological mechanisms involved in insulin resistance and their role in Alzheimer’s disease. The proposed research is relevant to public health as it is expected to provide new ways to prevent, delay or treat Alzheimer’s disease, by targeting insulin sensitivity. Thus, the project is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to improving fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burdens of complex human diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease.
