IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Type 2 diabetes (T2D) in pregnancy affects over 100,000 individuals annually in the U.S., of which >50% are enrolled in Medicaid, and most enter prenatal care with suboptimal glycemic control. We propose “ACHIEVE: Successfully achieving and maintaining euglycemia during pregnancy for type 2 diabetes through technology and coaching,” a multi-component intervention that includes a mobile health (mHealth) application, provider dashboard, continuous glucose monitoring (CGM), and team-based coaching for medical and social needs. ACHIEVE empowers Medicaid-enrolled pregnant individuals with T2D and their healthcare providers to achieve and maintain glycemic control, improve access to care, and provide patient education and support.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells require their actin cytoskeleton to divide, move, and communicate with their environment. This project will reveal novel mechanisms of how actin monomers, the basic subunit the actin cytoskeleton, control the assembly and organization of actin structures in the cell. Deciphering these fundamental mechanisms could explain why defects in monomer regulation are associated with human diseases such as neurodegeneration, inflammatory disorders, cardiac disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The widespread use of organophosphate esters (OPEs) as flame retardants has resulted in ubiquitous exposure, which have been observed to impact lipid levels, disrupt metabolic function, and impair glucose tolerance in toxicological studies, supporting OPEs as obesogenic and metabolism-disrupting chemicals. While some epidemiological studies have reported that OPEs are associated with lipid accumulation, specifically increased odds of being overweight and obese as well as higher waist circumference, body mass index (BMI), total cholesterol, and triglycerides, no study has examined the relationship between early life OPE exposures and adiposity and cardiometabolic health in adolescence using a prospective study design. We propose to utilize the Health Outcomes and Measures of the Environment (HOME) Study to examine whether early life OPE exposures, from gestation to adolescence, are associated with adiposity and cardiometabolic health outcomes in adolescence at 12 years using repeated measurements of OPEs to identify periods of susceptibility, while also using advanced statistical methods to account for complex OPE mixtures.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Healthy People 2020 and the National Institute of Health have identified rural health disparities and the lack of research on rural health as top priorities, yet little is known about the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on primary care utilization among rural patients. The goal of the proposed study is to advance knowledge on how the COVID-19 pandemic and subsequent wide-scale expansion of telemedicine has affected the use of primary care services and quality of preventive care among rural, low-income patients compared to those residing in urban areas. This innovative research project will help inform efforts to improve healthcare access and quality of care for low-income, rural patients.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The effect of rurality and the COVID-19 pandemic on telemedicine and preventive healthcare use

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In well-resourced, tertiary care emergency departments (EDs), ultrasonography or magnetic resonance imaging are typically used to diagnose appendicitis, the most common pediatric surgical emergency, in children presenting to the ED with abdominal pain. Clinicians in resource-limited settings such as community EDs, however, encounter a diagnostic dilemma in these situations: they must often choose between computed tomography (CT), which carries the risk of radiation exposure, and watchful waiting, which carries the risk of delayed diagnosis. We aim to develop and test a shared decision-making intervention that would allow ED clinicians and patients/families to make the decision about diagnostic next steps together, with the goal of optimizing resource utilization, increasing patient/family engagement, and reducing unnecessary CT scans without increasing the risk of delayed diagnosis of acute appendicitis.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Testing of an Intervention to Facilitate Shared Decision-Making in Pediatric Patients with Abdominal Pain Presenting to the Community Emergency Department Setting

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Patients suffering from a traumatic injury, autoimmune reaction, or severe viral infection often experience a sense of ‘brain fog’, which is the manifestation of chronic inflammation and acute damage within the brain tissue. We have identified two mechanisms through which innate immune cell activation drives this acute brain damage; infiltration of activated white blood cells from bloodstream circulation and chronic inflammation of brain- resident microglia. We will use drug delivery systems to activate innate immune cells within target tissues (i.e. blood, brain) in a controlled manner, both to uncover mechanistic insights into inflammation-induced brain injury and the lay groundwork for new anti-inflammatory therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation in the brain results in the accumulation of excess waste, fluid, and immune cells which require mechanisms of drainage and coordination with the peripheral immune system. Failure to do so may result in the exacerbation of a variety of brain diseases like Alzheimer’s, traumatic brain injury, Parkinson’s, glioblastoma, multiple sclerosis and stroke. Our lab discovered that meningeal lymphatic vessels at the cribriform plate near the front of the brain are highly dynamic regulators of neuroinflammation and we seek to understand if local crosstalk between these lymphatic vessels and migratory dendritic cells controls disease related immune response in the brain. Pharmacological manipulation of the cross-talk between dendritic cells and cribriform lymphatic endothelial cells may have potential therapeutic value for diseases of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer vaccines are promising strategy to stimulate robust and durable immune responses against tumors, but they have yielded only modest clinical success due to several critical immunological barriers. This proposal aims to address these challenges through the development of a new cancer vaccine platform that targets antigens arising from patient-specific mutations. If successful, this approach to bolstering antitumor immunity has potential to increase the number of patients that benefit from cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: Growing evidence indicates that exposure to chemicals in the environmental might increase NCD risk although the mechanisms of disease initiation are not well understood. In Uganda, the estimated risk of mortality from NCDs is 22%, primarily due to cardiovascular disease and cancer among other factors. This work will assess the risk of exposure to emerging pollutants and the potential effects on mammalian metabolism to provide fundamental knowledge on how environmental insults alter biological processes and therefore inform interventions that prevent diseases and deaths through healthier environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research aims to deepen our understanding of sugar-mediated protein-protein and protein-DNA non-enzymatic cross-link formation. We propose to identify the structural and dynamical molecular factors responsible for these abnormal cross-links in biological tissues. Our theoretical approach complements existing observations by accessing time and length scales invi- sible to experiments. Because cross-links are involved in a broad range of diseases, from cancer metastasis to bone and skin disorders, this project will lay the foundation for advances in disease treatment or prevention, ﬁtting NIGMS's mission statement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Based on our findings in three cardiomyocyte-restricted inducible KO models, we discovered a new GR-KLF15- BMAL1 mechanism regulating clock and metabolism in cardiomyocytes. We test here the overarching hypothesis that this cardiomyocyte-autonomous axis is triggered by specific GC timing and rescues cardiomyopathy in type-2 diabetes. We will test this paradigm by identifying 1) the circadian cue specifying this glucocorticoid effect in diabetic heart; 2) the role of the cardiomyocyte-specific BMAL1 in discriminating between beneficial versus adverse effects of chronic glucocorticoids on heart metabolism; 3) a novel provocative role for the cardiomyocyte-specific GR-KLF15 cascade to reactivate metabolic flexibility in the diabetic heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 3 million adults in the U.S. suffer from inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This project aims to develop clinical proof-of-concept for a novel oral immune therapy, R-3750, which delivers SlpA to the intestinal tract to reestablish gut immune homeostasis. SlpA reduces gut inflammation, reestablishes gut mucosal barrier function, induces positive maintenance of the gastrointestinal microbiome, and eliminates symptoms of experimental colitis. Based upon these properties, commercialization of R-3750 could provide an important new IBD treatment that is oral-based, safer than current drug options, and potentially lower cost.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Oncogenic activation by well-defined mutations of the RAS family of GTPases is among the most frequent mutations in human cancers, but there remains a paucity of FDA approved drugs that specifically target most RAS mutants. We have established an innovative strategy, utilizing protein engineering, to identify novel inhibitory agents to each RAS family member and to select mutants. We will extend our study to address important unanswered questions regarding RAS biology, identify vulnerabilities in RAS mutants, and inform the development of cancer therapy that directly targets oncogenic RAS mutants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While scientific talent is distributed broadly across the United States, opportunities to develop such talent are not. We have identified a partnership between the University of Idaho (U of I) and North Idaho College (NIC) as a mechanism to bring biomedical research training opportunities to students in Northern Idaho who would not otherwise have them. Our program will provide students enrolled at NIC an opportunity to engage in independent research before and after transfer to U of I to complete a biomedical bachelor’s degree, with the long-term goal of increasing the size and diversity of the biomedical research workforce.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Shared decision-making (SDM) ensures that clinical decisions without a single best choice incorporate and reflect patient preferences, thereby promoting patient empowerment, improving transparency, and increasing trust. There are no instruments specifically designed to measure the process of SDM in pediatrics, limiting the evaluation of SDM on health outcomes in this population. The overall goal of this project is to develop and evaluate an instrument to measure the process of SDM with parents of young children.

PROJECT_TITLE: Development and Evaluation of an Instrument to Measure Shared Decision-Making in Pediatrics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Biomedical research is sorely lacking the presence, voice, and talent of underrepresented scientists with doctoral training. Kennesaw State University and the University of Georgia request funding to conduct a five-year Peach State Bridges to the Doctorate Program with the goals to train five Master’s-level graduate students per year and bridge them into PhD programs in biomedical science. Incumbent to carrying out the NIH mission to diversify this field, this inclusive and nurturing environment will provide high-quality research training for URMs with positive impacts within and between the institutions, thereby increasing the number of URM biomedical PhD- level research scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gut microbiome is emerging as key regulator of complex behaviors, including those associated with neurodevelopmental disorders, but little is known about the underlying mechanism. Here, we will use a series of multidisciplinary and convergent approaches to identify the signals, structures and mechanisms by which a given bacterial species (L. reuteri) regulates a selective behavior (social behavior). We believe that these studies could lead to the development of novel probiotic-based non-invasive treatments for individuals with neurodevelopmental disorders associated with social deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and metabolic disorders are increasing in epidemic proportions in the country which ultimately leads to poor outcomes including heart failure. AKT substrate of 160kDa (AS160) has been identified as nodal regulator between insulin signaling and glucose uptake, but research into its physiological role in cardiomyocyte metabolism has been hampered by limitations of available models. In this context, our studies are focused on elucidating the composition of the cardiac AS160 regulatory complex, how this complex and AS160 regulation is altered during disease, and the effect on cardiomyocyte metabolism in order to develop novel therapeutic strategies for cardioprotection in obesity and obesity related metabolic syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early liver transplantation (elT), defined as LT evaluation with <6 months of alcohol abstinence, is associated with acceptable outcomes for patients with severe alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) in retrospective studies. However, prospective, multi-center data including biopsychosocial factors on elT for all patients with ALD in racially, culturally, and socioeconomically diverse populations are lacking. The INTEGRATE collaborative is a highly diverse investigative team that seeks to: 1) define factors influencing referral and waitlisting for elT in ALD (selection); 2) identify which biopsychosocial factors are causally related and predictive of outcomes most important to stakeholders (outcomes); and 3) determine how integrated care among the healthcare team influences stakeholder-relevant outcomes in elT for ALD (management).

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because reducing contaminated urine cultures will help reduce unnecessary antibiotic use, slow emergence of antimicrobial resistance, and preserve the effectiveness of antibiotics for current and future generations. Reducing contaminated urine cultures will also reduce waste of laboratory resources and decrease costs for patients and healthcare institutions. The proposed research is also relevant to the National Action Plan for Combating Antibiotic-Resistant Bacteria because it will improve accuracy of a diagnostic test commonly used to detect resistant bacteria.

PROJECT_TITLE: A Randomized Controlled Trial of a Diagnostic Stewardship Intervention to Reduce Inappropriate Antibiotic Use for Urinary Tract Infections in Primary Care

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Residents of northern Lake County, Indiana, have expressed great concern regarding the potential health impacts resulting from ongoing release of environmental pollutants from the area’s numerous metal, petroleum, and chemical industries. There is substantial scientific data that exposure to individual metals and volatile organic compounds can result in neurotoxicity and other health outcomes; however, there is very little information regarding the cumulative impact of exposure to a complex mixture of these compounds. This community- engaged research project will address both knowledge gaps by characterizing resident exposure to multiple environmental chemicals, determining the association of exposure to these mixtures with self-reported health outcomes and neurological function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed dissertation work will contribute to the fundamental knowledge with longitudinal empirical evidence on the influence of physical, social environmental factors on social isolation and cognitive health, and contextualized the role of technology use. The postdoctoral research will build knowledge on the behavioral and contextual pathways that could explain the association between social isolation and cognitive decline in later life. Knowledge to be built in the predoctoral and postdoctoral stages will be synthesized to inform the development of a technology-facilitated community-based intervention program to reduce social isolation and prevent cognitive decline among older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among the 40% of patients with an HLA-B44 supertype allele, greater clinical activity of programmed cell death 1 (PD-1) inhibitors is seen when mutations lead to peptides in which a neutral or positively charged amino acid is substituted with a negatively charged amino acid, presumably based on favorable binding to the positively charged HLA-B44 binding pocket. We propose comprehensive studies to characterize the effects of these specific mutational events on the tumor microenvironment. We will also evaluate whether these specific mutational events can assist in directing patients to appropriate therapeutic approaches in both early and advanced stage non-small cell lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is commonly applied to women with breast cancer and monitoring tumor response to chemotherapy is currently based on tumor size measured by physical exam, which is subjective, difficult to quantify, and most importantly, temporally delayed compared to underlying biological changes. Quantitative, reproducible, and objective methods that could provide an early detection of tumor physiological changes before size changes could significantly improve treatment outcome and the quality of patient care. Here, we propose to leverage Magnetic Resonance Fingerprinting (MRF), a new platform for quantitative MR imaging that was developed by our team, to develop new imaging biomarkers for early assessment of treatment response in women with breast cancer, with the ultimate goal to reduce ineffective treatment in eligible subjects and tailor the treatment methods for optimum therapeutic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The insights from this grant will be critical to our understanding of the evolutionary origin of human adaptations and the health implications of historical population admixture. The novel methods that we will develop will allow an unprecedented level of resolution regarding the origin of genomic segments and mutations and when and why they had been selected. These insights will allow an accurate interpretation of the landscape of introgression and admixture across human genomes and will ultimately provide a key element for realizing personalized genomics and the utilization of individual genomic ancestry profiles for medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During HIV-1 replication, its proteins are covered in sugar molecules derived from the infected cell. The dense coat of host sugar molecules covers the virus-specific targets on the viral protein, allowing HIV-1 to circumvent proteins made by the immune system called antibodies. We have found a novel subset of antibodies, with an atypical shape, that are able to recognize the HIV-1 envelope protein via the dense shield of sugar molecules that normally inhibits antibody recognition. These antibodies, when found in macaques infected with the macaque version of HIV-1, exhibited broad inhibitory activity against HIV-1 infection. This type of antibody could be part of an effective antibody response if elicited by vaccination. Using these antibodies as a template, we developed a vaccine that focuses the immune response against the sugars on HIV-1 proteins. We will test whether our vaccine that presents only the appropriate type and number of sugar molecules can elicit broad and potent inhibitory antibodies in macaques.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Youth placed in out-of-home care engage in more health risk behaviors, such as substance use and sexual risk behavior, and this risk may be heightened among youth placed during adolescence. However, few studies have tested the short-term and long-term effects of out-of-home placement in adolescence on health risk behavior or examined mechanisms underlying these effects, and no studies have used methods for causal inference that can accommodate the time-varying nature of the variables in these models. The proposed study uses modern quantitative methods for causal inference to test the direct and mediated effects of out-of-home placement on later health risk behaviors among maltreated adolescents, providing important implications for child welfare policy and prevention of health risk behaviors among vulnerable youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquito-borne diseases are a global concern that impact public health, tourism, and natural disaster recovery efforts. With no preventative vaccines or effective therapeutic option available for most mosquito-borne diseases, vector control efforts are the only combative option; however, these efforts are often limited by financial constraint and insecticide resistance concern. This proposed project aims to integrate cutting-edge mosquito collection traps, and novel remote sensing and machine learning workflows to guide local vector operations and direct abatement efforts in a cost-efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Self-help cognitive behavior therapies (CBTs) for binge eating are maximally effective when paired with periodic contact with expert clinicians. Clinicians likely improve outcomes because they are trained to utilize specific behavior change techniques for facilitating treatment adherence and skills utilization during self-help CBT program. Given the limited availability of expert clinicians, it is critical to understand how to enhance outcomes from self-help CBTs without clinician involvement. Technological innovations such as Advanced Digital Data Sharing with Coaches and Just-in-time adaptive interventions (JITAIs) can potentially emulate some of the behavior change techniques used by expert clinicians and improve treatment targets. The proposed study will use a full factorial design, in which 76 individuals with transdiagnostic binge eating will be assigned to one of 4 treatment conditions, i.e., representing each permutation of two intervention factors (Advanced Digital Data Sharing with Coaches, and JITAIs) hypothesized to improve treatment adherence and skills utilization being included or excluded from a base self-help CBT program (delivered via a website and companion smartphone application) without clinician involvement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Conversion of ubiquitous C–H bonds to C–heteroatom bonds could provide expeditious access to medicinally relevant molecules; however, current methods often require the use of endangered transition-metals, expensive enzymes, and/or harsh oxidants. The strategy proposed offers a sustainable solution by utilizing economical photoexcited nitroarenes that serve as the C–H bond activator and the oxygen atom source to enable novel C– H hydroxylation events anaerobically. Strategies for C–X and C–N bond formation at the expense of C–H bonds via interception of the in-situ formed hydroxylation intermediate under these mild and operationally simple conditions can lead to a universal platform for the incorporation of heteroatoms into organic molecules.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIGMS’s mission seeking fundamental knowledge relevant to treating human disease because it will investigate the physical basis and functional consequences of phase separated domains in the membrane and cytoplasm. Understanding these domains could transform our understanding of neurodegenerative and other diseases which often involve pathological aggregation and other aberrant domain formation. It could also transform our understanding of a wide variety of drugs and treatments including alcohol and some anesthetics which alter domain formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Fatal or impairing neurological diseases, including movement disorders, brain cancers, psychological disorders, epilepsies, malformations, and memory disorders, impose heavy burdens on both individuals and society at large. Transcranial magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound surgery (tMRgFUS) is an extremely promising, minimally invasive treatment modality for neurological diseases whereby sound waves are focused to a specific region of the brain and elicit a number of beneficial effects such as heating, immune-modulation, neuromodulation, and blood-brain-barrier disruption. Our experience has identified an opportunity to improve the treatment efficacy of tMRgFUS by resolving a ubiquitous impediment to accurate and information-rich guidance imaging: the acoustic coupling medium. This study will develop and validate a new acoustic coupling medium that promotes more accurate and information-rich guidance during tMRgFUS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The career development plan includes training in alcohol-specific recovery processes and trajectories of change, social identity and social network change processes for recovery during adolescence, social network and mixed methods study design, and lab management and grantsmanship. The K01 study is a longitudinal observational study that will utilize a social identity mapping (SIM) approach to examine social network, social identity, and recovery capital change among adolescents with AUDs in outpatient treatment. The SIM will be adapted from existing adult implementation models to specifically address adolescent needs and a comprehensive longitudinal model of the effects of adolescents' social network, social identity, and recovery capital on substance use outcomes will be developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for minimally invasive, cost-effective and high-throughput methods to identify individuals who survive high radiation doses from a radiological event, but are subsequently at risk of developing radiation induced tissue/organ injuries. We propose to validate the CardioWatch panel predictive of radiation cardiac injury. The long-term goal of this work is to design a kit-based biomarker assay that can be used to estimate risk and severity of late radiation injuries in victims of a radiological event before the appearance of clinical symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will systematically explore epistatic interactions that drive evolution of antibiotic resistance with the ultimate goal of developing novel antibiotics and antibiotic treatment strategies that select against resistance. Towards this goal, we will study molecular evolution of the dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) enzyme in Escherichia coli under antibiotic selection, and engineer mutant-specific competitive and allosteric DHFR inhibitors that can select against resistance-conferring DHFR mutations. Finally, we will develop and synthesize a novel class of molecules that we named “-lactamase traps” (or BLTs) to select against -lactamase genes in Gram-negative bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall objective of this proposal is to develop a workplan for investigating biophysical dynamics of PROTAC interactions by the combination of in silico modeling and in vitro assay screening. The results will provide molecular basis and a technical platform for effective search of therapeutics with a PROTAC strategy.

PHR: Project Narrative It is proposed in this application that the use of a minimally invasive quantitative molecular based mitochondrial DNA content of Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells (PBMC) as diagnostic biomarker to screen chronic hepatitis B (CHB) infected persons in Nigeria will promote early detection of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), minimize hazards and cost of investigation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Evidence-based preventive health services are vastly underutilized by older Americans. This proposal’s promising multilevel intervention will stimulate greater use of the Medicare Annual Wellness Visit, an established but underused mechanism that gives providers dedicated time to focus on preventive health services. The anticipated increase in preventive health services stemming from greater Annual Wellness Visit use will improve population health and lower mortality, particularly in at-risk racial/ethnic minority patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bloodstream infections (BSI) caused by bacteria translocating across an injured mucosa are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in patients who undergo stem cell transplantation. There are no known strategies to prevent BSI from translocation of BSI through the injured mucosa, including those through the oral cavity. Through this study, we will determine the effectiveness of twice daily xylitol-wipe application on reducing BSI from oral organisms through a randomized, multicenter, double-blind, placebo-controlled study in pediatric stem cell transplant recipients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop and validate an functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) technique for mapping awake mouse brain function. Successful completion of this work will create a new fMRI data acquisition and on- line reconstruction package on the preclinical MRI platform, for which mouse models are frequently used to study brain function/dysfunction. Our experiments will also examine the contrast mechanisms of this non-invasive fMRI technique, explore a novel means to further boost contrast, and overcome the key limitations of the conventional fMRI that could translate to significant public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiac arrhythmias reduce the quality of life and increase the risk of death for millions of Americans, yet current treatments are inadequate to the scope of the problem. While there are clear genetic factors that contribute to the risk of arrhythmias, the mechanisms through which genetics confer risk remain unclear. The goal of this project is to address this gap in knowledge with the goal of facilitating new therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Coronaviruses, including the pandemic SARS-CoV-2, have posed severe threats to global health and led to substantial economic loss. However, the limited knowledge of coronavirus biology and pathogenesis greatly hinders the development of effective antiviral treatments. This work aims to understand how the dynamic interplay between SARS-CoV-2 and host factors controls viral gene expression with the goal of revealing novel druggable targets for innovative strategies against these highly pathogenic coronaviruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular diseases involve a phenotypic switch of vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) to diverse, pathological cell states. I will study a transcription factor, MEIS1, that safeguards the VSMC differentiated phenotype thus preserving normal vascular homeostasis. The current proposal utilizes innovative and genetically edited mouse models, vascular smooth muscle cultures, and collaborations with pioneers in the field, to gain foundational insight into the functional role and transcriptional regulation of MEIS1 in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)—which manifests as acute lung injury—is characterized by an exaggerated host immune response and cellular damage, as a result of which it is a major cause of disability and death. There is an urgent need to better understand host immune response mechanisms in the lung, with the goal of yielding new strategies to improve ARDS treatment. Our proposal directly addresses this need by investigating and employing C3—an evolutionary conserved complement protein central to host defense—to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with ARDS due to its ability to protect the lung.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prior social experiences influence our everyday choices; for instance, we might favor a particular restaurant because it’s where we had a first date with our spouse. This process likely reinforces the value of social information but is not well understood neurobiologically. We will study the developmental processes by which organisms come to prioritize social information and use it to make choices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Adenosine methylation (m6A) is a highly prevalent RNA modification that has been linked to several human cancers. The m6A methyltransferase complex has emerged as a potential therapeutic target; however, efforts to identify methyltransferase inhibitors have been hampered by the lack of methods that provide a cellular readout of adenosine methylation on a high-throughput scale. Here, we will develop a novel genetically encoded m6A sensor system that provides a fluorescence-based readout for mRNA methylation which can be used both for high-throughput drug discovery efforts as well as studies investigating m6A biology and its contribution to cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While surgical incision healing is of tantamount importance in restoring the integrity of skin and protecting against invading pathogens, the essential role of cutaneous sensory afferents in recruiting and activating immune cells to the surgical site is not fully understood. The goal of the proposed research is to advance the understanding of neural-immune signaling during surgical wound repair and of the impact of peripheral nerve blocks (PNBs), an indispensable perioperative tool, on this interaction. This work will advance our understanding of how sensory neurons and PNBs impact wound repair and lead to improved, personalized perioperative care of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells in many organisms contain important proteins called nucleosome chaperones that regulate how gene instructions in DNA are copied into RNA before being used to make other proteins. We propose to study this process with tools that let us measure the behavior of single molecules at a time, focusing on how the function of nucleosome chaperones change depending on decorations on DNA-packaging proteins that change with the energy status of the cell. Because cancer cells have more nucleosome chaperone proteins and different decorations on their DNA-packing proteins, and chaperone proteins are involved in replication of viruses, our results may be used in the development of cancer therapies, as well as antiviral therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  A leading cause of microbial infections in hospitalized patients is Gram-negative bacteria, which release the cell wall component lipopolysaccharide capable of activating innate immune pathways. We postulate that ACOD1 is a mediator of lethal bacterial infection independent of its canonical function in itaconate production. Our research could not only provide new therapeutic targets for infectious diseases, but also establish promising uses for anticancer drugs in limiting inflammatory responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The bacterial residents of the gut impact human health. The specific makeup of these bacterial communities can differ dramatically between people, yet how these differences arise is not understood. My research combines computational analyses with experimentation to generate unique insights into the forces that sculpt the inhabitants of the human gut, through the lens of interbacterial antagonism and defense.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE There are ~40 million people world-wide infected by the Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 (HIV-1, commonly referred to as HIV); there is currently no cure, and antiretroviral treatment is the primary treatment option. As antiretroviral treatment eventually fails over time due to the development of drug resistance, we will develop new computational tools for forecasting HIV evolutionary trajectories under therapeutic selection pressure leading to drug resistance, using high resolution all atom molecular dynamics simulations together with physics-based machine learning models of sequence co-variation. The computational work, complimented by structural, biophysical, and virological studies, will lead to the development of surveillance tools to forecast the response of viral systems to the selection pressure of antiviral therapeutics which may be used to individualize and develop new combination antiretroviral therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative: Diseases such as cystic fibrosis, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, idiopathic lung fibrosis and retinitis pigmentosa result from improper biogenesis of mutant membrane proteins and a breakdown of the cell’s innate protein quality control mechanisms. Our overall goal is to understand how ER associated Hsp70 and Hsp40s facilitate the biogenesis, quality control, and maintenance of membrane proteins that perform essential cellular functions and are mutated in recessive (cystic fibrosis) and dominant (interstitial lung disease, retinitis pigmentosa) protein misfolding disease. Mechanisms identified will be targets for development of therapies that can treat this devastating set of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Early stage oral cancers and precancers are currently under-detected, representing missed opportunity to improve the poor outcomes of oral cancer. While screening with conventional visual-tactile examination is limited in accuracy, artificial intelligence-assisted precision diagnostics could shift the cancer prevention paradigm toward screening for the broader population if enabling reliable triage of oral lesions for risk-based management. The proposed disease simulation model will evaluate the benefits and harms of harnessing these devices and precision treatment thresholds, guiding translation toward cancer control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Product safety profiling, of which developmental and reproductive toxicology (DART) testing is an important component, is necessary to determine and continually ensure safe dosage or exposure levels of every chemical that comes into contact with humans. Toxicity testing is mostly done in genetically inbred mammals such as rats and rabbits, but public and regulatory pressure has led to directives eliminating the use of animals in safety testing where possible. In this proposal, we will develop a DART assay using genetically different wild strains of a microscopic soil worm, C. elegans, to provide a faster, cheaper, and more ethical alternative to testing on mammals, and investigate population-wide differences in responses to hazardous chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older individuals have a significantly elevated risk for organ dysfunction and mortality when exposed to trauma or injury. We will examine a previously unknown mechanism for the increased morbidity in aged individuals due to chronic leak of digestive enzymes from the bowel into the systemic circulation and tissues, resulting in gradual but inexorable organ dysfunction with age. We propose and test a new translatable approach to block leaking digestive enzymes originating from the bowel and thereby reduce the high sensitivity to trauma in the old.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will explore a mechanism we have uncovering by which selenium exerts its biological effects in a mechanistically distinct from its ‘textbook’ role of producing selenoproteins. Our findings indicate that selenium can also donate its electrons to ubiquinol and that this is a rapid mechanism by which selenium can counter oxidative stress and restore electron transport chain activity, expanding what is known about selenium in biology. We will explore how this mechanism can protect against cell death in models for various disease contexts including heart attacks, mitochondrial disorders, and environmental toxin exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Time-to-event outcomes are commonly encountered in diagnostic and therapeutic research for heart, lung, blood and sleep diseases, e.g. time to stroke. Because the popular hazard ratio measure does not provide a valid marginal causal effect interpretation, we propose to develop a comprehensive propensity score matching based restrict mean survival time estimation strategy and a software package for clinical researchers to tackle this complex causal inference problems in observational studies. We will also apply these methods to conduct a secondary data analysis on effectiveness of anticoagulant drugs using electronic medical record data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common malignant primary brain tumor and among the most lethal due to their recurrence and therapeutic resistance. These properties are associated with a GBM stem cell (GSC) fraction present within distinct microenvironmental niches of the tumor and we have identified the protein WDR5 as specifically essential for GSCs to grow and maintain stem-cell-like biology in GSC-rich niches of GBM tumors. The successful completion of this proposal will yield an understanding of the roles of WDR5 in GBM niche biology and an appraisal of the therapeutic efficacy of inhibiting WDR5 in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how a subset of surface glycosphingolipids regulate the localization and function of KRAS on the inner plasma membrane. KRAS operates as a molecular switch that regulates cell proliferation, survival and differentiation. Unraveling the novel mechanisms underpinning the role of glycosphingolipids will have therapeutic applications since constitutively activated KRAS must be localized to the plasma membrane in the correct lipid environment in order to function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapies that disrupt immune evasion through the PD-1 or CTLA-4 pathways have shown remarkable efficacy yet fail in many patients, likely due to additional mechanisms that are yet to be defined. This proposal will investigate how epigenetic silencing of the repetitive genome drives immune escape in cancer cells, and will specifically explore the role of the epigenetic repressor, SETDB 1, in silencing transposable elements and immune genes in melanoma. A deeper understanding of these mechanisms could ultimately yield new biomarkers and epigenetic therapies capable of selectively enhancing the efficacy and scope of immunotherapy for melanoma and other cancer types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Developing optimal radiation and immunotherapy combinations is hindered by the limited ability to deeply understand therapeutic responses and there is a critical need to innovate with rectal cancer when cure with radiation and systemic therapy could save a morbid surgery. We have developed an integrated approach to assess early biopsy tissue after short course radiation therapy to assess molecular, cellular, and spatial dynamics that could improve our ability to nominate promising therapies. With pre- and post- therapy biopsies from our αCD40 trial, we will perform single cell RNA sequencing, multiplexed immunofluorescence, deep learning from histopathologic tissue to identify therapeutic opportunities and study mechanisms of response to αCD40.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The drive to eat is mediated by activity in homeostatic (i.e., nutrient need, hunger) and hedonic (i.e., pleasure, reward) neural circuits in the brain. In our modern food environment, this drive to eat has led to an obesity crisis, especially in the United States. The current proposal takes a unique approach to understanding obesity by (1) determining how homeostatic and hedonic circuits interact to promote overeating and (2) revealing how neural activity in these circuits predicts future development of obesity, potentially leading to paradigm-shifting prevention and treatment strategies for obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The Boston Older Americans Independence Center (Boston OAIC) has established a robust interdisciplinary research network among aging researchers from Boston's leading academic medical centers to foster translational research in function promoting therapies (FPTs) – pharmacologic, physical, nutritional, technological and behavioral interventions to reduce the burden of disabling functional limitations in older adults. The Boston OAIC will integrate 19 externally-funded studies, 3 Research Education Core projects, 3 pilot and exploratory science projects, and 3 developmental projects into an interdisciplinary program that is supported by a Leadership and Administrative Core, a Research Education Core, a Pilot and Exploratory Studies Core (PESC), and 3 research resource cores (Function Assessment Core, Preclinical Discovery Core, Biostatistics and Data Science Core). Unique strengths of OAIC include its focus on FPTs; emphasis on translation; demonstrable success in recruiting and advancing talented young investigators, especially physician scientists, including 3 Beeson scholars; its extension across the entire spectrum of translational research; the outstanding productivity of its investigators; strong leadership and institutional support; its success in developing intellectual property, leading and participating in some of the most important randomized trials of FPTs, and in forging synergistic collaborations with other OAICs and with other Boston area aging research programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Overall  Defining bone marrow cell identities and states using quantitative spatial maps of RNA, protein, and N- glycans, our proposed Bone Marrow Tissue Mapping Center will dissect the cellular composition and spatial structure of bone marrow niches to understand which cells and interactions are critical to each branch of hematopoietic maturation. The multi-arm sample collection strategy, leveraging of clinically-validated pre- analytical pipelines, assay technologies (Nanostring DSP, Multiplexed Ion Beam Imaging, and MALDI-MSI), computational tools (pixel-based analyses, cell-based analyses, neighborhood analyses), and biological principles are broadly applicable to and complement other HuBMAP projects. Interrogating the interdependence between bone marrow tissue structure and hematopoiesis is informative not just in blood cell maturation, but for understanding metabolism, aging, and development of cellular therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Completion of this work will provide a detailed mechanistic understanding of how SAMHD1 non-catalytically directs CtIP function in DSB repair to maintain genome integrity and govern breast cancer treatment resistance and new insights into how SAMHD1 dysregulation leads to genomic instability and development of disease, including cancer, autoimmune disease, and viral infection. In addition, this work is expected to elucidate the significance of the SIRT1 acetylome in directing SAMHD1 in DSB repair, providing new insights into the upstream signaling events governing SAMHD1 function in DSB repair and how loss of Sirt1 results in an in vivo tumor permissive phenotype. Finally, this work will establish proof of concept for the use of VLPs with Vpx in targeting SAMHD1 as a novel therapeutic approach for sensitizing resistant breast cancer to DSB-inducing agents that may significantly improve clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many patients undergoing hemodialysis require use of a catheter to secure vascular access, but complication rates are high due to infections and thrombosis; however, no available solutions successfully prevent both these complications. We developed a coating technology to reduce the complication rate with catheter use during hemodialysis by ameliorating thrombosis and infections, and our previous work optimized the coating procedure for hemodialysis catheters. In this proposal, we will complete our path to marketability with the long- term goal of improving the outcomes of patient requiring hemodialysis by reducing infection and thrombosis- related complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Up to 50% of children fed by gastrostomy tube suffer from feeding intolerance but, despite the high prevalence and large health impact of this issue, little is known about its pathophysiology, which hampers our ability to deliver personalized, physiology-based therapies. We hypothesize that patients with feeding intolerance have measurable impairments in gastric emptying and accommodation and that non-invasive biomarkers can be identified that are associated with symptom severity and treatment response. Through this career development award, we will use both cross-sectional and longitudinal cohort study designs to: (1) thoroughly characterize gastric mechanisms of feeding intolerance using gastric ultrasonography and nuclear medicine scintigraphy and (2) quantify the physiologic and clinical impacts of two commonly used but inadequately studied feeding intolerance treatments, erythromycin (which improves gastric emptying) and cyproheptadine (which improves gastric accommodation).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This project is aimed at developing a novel approach to building generalizable models that identify the network level functional organization in the brain associated with clinical symptoms and behavior. Understanding the organizing principles of the brain as they relate to specific psychiatric symptoms and cognitive behaviors will improve diagnoses, aid in categorizing patients, identify treatment targets, allow assignment of the correct treatment to patients, and provide a quantitative means of monitoring treatment response. This work could have a major impact on the application of functional MRI in both basic neuroscience and psychiatric medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome sequencing has enabled great advances in the diagnosis of pediatric rare diseases, but the majority of cases still go unsolved. One issue is that many cases cannot be explained by a single mutation, but instead are caused by an accumulation of mutations across many genes. We will provide computational and statistical methods integrating diverse functional and genomic resources across 1,900 rare disease individuals to accurately identify these complex, non-Mendelian causal mechanisms of pediatric rare disease phenotypes, increasing the potential to diagnose unsolved patient cases.

PHR: The proposal represents a longer-term plan that will develop a new and re-imagined generation of medical imaging instrumentation. It is founded on a partnership of unparalleled instrumentation development capability, coupled with cutting-edge capability in implementing advanced algorithms for multi-dimensional image generation. This will accelerate development, growth and clinical translation of new promising emerging cancer therapy methods. It will also lead to technology advancement that will enable research community and industry in developing next generation clinical imaging instrumentations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Serotonin (5HT) activates more than 20 different GPCRs that couple to every class of G protein. Many drugs use in clinical medicine target 5HTRs and much is known about how these drugs influence G protein signaling from the receptor. However, almost nothing in known about the endocytic and post-endocytic trafficking properties of the 5HTRs either in response to 5HT itself or drugs that target the 5HTRs, despite that fact that receptor recycling and degradation have dramatic and opposing effects on signal transduction. This proposal will address this gap in knowledge.

ORG_NAME: LUNDQUIST INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL INNOVATION AT HARBOR-UCLA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative Aspergillus fumigatus is the principal cause of invasive aspergillosis, which is a frequently deadly and increasingly common disease in immunocompromised patients. The goal of this project is to characterize a novel transcriptional regulator in A. fumigatus that governs host cell interactions and virulence and to discover the downstream effector genes that are controlled by this regulon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop advanced tools to enable faster discovery and design of protein-based drugs for new disease targets. These tools would enable optimization of multiple parameters simultaneously, creating more potent therapies with less side effects. Thanks to speeding up the development cycle and reducing the time to market, these tools also have the potential to reduce end cost to patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The overarching objective of this project is to understand how U.S. state policies and county economic conditions have jointly contributed to the large and growing geographic disparities in midlife mortality, psychosocial wellbeing, and health behaviors. It develops innovative measures of state policy contexts and county economic conditions over 40 years to predict 1) deaths from all causes, 2) deaths from specific causes driving the rise in midlife mortality (drug overdose, alcohol poisoning, suicide, and cardiometabolic diseases), and 3) the psychosocial and behavioral risk factors for those causes of death. The findings can inform broad policy responses and targeted interventions to reduce the geographic disparities in midlife mortality in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Increased susceptibility to secondary bacterial pneumonia after recovery from primary influenza infection is an important clinical complication. Host immune factors, rather than pathogen associated molecules, are now well recognized as central players in determining susceptibility to secondary infection. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Our proposed studies elucidate a novel transcriptional gatekeeping mechanism involved in dysregulated immune response of alveolar macrophages to secondary bacterial infection. We identify immune and epigenetic factors that imprint an immunological memory in alveolar macrophages during prior influenza infection, that causes these cells to mount an early and exaggerated inflammatory response upon subsequent secondary bacterial infection, resulting in sepsis and severe disease. Our proposal identifies novel therapeutic targets that will have significant impact on designing measures to correct the innate immune cell dysfunction, not only in secondary infections but also in other airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving outcomes associated with treatment of head and neck cancers demands early determination of metabolic, functional and molecular changes that unfold in the tumor microenvironment. The current proposal leverages non-invasive, quantitative, and frequent measurements to reveal the poorly understood time-course of biological responses to clinically relevant doses of radiation and chemotherapy using diffuse reflectance and Raman spectroscopy. Furthermore, we will develop an endoscope-compatible multimodal optical probe for in vivo monitoring of treatment resistance that will enable real-time determination of spectral markers, and therefore, provide the rationale for personalizing treatment for patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Morphogenesis, the biological process that causes cells or tissues to attain their characteristic shape, is highly conserved throughout phylogeny and is fundamental to development and wound healing. We use powerful imaging, genetic, biochemical and biophysical approaches to investigate cell sheet morphogenesis in a model system, Drosophila melanogaster. Our studies are designed to probe the molecular function of key players in contractility (the motor proteins, myosins) and to identify new genes that regulate and drive cell sheet movements, then investigate the molecular basis for how the genes c0ntribute to such morphogenesis – our work continues to provide important insights into the basic biological mechanisms that go awry in human pathologies such as cardia bifida, spina bifida, cleft palate and wound-induced, epithelial lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sinoatrial node dysfunction that affects one in 600 people over 65 years of age is mainly treated by an implantable pacemaker to restore the sinus rhythm; however, electronic devices have inherently insurmountable design limitations. The goal of this proposal is to understand how the microenvironment and imposed forces affect the pacemaking function in pacemaking cells differentiated from human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs). Findings form this study can generate a sustainable source of pacemaking cells for engineering biopacemakers that circumvent limitations associated with electronics and inspire new therapeutic strategies or preventive measures for sinoatrial node dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The ability of cells to regulate proteostasis in response to protein unfolding and aggregation is essential for their survival and health. In this project, we propose a multi-model approach to determine how protein AMPylation regulates the proteostasis network in health and disease. The results of our studies will expand our understanding of the processes that control proteostasis and protein aggregation, which will immediately benefit our efforts to develop novel therapies for aging- and protein aggregation-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Novel mechanisms for post-transcriptional gene expression regulation continue to emerge. I recently identified the role of ribosome to enhance translation of canonical open reading frames by translating small ORFs (downstream ORFs or dORFs) in the 3’UTR. Since dORF is a novel, widespread and strong regulatory element among vertebrates, this proposal aims to study the mechanism of dORF regulation and the biological impact of dORF dysregulation in cancer. This will help us better understand post-transcriptional regulation in cancer and further, may provide dORF as new diagnostic regions of the mRNA and potential targets for drug design.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Word reading disability is the most frequently diagnosed form of learning disability in children, having a major impact on health and quality of life, with effects associated with poor academic achievement, employment prospects, and problems with social relationships. Understanding complex behavioral phenotypes of RD that vary as a function of child experience and cognitive ability across linguistically diverse samples of learners who have been historically under-represented in research on specific learning disabilities is a fundamental step towards improving identification, prevention, and treatment of reading problems. The overarching goal of this LD Hub is to continue to lay the foundation for a generation of research that situates educational practices (e.g., diagnosis, curriculum, instruction, & intervention) in a novel theory of individual word reading development with the knowledge and product generated from this Hub being used to inform future behavioral, computational, and neurobiological studies examining the development of word reading skills and will be used to align theories describing the relations between child- and word-attributes that explain individual differences in word reading more closely with the educational challenges confronting educators of both typically developing (TD) and more specifically children with reading disability (RD), while also expanding our emphasis to assess where important differences exist in under-represented populations in RD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to human health because Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is the number one infectious disease killer in the world. The ability of innate immune cells to kill or control Mtb infection is critical for disease outcomes. Therefore, I aim to understand how this process is regulated in hopes of one day developing therapeutics designed to enhance macrophages' antibacterial responses and control infection in human patients. The proposed research is relevant to the part of NIH's mission that pertains to making fundamental discoveries that will help prevent and treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Pediatric nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is a major clinical condition since it is most common chronic liver disease in children. New knowledge in disease mechanisms is necessary to understand how liver injury progresses from simple fatty liver to steatohepatitis since this may lead to serious complications, such as cirrhosis, cancer or liver failure. This proposal investigates whether DNA damage response mediated by ataxia telangiectasia mutated gene pathway, which governs major cellular processes, will be altered in pediatric nonalcoholic fatty liver disease – this will allow ways to improve outcomes and health in children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative There is a critical need for well-trained neurosurgeon-scientists and neurologist-scientists to conduct basic, clinical, and translational research that will lead to improvements in the treatment or cure of neurological disorders. These individuals occupy a unique space working at the interface between clinical medicine and scientific discovery. The immediate goal of the proposed Washington University in St. Louis Neurosurgery and Neurology Research Education Program is to train neurosurgery and neurology residents in either basic or clinical science research, so as to foster their academic success and development into independent physician-scientists who can further our understanding of the mechanisms, etiology, and treatment of neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hispanic children with cancer are significantly underrepresented in cancer clinical trials, therefore there is an urgent need to identify effective interventions to overcome low clinical trial participation to equitably benefit Hispanics. Our long-term goal is to implement generalizable, targeted, effective, and reproducible peer navigation interventions to enhance minority accrual to clinical trials and our overarching objective for this R01 is to increase clinical trial accrual in Hispanic children with cancer by improving research literacy in their parents in a Hybrid randomized clinical trial to both test COMPRENDO (ChildhOod Malignancy Peer REsearch NavigatiOn) peer navigation effectiveness and explore multisite implementation determinants. COMPRENDO has the potential to increase clinical trial accrual in Hispanics across the age continuum, enabling the equitable translation of discoveries and therapies, which is a top priority for NCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children born extremely preterm exhibit much higher rates of cognitive function impairment during early childhood through adulthood than those born full term. We propose to examine relationships among gene variants, DNA methylation, neonatal inflammation, and developmental trajectories of cognitive function in extremely preterm children ages 2-17 years. This study will be among the first to identify genetic and epigenetic factors that can be used for risk stratification, as well as molecular processes that can be the targets of early risk-mitigating interventions to improve quality of life for children born extremely preterm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous glucose monitoring devices have improved glycemic and quality-of-life outcomes in persons with type 1 diabetes and have become the standard of care. However, significant and persistent disparities in their use have emerged, particularly in Black and Latinx youth, in whom rates of adoption and continued use trail behind their non-Latinx white counterparts. Developing and evaluating effective strategies to facilitate successful diabetes technology use that is developmentally and culturally responsive to Black and Latinx youth are critical and necessary steps to mitigate disparities and improve metabolic and behavioral health in adolescents with type 1 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary hypertension leads to right heart failure and death. Mechanistic details of right heart failure remain elusive with no approved therapies directly targeting the failing right heart. This proposal investigates the role of Snai1-LOXL2-CTGF axis in endothelial-to-mesenchymal-transition and fibrosis associated with right heart failure and proposes targeting Snai1 and/or LOXL2 as novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will focus on how a particular class of bacterial systems controls important aspects of bacterial survival and lifestyle decisions such as antibiotic resistance and the transition to an infective state. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Humans with mutations in CLCN6, which encodes the ClC-6 chloride channel, have reduced hypertension risk, therefore, ClC-6 may be revealed as a possible novel therapeutic target, but more information about its function is essential. These studies will form a necessary foundation for the role of the channel encoded by the CLCN6 gene and provide mechanistic insight into its physiological functions and the molecular processes controlled by this understudied transporter.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: HMG-CoA reductase (HMGR), a key enzyme of cholesterol synthesis and the target of statins in the clinic, is regulated by controlled degradation. We have discovered the mechanism of regulated degradation, called mallostery, in which a protein quality control pathway is harnessed for selective HMGR destruction. We are exploring the features of mallostery, to understand its role in a growing number of cellular processes, and as an exciting avenue towards an entirely new class of pharmaceutical agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: This proposed U54 Collaborative Partnership between NCCU and UNC involves increasing NCCU alcohol research and student research experiences in fetal alcohol toxicity, alcohol neurotoxicity, and alcohol-induced carcinogenesis and inflammation. Health disparities include increased severity of alcohol-related pathology. Collaborative partnerships that carry out integrated and focused research on the molecular mechanisms of alcohol pathology involving faculty and students from NCCU, a historically Black College or University, educate and involve future researchers on alcohol-related health disparities and provide opportunities for careers in medical fields as well as making discoveries on mechanisms that may lead to cures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed activities will bring new insights from neighborhood research into the geroscience domain by extending studies of neighborhood disadvantage and brain health into the middle-age phase of life, where dementia prevention may be possible. This work will inform the identification of high-risk individuals and significantly advance the evidence base needed for developing neighborhood-level dementia prevention efforts. The long-term goal of this line of research is to lower the global burden of degenerative brain disease through better understanding of modifiable risk factors for dementia and improved identification of at-risk individuals before disease end-points emerge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE: The current treatments for alcohol use disorders are not universally effective, so determining new therapeutic areas is of critical concern. Astrocytes, key regulators of the neuroimmune response and neurotransmission, represent a novel target by which to reduce excessive alcohol consumption. The results of the current study will explore the viability of reducing binge drinking and cognitive deficits through manipulating astrocytic regulations of neuroimmune and glutamate signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as an understanding of those molecular pathways that modify sensitivity to prenatal alcohol exposure-induced birth defects is expected in the long-term to inform clinical practice and ultimately reduce the incidence and severity of Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD). This objective will be met by applying two innovative and complementary approaches to assess in cell and animal models if novel genes or chemicals modulate the deficits elicited by ethanol exposure. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the parts of NIH/NIAAA’s mission that pertains to characterizing biological mechanisms underlying FASD, identifying biomarkers of prenatal alcohol exposure, and ultimately will reveal fundamental and novel insights into the mechanism of ethanol-induced birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hypoglycemia is a dangerous condition resulting from exogenous insulin therapy in Type 1 Diabetes that could be remedied by endogenous glucagon secretion. We found that while alanine or glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) alone induce modest increases in glucagon secretion, the combination of alanine and GIP synergistically increase glucagon secretion. In this proposal, we will test the hypothesis that -cell secretion of glucagon is able to mitigate insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This proposal will identify and characterize the posttranslational modifications (PTMs) of the proteome of emerging viruses (the `viral PTMome') as well as the modifying enzymes that control viral PTMs and thereby virus replication and pathogenesis. We will use an integrative approach that combines proteomics and gene-targeting screens with molecular, biochemical, and virus infection studies to address fundamental unanswered questions in virology, which will spur entirely new lines of treatment for a range of infectious diseases that represent public health threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to investigate the effects of alcohol on mammary stem cell deregulation and genomic instability in mammary tumor initiation and development. The role of the alcohol metabolite, acetaldehyde, in this process and the consequent molecular changes will be studied using transgenic animal models. Results from this project are expected to advance our understanding of the mechanisms of alcohol-associated breast cancer risk.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This study will advance the current understanding of stress and deleterious aggression in captive nonhuman primates using an experimental social network approach that will allow the development of an adaptive management program for primate facilities that will enhance group stability and successfully reduce stress and deleterious aggression, and prevent severe outbreaks in group-housed rhesus macaques. The rhesus macaque is an important biomedical model for human health research and this research is relevant by addressing the 3R's and their effects on biomarkers of individual health in a well-established nonhuman primate model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Our training program for “Translational Research In Alzheimer’s and Related Dementias (TRIAD)” will provide predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees with the cross-disciplinary knowledge and skills needed to discover, develop, and advance new treatments for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias. Trainees will be provided with expertise in cutting edge approaches from molecular methods to preclinical approaches and translation to clinical research. Our highly collaborative, interdisciplinary, and supportive team-based environment at the University of Kentucky will produce the skilled workforce that is critically needed to conduct basic, translational, and clinical research for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The public health relevance of MIDUS is its rich contributions to knowledge of how psychological and social experiences in early and middle adulthood matter for later life health and wellbeing. Psychosocial factors are recognized as protective resources as people deal with varieties of adversity, and MIDUS is at the forefront of explaining how they promote resilience by linking them to biology and neuroscience. Importantly, many of these psychosocial factors are modifiable, making them powerful targets for prevention and promotion of positive health among U.S. adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) We will elucidate the mechanisms by which DNA breaks suppress proliferation in developing B cells to promote normal development and suppress leukemic initiation. We will also delineate RAG-specific mechanisms that regulate DNA damage responses, which will establish critical insights into immune deficiencies and tumor suppressor pathways in B cells. This work will identify new approaches for engineering cellular responses to DNA injury and will reveal new therapeutic opportunities for B cell leukemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal is designed to utilize state-of-the-art gene editing technology for knocking out genes that control liver development in the mouse embryo. To replace that liver with one derived from a rat, we will then inject stem cells from a donor rat into the blastocyst of the mouse. This should allow the mouse fetus to grow and function with a new liver that is derived from an entirely different animal species than mouse. These pilot studies are designed to ultimately develop a reproducible and efficient method for generating human livers in pigs for transplantation without the need for immunosuppression; and represent a glimpse into the future of highly individualized medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI) is a common reason for antibacterial use and overuse globally. The objective of this proposal is to develop and evaluate an evidence-based, cost-effective strategy to improve antibacterial use for LRTI in a low-resource setting. The long-term goal of this work is to translate these methods to other low-resource settings to combat the growing global crisis of antimicrobial resistance.
