IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The vector-borne spirochetes that cause relapsing fever are transmitted to humans by either ticks or human body lice, and although the etiological agents of relapsing fever were identified over 100 years ago, very little information exists regarding the pathogenic strategies employed by these bacteria. We will gain critical knowledge regarding the regulatory networks that control adaptation of tickborne relapsing fever spirochetes during transmission and infection and identify virulence determinants required by the bacteria for host-pathogen and vector-pathogen interactions. Regulators and virulence factors identified in this project represent potential targets against which future therapeutic interventions and/or diagnostics for tickborne relapsing fever could be developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study aims to solve critical limitations of adoptive cell therapy of cancer by facilitating the development and evaluation of “off-the-shelf” engineered anti-tumor T-cells that will a) resist host immune rejection and b) withstand the immunosuppressive microenvironment of solid tumors. In the F99 phase, I will modify therapeutic T-cells to selectively recognize and eliminate alloreactive lymphocytes via an alloimmune defense receptor (ADR), and in the K00 phase I will identify key changes in tumor microenvironment in response to T-cell activity to further engineer therapeutic T-cells for optimal performance in solid tumors. Successful completion of this proposal will inform the development of next-generation banked T-cell therapies that are safe and effective in cancer patients.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE There are major challenges facing the nephrology community in the United States: the overall decrease in interest in nephrology as a specialty and the decreased interest in a career as physician scientist. Therefore, implementation of programs at earlier stages of training in areas where the interest in academic medicine is diminishing is a priority. The goal of this proposal is to engage first year medical students across the Florida state in a summer program designed to foster interest in nephrology by exposing students to basic, clinical, and translational science research opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The composition and concentration of proteins in a cell are tightly regulated to maintain cell identity and ensure physiological functions. We propose to apply stable isotope labeling, mass spectrometry, and kinetic modeling methods to understand how the processes of protein synthesis and degradation are orchestrated during cell state transitions in human induced pluripotent stem cell differentiation into various cell types. The resulting knowledge, data, and software tools have the potential to advance current understanding of cellular differentiation and open new avenues for disease modeling and tissue engineering applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Opioid use disorder most commonly begins during adolescence and young adulthood and requires early intervention to prevent lifetime harms. This project will use Medicaid data from across the US and apply a novel analytic framework, the Cascade of Care, to the care of youth aged 13-25 with opioid use disorder. Researchers will identify racial and ethnic disparities in key stages of the Cascade of Care (diagnosis, treatment initiation, medication receipt, short-term engagement, and long-term retention), examine the role of medications in promoting treatment engagement and retention in youth of color, and measure real-world health outcomes in youth who fall out of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Extreme weather events such as wildfires and prolonged drought in the last decade alone have adversely affected air pollution exposure in states such as California, resulting in a number of metropolitan counties with particulate pollution levels above federal and state ambient standards and levels that rival the world's most polluted cities during large wildfires. In this application, we will leverage 25 years of follow-up in the California Teachers Study cohort to evaluate the intersection of severe weather events and air pollution in an aging female population who are at their peak susceptibility for stroke and other cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The interplay between anti-phage defense systems in bacteria and counter-defense strategies in phages can determine phage infection outcomes, which in turn have widespread impacts on the evolution and treatment of infectious disease. Most defense and counter-defense systems in nature have not been identified, so we will apply a novel functional selection scheme to identify these systems from various metagenomes and libraries of synthesized phage genes. We will then use genetic and functional techniques to characterize these systems mechanistically and reveal fundamental insights into the molecular arms race between bacteria and phage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The 5-year survival rate for patients diagnosed with the blood cancer acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is 27.4% and the median survival for relapsed elderly patients is less than 7 months despite significant advances in care. We have developed an immunotherapy that genetically engineers human T cells to target a protein called FLT3 on leukemia cells. Upon conclusion of these studies of this FLT3 immunotherapy T cell drug, we will better understand how to treat AML and be poised to start a therapy directed at curing a greater fraction of AML patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The percentage of underrepresented minorities in the biomedical careers is below the corresponding percentage for majority groups. The primary emphasis of Project ACE -- ACtion for Equity: A BUILDing SCHOLARS Pipeline is to increase the number of underrepresented students from historically and economically disadvantaged backgrounds in the biomedical fields through instruction based on a research- infused curriculum. By exposing students to biomedical research at the high school level; incorporating their teachers in research experiences; and engaging students' families in their academic and research skills growth, Project ACE will create a pipeline of Hispanic students from economically disadvantaged high schools who are prepared academically and socially to pursue biomedical careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The objective of this training program is to offer an integrative curriculum and environment needed to train the next generation of thought leaders and workforce that are versed in convergence research leading to regenerative engineering solutions for adult and pediatric patients with major disabilities. Specifically, program graduates will have the capacity to develop scientific, technical, and clinical knowledge and skills that will enable them to recognize and solve challenges associated with the restoration of tissue and organ function. Core innovative and unique elements of the program include: 1) clinical rotations to gain direct insight into organ failure and tissue reconstruction challenges that afflict patients and physicians; 2) a 3-member mentorship team that includes 1 clinical, 1 life/physical sciences, and 1 engineering faculty member; 3) internships at companies and/or institutions with product development expertise involving regenerative engineering; and 4) experiential courses to learn experimental techniques that are essential to the implementation of regenerative engineering.
PROJECT_TERMS: Regenerative engineering;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Regenerative Engineering Training Program (RE-Training)

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants with medical complexity are a medically vulnerable population with high emergency department and inpatient resource use, disparities in care (notably among rural populations), and significant adverse emergency health outcomes. Through the proposed training and research plan, the PI will optimize and implement an advanced emergency care planning tool for infants with medical complexity through a user- centered dissemination and implementation science approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of human papillomavirus (HPV)-related oropharynx cancer is increasing, patients have a 20% risk of dying within 5 years of diagnosis with this disease, and treatment often has severe negative effects on long-term quality of life. We’ve characterized two main types of this disease that depends on whether HPV has become integrated into the patient’s own genome in their tumor cells. In this grant, we will study the effects of HPV integration and their relationship with survival, with the goal to improve patient’s quality of life and chance of survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative Chemotherapy treatment during cancer treatment can induce cognitive impairments, and often involves environmental influences such as oxidative stress. The manipulation of anti-oxidant molecules in normal brain tissues may impact critical events associated with behavioral performance. The ability to quantify and interrelate measures of neuronal morphology, biochemistry and behavioral performance in animals that overexpress a specific anti-oxidants will provide novel insight about chemotherapy induced cognitive impairment, and may ultimately contribute to the development of strategies or approaches for the management of this serious complication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRAVTIVE Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are highly prevalent in adolescent girls and young women and, in many regions of the world, diagnostic testing is not widely available; therefore, women only receive treatment if they report symptoms. However, the majority of women with an STI do not experience symptoms, resulting in persistent infections that can have serious consequences for reproductive health. In this proposal, we will assess the acceptability of point-of-care STI testing plus expedited partner treatment and its impact on the incidence of common curable STIs among women at risk for STIs and HIV, providing critical information to national policy makers and reducing the burden of STIs in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term goal of the RCMI Specialized Center, Ola HAWAII, is to improve minority health and reduce health disparities for those communities in Hawaii which suffer disproportionately in health outcomes and healthcare access. In the next five years, the objective of the Center is to lead and advance minority health and health disparities research in Hawaii. Ola HAWAII has assembled an exemplary team to build institutional capacity in basic biomedical, clinical and behavioral research; engage underserved communities; mentor and support a diversified workforce; and enhance core facilities and resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood cancers are caused by genetic mutations inherited at birth or acquired during cancer development. Understanding these mutations is critical for accurate diagnosis and treatment of children and young adults with cancer, but they are currently under-represented in public genetic databases. We will develop procedures and expert panels to fill this gap by performing focused curation of mutations found in childhood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge in neuroscience is to uncover how defined neural circuits in the brain encode, store, modify, and retrieve information. Technological advances have allowed researchers to begin to optically measure and modulate neural activity, and while a great deal of scientific and technical progress has been made, there is still much to learn concerning complex neural function, especially within the context of natural behavior. Here, we will fill this gap by developing open-source, head-mounted miniature microscopes with closed-loop spatiotemporal illumination capabilities for large-scale, real-time, patterned photo-stimulation and improved neural imaging in freely behaving animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This innovative proposal builds on a novel hypothesis that neighborhood characteristics can contribute to substance use disorders among urban youth of color. Using geospatial analysis and machine learning methods, this study will have a high impact on aiding prevention scientists to better predict and prevent substance use disorders among urban youth by identifying place-based factors. This study will also serve as a guide for addiction researchers on how to work collaboratively with community members to avoid racial bias in predictive algorithms and develop sustainable solutions that will serve communities in an equitable way.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Cognitive and emotional health is critical for independent living and quality of life. Using decades of multi-domain longitudinal data, the proposed project will investigate risk and protective factors that can inform interventions and treatments to prevent or reduce cognitive declines, emotional impairments, and dementia. MIDUS is unique for its emphasis on the interplay of cognitive, emotional, biological, and brain health as well as its capacity to illuminate how racial and socioeconomic disparities can contribute to AD/ADRD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a highly prevalent and costly condition in the United States and a major cause for disability worldwide. Chronic pain is still a clinical diagnosis not based on objective and quantitative measures, which results in a large variability in patients’ classification often even under the same condition and hampers clinical care and scientific research. By drawing a parallel between chronic mental illness and chronic pain, this proposal aims to study the validity of quantitative language processing and audio-visual data analysis in discriminating between different types of chronic pain patients and in predicting response to treatment to derive quantitative and reliable biomarkers for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Children and adults with acute leukemias have dismal outcomes with current therapy. The planned research project is relevant to public health because the elucidation of oncogenic transcription factor function and development of effective therapeutic strategies will lead to improved therapies for patients. The proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH mission and the urgent unmet need of understanding of molecular mechanisms of aberrant cancer gene control, thereby elucidating fundamental causes and developing improved treatments of human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evolution tends to improve or remove a gene that is bad at what it does. A gene that nominally causes cell death often fails to kill cells; yet it is still found across many organisms and actively utilized. Perhaps we mis-understood its true, underlying functions? We refocus its role as a “trial-by-fire” and outline the novel tools and methods we will use to examine the evolutionary benefits that allowed this gene family to thrive and diversify.

PROJECT_TITLE: Pyroptosis is a Trial-by-Fire Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effects of paternal exposure to non-persistent pesticides on male reproductive health and offspring health remain unclear as well as the potential mechanisms that explain the associations. This proposal seeks to evaluate male pesticide exposure in relation to semen parameters, sperm DNA methylation, mitochondrial DNA biomarkers, pregnancy and perinatal outcomes as well as epigenetic aging. The proposed study will increase our understanding of how men’s non-occupational exposure to pesticides - a relatively understudied area - impacts couples’ and offspring’s health through sperm and elucidate underlying biologic mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) improves glycemic control, reduces hypoglycemia and facilitates personalized care in insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes (T2D) but are vastly underutilized. Multilevel interventions are increasingly recognized as a promising strategy for addressing complex healthcare problems, such as incorporating CGM devices into routine diabetes care. This proposal aims to apply Implementation Science to develop and test an innovative, multilevel intervention to support adoption and retention of CGM for insulin- requiring T2D patients in primary care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our objective is to develop a diverse pool of well-prepared interdisciplinary investigators focused on advancing knowledge about women's health, the influence of sex and gender on health and disease, and the causal underpinnings of inequities in access and health outcomes. The strategic focus of the Vanderbilt-Meharry BIRCWH is to integrate the study of sex/gender differences and disparities in women's health into thriving research programs across the scientific spectrum, to deepen our understanding of sex/gender biology and actualize personalized prevention, diagnostics, and therapeutics for girls and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The most recent community needs assessment denoted cancer as the most significant health priority in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the second most significant in Queens County. Strategies to decrease cancer burden were identified and included increased outreach and leveraging education and wellness programs to all communities; diverse, underserved, and anyone in our catchment area. With our current system in place Northwell Health NCORP can affect change on health outcomes in the community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma is the leading cause of mortality in the US in people under the age of 45 and is predicted to be one of the top contributors to the burden of global disease in this decade. This project aims to understand the early immune response and identify immune-based markers of severe burn injury, one of the most common traumatic injuries worldwide. We will focus on neutrophils as the most abundant white blood cell and the first responders in the human immune defense system to injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: NARRATIVE At present, diseases of the brain are the leading cause of disabilities and, due to longer lifespans and an increasing elderly population, these diseases are expected to become the dominant cause of death in the next 10-20 years, exceeding cancer and heart diseases. To meet this critical need, we are developing a innovative ultrahigh-performance brain positron emission tomography (PET) detector modules that will overcome current technological shortcomings and will provide advanced tools to accelerate research on fundamental mechanisms of brain maladies, and ultimately provide a valuable clinical diagnostic device. This proposed research is relevant to both public health and the NIH's mission pertaining to the development of fundamental knowledge for improving the diagnosis, staging, and treatment of brain diseases and mental illnesses. 1

PHR: Project Narrative Duke University, a major research university, and North Carolina Central University, a historic black university, both in Durham, NC partner for this career development program in women’s health research. Three selected junior faculty members from these two institutions will receive formal mentoring and training to conduct interdisciplinary research relevant to women’s health across the lifespan emphasizing health disparities and the effects that sex and gender have on health. These well trained scientists will be the future champions for improving women’s health nationwide and globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular function requires the capacity to maintain physiological protein compositions and respond to environmental stimuli. The proposed project will apply large-scale mass spectrometry and proteomics technologies to examine post-transcriptional mechanisms that regulate protein composition and synthesis in mammalian tissues as well as human cell culture models. The results will advance current understanding of how tissues and organisms mount successful responses to oxidative stressors or lose resilience and develop diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Alcohol use typically begins during adolescence and prevalence rates for alcohol use disorder (AUD) peak before age 21. Yet, despite clinical demand, AUD treatments for youth rely on psychosocial interventions that yield only modest benefits at best. This K24 renewal will provide the candidate with protected time to mentor promising early-career scientists in patient-oriented research in alcohol science and conduct an innovative research project focused on leveraging digital health to improve access to evidence-based interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Infections are a major source of morbidity and mortality in hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) patients, as they impair hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) self-renewal and engraftment. Here we will investigate how infectious stress modifies the HSC epigenome to promote myeloid differentiation and hinder engraftment. The overall goal is to define mechanisms of preserving long-term HSC function in the setting of inflammatory stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL Senescence refers to the loss of cell function with aging and is associated with many chronic diseases of aging, but the mechanisms by which this happens is poorly understood at a molecular level. The proposed project seeks to advance knowledge of the molecular features of senescence through cutting-edge profiling techniques and mouse resources that will complement efforts at the human level to map senescence in human cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Urinary tract infections are serious infections that can cause many health complications and death in people with diabetes. Research suggests that cells in the bladder are important for fighting urinary tract infections. By studying how insulin resistance and diabetes impact the antibacterial mechanisms in these bladder cells, we can gain insight into why people with diabetes develop infections and identify new options to treat and prevent them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARATIVE The medical burden of urinary tract infection is significant as they directly contribute to 1% of all clinical visits in the United States and, in postmenopausal women, frequently progress into recurrent urinary tract infection, which has significantly limited treatment options beyond long-term antibiotic therapy. The urinary microbiome and vaginal microbiomes have been shown to be interconnected and vaginal Lactobacillus, which are also observed in the urinary tract and are associated with estrogen hormone therapy in postmenopausal women, have been shown to protect against bacterial vaginosis and are associated with reduced recurrent urinary tract infection. In this proposal we aim to identify alternate therapeutic strategies for recurrent urinary tract infection by elucidating the yet unknown mechanisms of how estrogen hormone therapy enriches the urinary tract with putatively protective Lactobacillus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Congenital heart disease (CHD) remains the most common type of major congenital malformation and the leading cause of mortality from birth defects with up to one third of patients with complex disease developing heart failure (HF) in the second and third decade of life, despite an intervention. Ventricular assist devices (VAD) in patients with CHD and HF remain underutilized, in part due to the highly variable cardiac anatomy and complex physiology. This study will assess if a 3D printed cardiac model improves visualization of VAD and cannula placement sites in CHD-HF patients as compared to 2D imaging alone and if perioperative factors and patient outcomes improve in CHD-HF patients with use of 3D printed model versus traditional imaging in VAD placement planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The dysregulation of post-transcriptional modifications, cellular localizations, and associated proteins lead to disease. However, little is known about how these features control the functions of circular RNAs, a recently discovered group of single-stranded RNAs that lack ends. Our investigations will establish a fundamental understanding of RNA biology and will present potential targets for the development of new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a significant public health problem, and current treatments do not address the impact of stress dysregulation and stress-induced craving and anxiety in AUD. The proposed research will address this problem and evaluate pregnenolone, which is a safe and well tolerated precursor of GABAergic and other neuroactive steroids, in a 12-week randomized controlled trial for improving alcohol use outcomes, other psychological and physical health functioning and patient related outcomes in those with AUD. Positive findings will support the use of pregnenolone to reduce heavy drinking outcomes and improve functioning among individuals with AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinical genetic testing is becoming increasingly common, particularly among patients with cardiovascular disease. Much of our understanding of genetic disorders was obtained prior to the wide use of genetic testing in clinical practice, creating a biased view of the symptoms and outcomes that occur among patients that carry disease-associated mutations. This project seeks to use computational modeling and large electronic health record datasets to learn more detailed information about the consequences of rare mutations in genes linked to congenital disorders with severe cardiovascular symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative Despite the success of cochlear implants, devices surgically placed in the inner ears of patients with severe hearing loss, there remains substantial variability in the overall speech perception outcomes for the children and adults who receive them. The main goals of this project are: i) to improve our understanding of how cochlear implants affect the developing auditory system, ii) apply that knowledge to test new methods for programming children and adults, and iii) to study how long it takes listeners to adapt to new cochlear implant programs over the short- and long-term. The results will improve our understanding of how the deafened auditory system develops with cochlear implant stimulation and advance clinical practice to improve hearing outcomes in cochlear implant listeners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 antiretroviral therapy (ART) has been transformative, but comes with side effects, stigma, and the need for daily self-administration. HIV-1 broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) could replace these therapies, but current approaches for their delivery are inadequate. We propose to convert primay B cells into efficient and adaptive bNAb-delivery vehicles that can control an established HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This project addresses how heme, an essential iron containing nutrient, cofactor, and signaling molecule, serves as an inter-organellar and inter-organ signal that regulates lifespan in cells and animals. PHR: Plugging & Pulling-in: tuning peptides for TolC to overcome antibiotic resistance Narrative Antibiotic resistance is an increasingly dire global health challenge. Antibiotic efflux pumps push antibiotics out of bacterial cells so that antibiotics cannot reach their targets. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Social context and resulting social choices are key features of health whose neural circuitry are not well understood. We will combine systems neuroscience tools with new machine learning approaches to interrogate anterior cingulate projections to the amygdala and nucleus accumbens during a novel rodent social choice paradigm. Given MDMA's impact on social reward, we will also test the impact of MDMA paired social exposure on social choice during our paradigm.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteria communicate using a process called quorum sensing to cooperatively change expression of genes required for pathogenesis, including secretion of toxins and biofilm formation. My lab studies the regulation of quorum sensing genes in marine Vibrio bacteria that are human pathogens. We will determine how quorum sensing signals are integrated together with environmental signals to control gene expression required for pathogenesis and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Building on research regarding the Tripartite Integration Model of Social Influence (TIMSI), Native American culture, and integrative identity, we propose to conduct a longitudinal quasi-experimental study to assess intervention impacts on Native biomedical scholar research career development. Specifically, we propose to use a prospective propensity score matched longitudinal design to compare the short-, medium-, and long-term outcomes of three groups of emerging Native biomedical scholars. This proposed study will advance research in this area by assessing how and when Native scholars integrate into their professional communities and what interventions contribute towards that integration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research aims to discover critical neural correlates resulting from repeated excessive alcohol drinking that may progressively lead to the allostatic state. We focus specifically on neuronal plasticity associated with the development of maladaptive affective behaviors caused by repeated binge drinking. We will determine how dysfunctions in valence coding amygdala neurons and projections from anterior insular cortex to these neurons contribute these behaviors, and we seek to identify circuit-based novel targets for more effective treatment of AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute lung injury (ALI) and its severe form, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), is a common life- threatening disease currently with no effective pharmacological interventions; ALI/ARDS is caused by the over- activation of macrophages and infiltration of neutrophils in the inflammed lungs, and past failures of investigative interventional therapies are in part owing to their inability to resolve the overwhelming acute pulmonary inflammation. Here, we propose to engineer synergistic cytokine-coated macrophage-based immunomodulatory therapy that can efficiently target the injuried lungs, program the pulmonary macrophages and neutrophils toward anti-inflammatory status, and eventually resolve the acute pulmory inflammation. If successful, this study would lay the foundation to develop novel cellualr immunotherapies for targeted immunomodulation in ALI/ARDS which can potentially revolutionize how ALI/ARDS is pharmacologically treated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study focuses on using the ADAPT-ITT framework to adapt material from existing career readiness interventions (Work2Prevent, tailored to young SMM and trans women of color at-risk for HIV infection, and iFOUR, tailored to older people living with HIV, regardless of race) to the needs of young Black SMM (YBSMM), ages 18-29, living with HIV. Given that economic challenges have been demonstrated to limit YBSMM’s engagement in HIV treatment, this intervention has the potential to support HIV-positive YBSMM in improving their economic conditions and associated HIV treatment outcomes. Further, the study uses implementation science methods to understand the context of implementation to prepare for efficient and cost- effective delivery in community-based organizations.

PHR: We propose an industrial-academic collaboration to characterize islet-derived extracellular vesicles in order to improve detection, monitoring, classification, and treatment of type 1 diabetes. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Persons who experience incarceration in the United States are disproportionately impacted by HIV infection and substance use disorders and are at increased risk of having poor health outcomes. The time of release from jails and prisons, known as community re-entry, is a period of particularly high risk and persons with HIV may fail to adhere to their HIV treatment. This study will investigate whether recently approved long-acting injectable HIV treatment, which is given every four weeks, as opposed to oral HIV medications taken daily, has the potential to improve HIV treatment outcomes among persons being released from correctional facilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Head and neck cancers are the sixth leading cause of cancer death worldwide, in part due to major challenges in patient stratification that have prevented the use of novel targeted therapeutics. The proposed work seeks to utilize three-dimensional (3D) culture models of oral cancers, the most common subsite of head and neck cancer, to better understanding of the biology associated with aggressive disease, as well as tumor features that may predict response to both standard and novel targeted treatments. We believe this approach is applicable beyond oral cancers, and the proposed work may support a paradigm shift toward using such 3D culture models to predict patient response to novel targeted therapies, particularly in the recurrent or metastatic setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is a form of breast cancer that does not respond well to standard treatments like chemotherapy and hormone blockers and as a result is more likely to recur. HER2 activating mutations are found in a small percentage of ILC, and this oncogenic mutation can be treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as neratinib. This study will use neratinib in combination with antiestrogens to treat early-stage ILC with the goal of demonstrating the clinical activity of the combination, improving breast conservation, and eventually, increasing the number of patients who have breast cancer cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: A group of bacteria called spirochetes cause syphilis, Lyme disease, leptospirosis, and are associated with periodontal diseases. The motility of these spiral- or flat waved shaped bacteria enable these micro-organisms to invade and damage host organs and tissues. Our long-term goal is to develop novel drugs that specifically target and inhibit this invasiveness for treating spirochetal diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Cortical circuit flexibility is influenced by learning and impacted by repeated stressors. The proposed research will focus on how fear learning and chronic stress modulate cortical activity in local microcircuits and large-scale networks. This work will provide new insights into behaviorally relevant plasticity in visual cortical circuits with implications for basic science as well as stress-related pathophysiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: There are over 150 different epithelia in the body, forming part of organs like the skin, kidney, liver, gastrointestinal tract and structures in the nervous system. Important questions still remain unanswered on how epithelial cells achieve their highly organized architecture, a process known as polarization, which is fundamental to a diverse array of epithelial functions. The objective of this proposal is to bridge this gap in knowledge by uncovering novel intracellular mediators that sort and escort surface proteins on their way to the cell surface and define pathways for epithelial polarization.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Adults with intellectual disability experience significant health disparities. Although they may benefit from precision medicine research advances, they are underrepresented in research and understanding of the legal, ethical, and social consent challenges that present barriers to their inclusion in this research is limited. A stakeholder-engaged approach to studying key issues for engagement of this population in precision medicine research and designing a disability accessible, interactive, and protocol-tailored consent toolkit will respond to: (1) expressed needs of precision medicine researchers for practical tools; (2) scientific interest in engaging adults with intellectual disability in precision medicine research; and (3) the goal of promoting health equity through inclusive precision medicine research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Unhealthy alcohol use adversely impacts HIV care and is associated with multiple physical and mental health comorbidities, and racial and ethnic minorities are disproportionately affected. There is an urgent need to train new scientists in patient-oriented research, address disparities, and implement alcohol interventions in HIV care. This K24 renewal application extends a highly productive and successful research mentoring program to increase opportunities for mentees in these critical areas, and proposes new HIV and alcohol mentoring opportunities for diverse clinicians and junior scientists, especially for those from racial and ethnic minority groups under-represented in medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Gay and bisexual men who have sex with men (GBMSM) in the rural southern United States experience a disproportionate incidence of HIV and STIs. Despite this, HIV and STI testing uptake and pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) initiation remain low among rural GBMSM. We propose a type 2 hybrid effectiveness- intervention randomized controlled trial to test the efficacy of a mobile app, Combine, to increase the uptake of HIV and STI testing and PrEP over a 24-month period among GBMSM in the rural South and to assess the effects of different implementation strategies on intervention maintenance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Our current understanding is that the underlying mechanisms responsible for the efficacy of PARPis is mainly through a synthetic lethal interaction with tumor DNA repair defects (‘BRCAness’). In this application, we aim to investigate the mechanisms and molecular determinants of the therapeutic efficacy of PARPis as immunomodulating agents through the induction of transcriptomic changes, a previously unknown mechanism of action of PARPis. The knowledge gained in this study will have a significant impact in broadening the clinical applications of PARPis in immuno-oncology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary thromboembolism remains a major cause of death and illness in the western world and while treatment leads to resolution in some, many continue to have symptoms and some develop pulmonary hypertension, an elevation of the pressures of the lung circulation leading to heart failure. Computed Tomography (CT imaging is integral to the diagnosis of pulmonary thromboembolism and is routinely obtained as part of its work-up. In this study we propose to use novel quantitative imaging tools to characterize the lung and heart in patients with pulmonary thromboembolism to improve identification of chronicity, prognostication and prediction of response to treatment while at the same time developing a quantitative relationship between structural changes on imaging and functional impairment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This K24 renewal will support ongoing mentorship of early career investigators from Africa and the United States in the conduct of patient-oriented research. The specific research aims leverage all aspects of my NIH- funded research program in Botswana to create new linkages between the Tsepamo Study and Botswana’s national pediatric HIV database; to evaluate a national rollout of long-acting injectable PrEP; to improve decisions related to delivery by cesarian section and train my current mentee in mentoring; and to identify specific children eligible for a safe analytic treatment interruption study, evaluate the acceptability of such an intervention, and support the independence of a senior laboratory-based mentee in Botswana in this field. The ultimate goal of my research and mentoring program is to support the most relevant scientific questions being asked by the next generation of researchers in Botswana.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The overall goal of the Johns Hopkins-Mayo-NIA Murine Senescence Mapping Program (JMN- MSMP) is to create an Atlas of Senescence in mouse tissues that coincide with tissues being explored in the human SenNet. The JMN-MSMP team combines expertise in aging, senescence, immunology, single-cell analysis, data sciences, and innovative computational approaches to achieve this goal. We will define cellular and molecular features of senescence, elucidate the heterogeneity of senescent cells, and characterize their impact on other cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many individuals following a set of rules about how to interact with one another and the environment can give rise to a group entity with new properties in a phenomenon known as emergence. To produce emergent behavior, animals must communicate with multiple other individuals while simultaneously processing sensory cues from the environment and then integrate this information into a cohesive behavioral output. While emergent behaviors have traditionally been challenging to study, my discovery of bidirectional spiraling as a novel emergent behavior in the highly tractable nematode C. elegans presents an opportunity to elucidate the communication mechanisms and neural dynamics underlying a collective behavior with implications for disorders marked by failure to integrate sensory and social cues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Current replacements for tooth enamel for individuals with disease or damage lack the superior materials properties of healthy enamel. Our proposal is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of biomineralization in order to reveal how the primary protein present during enamel formation, amelogenin, directs and controls this process. This understanding can ultimately aid our ability to develop enamel replacements with similar properties to naturally formed, healthy enamel.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As human aging and the resulting age-associated diseases are among the greatest challenges in our healthcare system, there is an urgent need to find interventions that prevent, delay, or even reverse these pathologies. While reducing GH action is highly effective in improving healthspan and lifespan in mice, aging is a complex, multifactorial process that will likely require targeting multiple pathways simultaneously for optimal benefits. Thus, the goal of this proposal is to evaluate gerotherapeutic strategies that combine GHR antagonism with other promising life extending compounds to reduce age-related disease and maximally enhance healthspan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although there are significant sex differences in the expression and onset of major medical and psychiatric disorders, clinical decisions based on research are primarily based on data from men and may often be inappropriate for women. Thus, there remains a strong need for the Harvard BIRCWH program to educate, train, and develop junior investigators who will commit their careers to studying the impact of sex and gender on clinical disorders. Our Harvard BIRCWH program will provide the basis for the development of sex- dependent treatment approaches and public awareness of the importance of these sex-dependent health issues for families and society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nanoparticle translation to the clinic is lacking in large part due to limited accumulation in target disease sites, a particular problem for heterogeneous cancers like ovarian cancer, which can be attributed to the complexity of both the biological environment and the nanoparticle constructs. There is an urgent need to develop tools to deconvolute the individual factors that contribute to nanoparticle accumulation and unlock the unrealized potential of cancer nanomedicine. Therefore, this proposed study seeks to provide a holistic evaluation of nanoparticle structure-function relationships by utilizing a new chemical barcoding strategy to identify materials properties associated with favorable biodistributions and tumor targeting, enable the elucidation of genetic components correlated with nanoparticle interactions, and allow us to leverage the identified genetic signatures for more effective targeted drug delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TET-dioxygenase are the gatekeeper of efficient transcription that regulate cell lineage fate, proliferation and survival. TET2 is one of the major TET-dixygenase that is most frequently mutated in many healthy elderly, wherein its presence put them at significantly higher risk of developing myelodysplastic syndromes and associated disorders. Naturally existing 2HG producing neomorhic mutations in IDH1/2 causes TET-inhibition which in turn leads to the preferential elimination of TET deficient TET2MT hematopoietic clones in human body as observed upon analysis of large cohort of patient data. Hence, establishing TET enzymes as a therapeutic targets. This proposal will enable us to develop small molecule lead compound for early as well as late therapeutic intervention and allow us to gain insights into strategies by which this might be achieved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Botulinum neurotoxins pose a significant threat to the nation as a potential bioterrorism agent. Here we propose to create a novel protein-based delivery platform that can deliver small nanobodies into the cytosol of motor neurons to neutralize botulinum neurotoxins. These studies will not only provide an effective post-exposure treatment for a top-priority toxin, but also establish a modular delivery tool for targeting motor neurons and delivering biologics into the cytosol of neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a rare condition characterized by gradual occlusion of the small pulmonary arterioles leading to progressively increased pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), right heart failure and death. Although causal mechanisms are unclear, our data, for the first time, show evidence of common genetic variation in two novel gene targets associated with the risk of developing PAH in the largest available PAH cohort studied to-date. Our studies will now shed insight into whether these two novel modifier genes contribute to the risk of disease progression and outcomes as well as provide new potential therapeutic targets in PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Dr. James J. Prisciandaro is a licensed Clinical Psychologist, Associate Professor in the Addiction Sciences Division of the Department of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC), who is committed to making a measurable impact on our understanding and ability to treat individuals with bipolar (BD) and/or substance use disorders (SUD) through his program of patient-oriented research (POR). Although he has been successful in designing and executing NIH-funded pharmaco-imaging studies, his efforts to mentor new clinical investigators have been greatly limited by his employment within an academic medical center that does not provide faculty with protected time for mentoring or professional development. The proposed K24 award would provide Dr. Prisciandaro with the protected time and supplementary funding needed to comprehensively train significantly more new clinical investigators and to develop and expand his methodological skills to include genomics research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The central nervous system (CNS) arguably represents the most difficult anatomical tissue location to access and to evaluate for viral infection and persistence. Here we propose to investigate the dynamics of viral reservoir cells in CNS cells from antiretroviral treated HIV-1-infected individuals, using a recently-developed single-cell technology pipeline. These studies may provide insights for targeted HIV cure interventions in people living with HIV-1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is one of the fastest growing causes of cancer-related deaths among Americans, and it disproportionately affects African Americans. Differences in prevalence of established HCC risk factors do not fully explain the high HCC burden in African Americans, and clinical interventions and policies to close these racial gaps have been largely ineffective because fundamental questions about how this disparity arises remain unanswered. Using a genome-wide association study approach, our research aims to identify and validate genetic factors that predispose to the development of HCC in African Americans and contribute to the racial disparities in HCC incidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Knowledge of the factors influencing pathogen spread in vector populations is critical for understanding dynamics of disease incidence, development of risk assessment strategies for novel pathogen introductions and development of transmission biomarkers that can be used to efficiently target control efforts. Since its introduction in 1999, the Category B Priority Pathogen West Nile Virus (WNV) spread completely across the United States with over 50,000 confirmed human cases and over 2,000 deaths. In this proposal, we will delineate the hologenomic (genetics of the mosquito and its associated microorganism) factors underlying WNV infection variation across field populations of Culex tarsalis. These results can be used to develop biomarkers for pathogen transmission in natural mosquito populations that can be used for targeting control efforts, and for use in risk assessment strategies to predict the likelihood of pathogen invasion during natural introductions or bioterrorist attacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Children with congenital heart diseases (CHD) often demonstrate neurodevelopmental deficits – that manifest as difficulties with language, cognitive tasks, and impaired executive function – and the risk factors that may contribute to this poor outcome remains elusive. Based on prior studies, altered CSF volumes and perturbation to CSF circulation may play a role in poor neurodevelopmental outcomes in CHD. This study aims to establish the relationship between abnormalities in CSF, as quantified using multi-modal magnetic resonance imaging techniques and neurodevelopmental deficits in children and adolescents with CHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The brief alcohol intervention (BAI) improves antiretroviral therapy adherence and increases viral suppression among people with HIV (PWH) with unhealthy alcohol use, reducing the possibility that they may transmit the virus. The BAI is ready for scale-up in ART clinics, but its effectiveness may be impaired by the alcohol-related attitudes and behaviors among clinic staff, especially in regions where excessive alcohol use is normative. This trial will identify the best way to scale up the BAI in ART clinics in Vietnam by giving some clinic staff the opportunity to experience the BAI themselves, before they are asked to give the BAI to PWH with unhealthy alcohol use.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal of the African Tuberculosis Bioinformatics Training Program is to strengthen bioinformatics training in Africa for infectious diseases, specifically for tuberculosis (TB), a major public health problem on the continent. The Program will address a dearth of trained bioinformaticians with expertise in TB and other infectious diseases, through a structured Master’s in TB bioinformatics, in which trainees will develop subject-specific expertise, complemented by international research visits, and other networking and capacity development opportunities. Trainees will be embedded within a vibrant network of LMIC and US-based mentors who will provide TB biology, bioinformatics and global health expertise together with individual mentoring to support the development of future leaders in infectious disease bioinformatics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: The skeleton is innervated primarily by NGF (Nerve growth factor)-responsive, TrkA (Tropomyosin receptor kinase A)-expressing sensory nerve fibers. In unpublished work, our laboratory has recently uncovered prominent regulatory roles for these neurons in pathologic bony bar formation after growth plate injury, although the mechanism remains unknown. In the present high risk / high reward proposal, we seek through a combination of approaches to uncover the neuroskeletal regulatory mechanisms which predict this pathologic response to skeletal injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) is a significant problem among immunocompromised individuals and has an attributed mortality rate as high as 90% in certain areas of the world. This proposal seeks to alleviate this issue by assessing the killing efficacy of human stem cell-derived neutrophils (iNeutrophils) against the two most prevalent isolates of IPA, Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus flavus. In doing so, this work will provide needed information on the potential of iNeutrophils as a novel antifungal therapeutic against IPA, while also elucidating mechanisms utilized by these cells to facilitate fungal clearance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Precise regulation of the Wnt signaling pathway is necessary to maintain hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) maintenance and quiescence. After a fracture event, the bone marrow environment, where the HSC niche resides, is then disordered and recruits various inflammatory cytokines as part of the healing process. Injury and age can lead to a dysregulation of Wnt signaling which this proposal hypothesizes alters HSC localization and differentiation, affecting the quality of fracture repair, and thus can be an unexplored target to treat age-related fracture complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Individuals who experience traumatic brain injury (TBI) and repetitive head impacts (RHI) are at increased risk for developing dementia and parkinsonism. This U01 will advance scientific understanding of the specific risks for the development of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related disorders (ADRD), chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), and other pathologies after RHI and TBI, establish the neuropathological features of TBI- related neurodegeneration, and determine the association of post-RHI and TBI neuropathologies with dementia and parkinsonism. This project will lay the foundation for future strategies to intervene, prevent, and treat TBI-related neurodegeneration and CTE.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The overall goal of this project is to elucidate the signaling mechanisms underlying the control of muscle growth. Specifically, we will use a combination of genetic and pharmacological approaches in mice to investigate the function of key components of the signaling pathway utilized by myostatin and related proteins. We believe that these studies will be important for developing the most effective strategies to target this regulatory system for clinical applications to treat patients with muscle and metabolic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: ––– PROJECT NARRATIVE –––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– Substance use disorders are a chronic human condition driven by numerous genetic factors. Many of these have remained opaque, and most human genes that have been linked with substance use phenotypes in genome-wide association studies have not been investigated for their causal roles. The results from this proposal will identify genes that affecting experience dependent amphetamine preference in vivo, thereby illuminating critical mechanisms driving addiction and substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Claes-Jensen Syndrome is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder caused by variants in the X-linked gene KDM5C that encodes a histone modifying enzyme. With the goal of improving the lives of those affected by Claes-Jensen Syndrome, in May 2022, several families came together to form the KDM5C advocacy research education and support (KARES) foundation. This proposal seeks support for the first KARES Foundation family and science conference that will bring together stakeholders in understanding Claes-Jensen Syndrome, including caregivers and affected individuals, researchers, and clinicians.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to use infection of Indian rhesus macaques by glycan-deleted SHIVs to prime, boost and affinity- mature bNAb responses targeting the fusion peptide through a natural process of Env-Ab coevolution. Then, by deciphering molecular pathways of Env-Ab coevolution leading to neutralization breadth, we will develop a “molecular blueprint” for the design of a germline-targeted, lineage-based, all-SOSIP Env trimer immunization scheme to test in rhesus macaques, and if successful, in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Male infertility can result from abnormalities in the structure of proteins (chromatin) that package DNA within the nucleus (epigenetics). Proteins that modify chromatin alter histone-DNA contacts, disrupting DNA structure and gene expression. Genetic experiments that elucidate the specificity of these chromatin-modifying proteins may lead to targeted treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are prevalent, afflicting more than 50 million Americans directly and countless additional family members and caregivers, and devastating. Understanding the relationship between/mechanisms underlying posttraumatic neurodegeneration is critical to diagnosing and treating afflicted patients more effectively. NEW-HOPE-TBI will develop and enhance a world-class brain tissue and open-access digital resource that combines deep clinical phenotyping, advanced neuroimaging, and state-of-the-art multimodal neuropathology from diverse prospective and observational cohorts across the spectrum of TBI-exposed and unexposed AD and ADRD donors to propel impactful posttraumatic AD and ADRD research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Immunotherapy and targeted therapy have arguably been the most important recent advances in treatment for colorectal cancer (CRC), but such advances have not equally benefited all individuals. Our goal is to identify and characterize the underexplored, critically important molecular mechanism of RNA splicing in CRC among patients of different races, ethnicities and ancestries and its influence on outcomes and disparities across these populations. To do this, we will use preclinical CRC models and leverage existing diverse cohorts with biospecimens and annotated data including the Latino Colorectal Cancer Consortium (LC3), the Detroit Research on Cancer Survivors (ROCS), and The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite considerable efforts to reduce oral health disparities, poor oral health continues to disproportionately affect Black and Hispanic children. The proposed research will investigate the influence of race/ethnicity on progression of dental caries and identify modifiable structural risk factors of disparities in quality of dental care to assess the cost-effectiveness and value of dental care, incorporating racial/ethnic disparities in the assessment of value. The results of this project are expected to inform multilevel interventions and support evidence-based policymaking by identifying strategies resulting in high-value care that also address equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The “Building a Cancer Epidemiology Cohort to Investigate Factors Associated with Higher Risk of Colorectal Cancer among Alaska Native People” will establish the first cohort study of risk factors for colorectal cancer (CRC) among Alaska Native (AN) people and establish a rich biorepository for future CRC research. The study will collect dietary and lifestyle, anthropometric, sleep, and physical activity data and biospecimens from 1,000 AN people. Our goal is to establish a comprehensive, community-based cohort to investigate risk factors for CRC among AN people that will be used to inform primary prevention strategies in this high risk population that has the highest documented burden of CRC globally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Despite unsafe firearm storage being the leading cause of firearm-related injury/death among young children (under age 5 years), we lack information regarding how to develop and deliver effective messaging to encourage parents to adopt firearm safety practices in early childhood. This study will employ a mixed methods, community-based, developmentally-informed approach to improve our understanding of the scope of and motivations for gun ownership, storage, and use among parents with young children. Applying decision science and behavioral economics constructs, and in concert with community partners, we will assess parents’ mental models of firearm safety and injury prevention during early childhood and apply the lessons learned to develop a parent-engaged intervention delivered by trusted messengers and precision messaging tailored for firearm injury prevention in early childhood.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-CE-23-005, Firearm safety and injury prevention during early childhood: A parent engagement approach

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Seasonal influenza (flu) infections kill hundreds of thousands of people each year and, while the annual flu vaccine is an important line of defense against this virus, we need to improve the vaccine to make it more effective. Before we can do this, we must first better understand the immune cells that respond to the vaccine. The goal of this proposal is to develop the tools and animal model systems to systematically and comprehensively study the flu-specific memory B cells that are the direct target of flu vaccination in adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor differences between patients can hinder the prediction of therapeutic response in cancer, as patients with seemingly similar tumors often display varying levels of chemo-sensitivity or -resistance. This work aims to abandon the “one-drug-ﬁts-all” approach and produce a novel method for discovering biomarkers of therapeutic sensitivity and resistance in cancer. Our results will assist clinicians in choosing the best available treatment for each individual patient.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative – Project 2 Whitehead Institute at MIT Transcription is a fundamental cellular process whose proper regulation is essential to establishment and maintenance of healthy cell states. Recent discoveries suggest that this process involves dynamic formation and dissolution of biomolecular condensates, and how they are dysregulated in tumor cells. This project aims to provide new insights into dysregulation of transcriptional condensates in multiple myeloma cells, with the goal of enabling development of novel therapeutic molecules with improved efficacy and reduced toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An increased understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying vascular calcification is fundamental in identifying novel therapeutic targets to treat a broad range of cardiovascular diseases. This proposal aims to elucidate the role of novel genes associated with coronary artery and aortic calcification in order to provide mechanistic insights on vascular disease. Defining the molecular underpinnings associated with vascular calcification will have important implications for the prevention and treatment of highly morbid vascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neuroblastoma is a pediatric extra-cranial solid tumor and despite extensive multimodal treatments, most of the high-risk pediatric patients develop progressive disease. Hence, there is critical need to develop novel therapies for neuroblastoma. The goal of this proposal is to study the mechanistic roles of Syk in the regulation of tumor growth and immunosuppression and to evaluate the potential of Syk inhibitors in combination with immunotherapy and radiotherapy for the treatment of high-risk neuroblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) is the most commonly used volumetric image guidance modality in radiation therapy. A major drawback of CBCT is its poor image quality, which prevents its use in treatment monitoring and adaptations to personalize radiation therapy. In this project, we propose a novel solution, two- dimensional antiscatter grid, to improve CBCT image quality to levels that has not been achieved previously. Successful completion of our project can open the path to CBCT-based treatment monitoring and adaptations, and therefore, can enable personalized radiation therapy for large patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bunyaviruses, such as Rift Valley fever (RVFV), Cache Valley (CVV), and Schmallenberg viruses (SBV), cause significant fetal death and abnormalities in ruminants. RVFV infection in humans is associated with late term miscarriage and still births, however it is unclear whether CVV, SBV and a related bunyavirus, La Crosse virus (LACV), can undergo vertical transmission in humans. This proposal will utilize human, sheep, and rat placenta ex plants and human trophoblast organoid models to identify host and virus factors that influence tropism and pathologies associated with congenital bunyavirus infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) results in epithelial injury and an increased risk and severity of lung infections in mammals, yet the mechanisms associated with microbe-microbe, host-microbe, and microbe-diet interactions involved in the observed VAD lung pathology remains unknown. We propose to investigate the role of dietary vitamin A and its derivatives on the microbial composition, biofilm formation, and metabolic changes in differentially expressed microbes in VAD lungs compared to controls. The proposed study aims to identify and characterize novel host-microbe and microbe-microbe interactions critical for lung health that are dysregulated in vitamin A deficient lungs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because dysregulation of cell cycle initiation results in human diseases, such as cancer and degenerative disorders. Outcomes from this research will provide new insights into alternate mechanisms of cell cycle entry that will pinpoint novel targets for therapeutic interventions for cancer and degenerative diseases. Thus, this proposal is relevant to NIGMS’s mission to drive and foster innovative research and strategies to ultimately protect human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with the congenital defect of bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) develop aortic stenosis (AS) earlier and more often than patients with normal tricuspid aortic valves (TAV), which adversely affects BAV patients’ length and quality of life. The goal of this study is to understand changes in biochemical signaling that occur in the major cell type of valves, valve interstitial cells, due to abnormal deformation patterns present in BAVs. Two-photon microscopy of excised valves, proteomics-based steady state biochemical modeling, and 3D biaxial oscillatory stretch screens will be employed to determine the relationships between micromechanical environments and biochemical signaling cascades so that novel pharmacological targets for AS can be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intestinal inflammatory diseases, such as ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease are a substantial public health burden. This proposal will identify the cellular and tissue dynamics underlying homeostasis in the small intestine and colon and how these dynamics are disrupted due to inflammation. Through generation of spatial maps allowing for comparison across many intestinal inflammatory diseases and validation of these high-resolution maps in model systems, this research is designed to inform treatment of these inflammatory diseases, including the development of therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the leading cause of death due to cancer in women and triple negative breast cancer has the worst prognosis of all major types of breast cancer. A patient's own immune system plays an important role in the efficacy of certain cancer treatments, such as immunotherapy. A better understanding of the role of B-cells (a major component of the immune system) in triple negative breast cancer may lay the foundation for improved immunotherapies or prognostic tools.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neural circuits generate sensation, movement and cognition, and aberrant neural circuits are implicated in many neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders. Drosophila is a simple and powerful system to address these questions, with the goal of identifying mechanisms conserved from fly to mammals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The enzyme p97 is an abundant and conserved molecular machine that unfolds proteins prior to their degradation. p97 is regulated by many binding partners through unknown mechanisms. PHR: Project Narrative This study characterizes the tissue response and safety limits of electrical micro-stimulation in multiple non- neuronal brain cells over time. Electrical stimulation is being used to probe brain activity and also treat a wide- range of diseases (e.g. Parkinson’s disease). IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Endogenous thymic regeneration is an important process enabling restoration of immune competence; however, this regenerative capacity diminishes with age such that severe damage (i.e., the pre-conditioning for hematopoietic stem cell transplants) leads to prolonged periods of immunodeficiency that detrimentally impact patient outcomes. In this proposal, we seek to understand how the thymus responds to injurious stimuli and how its endogenous regeneration is regulated. Better understanding these mechanisms may inform therapeutic strategies that boost thymic function after acute or chronic forms of insult, which could benefit patients whose thymus has been decimated due to age, infection, or common cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Paragons of Conformational Control in Metalloenzyme Reactivity Lisa Olshansky Project Narrative. From transport to respiration to biosynthesis, metalloenzyme function relies on the precise interplay between conformational dynamics and active site modulation. However, defining the specific structure-function correlations operative in complex redox machines can be extremely challenging. By creating simplified paragons of conformational control in metalloenzyme reactivity we capture the essence of this interplay, dissecting the energetic costs and consequences associated with regulation of function in the maintenance of human health.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to leverage a novel health records platform to build a comprehensive and transportable cardiovascular risk-prediction model specific to kidney transplant patients. The study will engineer a data visualization tool that allows patients and providers to engage in shared decision-making and identify targets of clinical and structural intervention. The results will be critical for informing individualized risk management of cardiovascular disease, improving long-term outcomes, and reducing health disparities with implications for dissemination across multiple institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative In the United States, chronic liver diseases rank 11th and 5th cause for deaths in all ages and in age 44~65- year group, respectively (National Vital Statistics Report 2019), yet up to 30% of patients with chronic liver diseases have no clear etiology. With the identification of a candidate virus in our preliminary studies, the current application aims to characterize this novel human virus and its link with liver disease. The etiological understanding is central to the prevention and management of life-threatening liver diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: In the pathogenesis of diabetic retinopathy, retinal mitochondria are damaged and the electron transport chain system is compromised, fueling into a vicious cycle of free radicals. Diabetes also alters expression of many long noncoding RNAs (LncRNA), and these RNAs with > 200 nucleotides lack an open reading frame for translation. Mitochondrial DNA encodes three LncRNAs, but their role in regulating mitochondrial homeostasis in diabetic retinopathy is not clear. This proposal is focused on understanding the role of mtDNA-encoded LncRNA Cytochrome B, important in the functioning of complex III, in maintaining mitochondrial homeostasis in diabetic retinopathy. These studies carry a significant translational impact as they are expected to identify novel therapeutic targets to prevent the development and progression of diabetic retinopathy, offering patients additional means to prevent/halt this sight-threatening complication of diabetes.

ORG_NAME: CENTER FOR CONSTRUCTION RES AND TRAINING
PHR: Project Narrative The relevance of this proposal, which is national in scope, is to prevent work-related fatalities, injuries and illnesses by training construction workers on DOE sites how best to protect themselves, their workplaces and their communities from exposure to radiation and other hazardous materials encountered during hazardous waste operations, facility decommissioning, decontamination and demolition, hazardous materials transportation, environmental restoration of contaminated facilities or chemical emergency response. A well trained construction workforce enables DOE, its contractors and subcontractors, and other stakeholders, such as trade unions and Native American tribes, protect not only the workers themselves but communities surrounding DOE sites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ribonucleotides are the most common lesion in the genome and have been linked to human disease. The goal of this project is to determine the structural and biological effects of ribonucleotides on telomere integrity, as well as characterizing the repair of ribonucleotides at telomeres. This project will provide technical and professional training by using a unique combination of biophysical, structural, and cellular assays to address the project goal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our project is to use genotype and phenotype data from a variety of sources, to generate polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for individuals belonging to diverse ancestries. Our focus will be on developing PRSs for coronary heart disease (CHD) and its major risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, obesity, hypercholesterolemia), collectively an enormous public health burden world-wide. We will develop methods to account for diverse genetic ancestry in models of polygenic risk and integrate PRSs into existing clinical risk prediction equations to estimate absolute risk of CHD for use in clinical decision making.
