IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reproductive health is dependent upon the formation of spermatogonial stem cells (SSCs) from its precursor cells, male germ cells (MGCs), and mechanisms governing this vital period of development are largely unknown. The primary aim of this study is to elucidate how an RNA binding protein (RBP), DND1, can post-transcriptionally regulate its target transcripts, thereby ensuring MGC-to-SSC development. Results obtained from this study can provide insight into why post-transcriptional regulation by RBPs play a critical role in MGC development across species and contribute to reproductive health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding communication between the lung and brain is critical in order to understand how respiratory viral infections ultimately impact the central nervous system. This proposal examines lung-brain communication in the onset of influenza A in a mouse model, testing the hypothesis that the lung and brain exert bidirectional influence to influence altering each organ’s immune state. In Aim 1 the role of pulmonary neuroendocrine cells in infection onset is studied by ablating these cells prior to infection, and in Aim 2 the role of neuronal activity in infection onset is studied by chemogenetic reactivation of relevant neuronal populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys. The mechanism underlying ADPKD is obscure with two major theories, haploinsufficiency (where a simple decrease in protein level is enough to cause disease) and the `two hit' hypotheses (where an individual is born with a defective gene then acquires another mutation on the normal gene causing the disease). This application will use NanoView technology to measure the level of polycystin-1 on exosomes to distinguish these two ideas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE_Overall Infection with HIV-1, the virus that causes AIDS, is a significant public health problem world-wide. An improved understanding of the specific functional and qualitative features of how the human immune system fights HIV-1 infection and how these features contribute to protection against infection is needed. This Program focuses on the role of what is known as the “Fc receptor” of antibodies and their interactions and cooperation with a variety of immune cells. This work will reveal how to maximize the body’s immune response against HIV-1 to yield more effective prevention, vaccine, and cure approaches, with potential for significant benefits to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this study is to reduce the burden of cancer for the minority population in our catchment area. We will contribute in the scientific design of cancer clinical trials at the national level and locally will use outreach to educate our population about clinical research specifically in cancer control, prevention, care delivery, and novel therapies to improve the health of the community. By facilitating the enrollment and participation of minority and underserved cancer patients into clinical trials, we will achieve our ultimate goal of improving survival and quality of life of all individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Viewing the same scene or object can drive different responses in visual cortex depending on whether the observer is stationary or moving, engaged or passive. Enabling this context-dependent processing is thought to be a key function of the neuromodulator acetylcholine, and deficits of acetylcholine are associated with disorders ranging from Alzheimer's Disease to schizophrenia; however, the mechanisms through which acetylcholine modulates the cortex are incompletely understood, hampering the development of treatments. This proposal dissects the action of acetylcholine on specific cell types in the visual cortex, clarifying how this neuromodulator impacts components of the cortical circuity to drive context-specific processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The knowledge gathered from this project is of significant public health relevance as it has potential to facilitate more rapid and timely detection and treatment of first episode psychosis (FEP) by evaluating the utility of systematic screening and communication strategies for psychotic symptoms. Current methods for identifying and treating FEP in the US are associated with long average duration of untreated psychosis (DUP), typically over one year, with longer DUP associated with greater symptomatic and psychosocial impairment, and reduced responsiveness to established treatments. Reducing the DUP could alleviate patients’ and their families’ suffering, reduce psychiatric disability, and decrease economic losses to the society, including both treatment costs and loss of productivity associated with disability.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adverse infant and maternal outcomes during the perinatal period continue to have deleterious effects throughout the life course. Neighborhood deprivation and discrimination contribute to these adverse outcomes and their related disparities, but the role of social support as a potential buffer against these effects is poorly understood. Our findings could assist in better identifying vulnerable pregnant women most likely to benefit from additional social support resources, without sacrificing the long-term goal of creating structural and societal changes that reduce neighborhood deprivation and discrimination.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder is one of the most perplexing neurodevelopmental conditions facing modern medicine today, with lifelong implication for affected families and society at large. This project will use an innovative smartphone app to collect information about infant social development during the first two years of life and compare this to genetic prediction markers, with the aim of better understanding how genetic factors and social experience contribute to the overall likelihood of autism. This will help to overcome a critical barrier to progress in the field by identifying potentially modifiable early risk factors amenable to intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE As shown by BRCA mutations, DNA damage causes cancer, is used to treat cancer, and acts in side effects to cancer treatment. Yet, DNA damage effects depend upon poorly understood BRCA DNA repair complexes (DRC) that are also a target for advanced treatments. To advance cancer medicine, our MANTIS-DRC project will provide foundational structural and mechanistic knowledge on BRCA repair complexes and their connections to cancer biology and therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke is the leading cause of disability in the United States, leaving a substantial number of survivors with permanent weakness. Neuromodulation of sensorimotor areas using physiologically targeted low- frequency stimulation is an innovative new direction to facilitate recovery of motor function. Our proposal seeks to optimize stimulation parameters to selectively target nodes in the motornetwork.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Transplant Research and Education Center (TREC) at Houston Methodist Research Institute (HMRI) and J.C. Walter Jr. Transplant Center Houston Methodist Hospital (HMH) and Kaiser Permanente Southern California (KPSC) will partner to improve CKD care and transplant rates for patients in the KPSC health system through system changes, inclusion of a peer mentoring program, and dissemination of an innovative technology-supported (mHealth) application to engage patients, family members, and potential living donors in pursuing transplant, including learning how to find living donors. The investigators will conduct a stepped- wedge cluster randomized controlled trial of the multilevel intervention in 12 KPSC medical centers and examine its effects on referral for transplant (primary outcome) and secondary outcomes including engagement in transplant education, level of patient knowledge, clinician and health system adherence to best practice recommendations, transplant wait-listing, and increased LDKT rates. After examining factors that moderate the intervention’s effectiveness across settings and underserved subgroups, they will develop implementation resources to facilitate intervention spread within commercial, academic, and safety net healthcare systems across the U.S.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Multilevel Intervention Strategies to Transform Kidney Care and Improve Pursuit of Transplant in an Integrated Healthcare Delivery System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative During chronic allergic airway inflammation, rare chemosensory cells called tuft cells produce prostaglandin E2 (PGE2), which I hypothesize modifies mucus movement and airway inflammation, contributing to diseases such as asthma and nasal polyps. My proposal will use mouse modeling and cell culture to understand how tuft cell-derived PGE2 orchestrates immune and epithelial functions in the airway during allergic inflammation, and then investigate whether the same processes contribute to asthma in humans. These studies will advance fundamental knowledge of airway biology and may identify new therapeutic targets to treat millions of patients suffering with chronic allergic airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Social determinants of health increase the morbidity of atrial fibrillation. This study will examine how individual- and neighborhood-level social factors relate to access to anticoagulation – an essential medication for individuals with atrial fibrillation – and its adherence. The project will support robust mentoring in patient- oriented, health services research for junior clinical investigators focusing on social determinants and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary graft dysfunction (PGD) is severe lung injury that occurs after lung transplantation and predicts poor clinical outcomes. We propose that elevated levels of cell-free hemoglobin (CFH) in the bloodstream and in the airspace cause PGD through injury to the lung endothelial and epithelial barrier, and that CFH accumulation and oxidation is promoted by common clinical practices used to care for lung transplant patients. In this application, we will establish a three-center study to determine how CFH causes PGD and how clinical management alters accumulation and oxidation of CFH, laying the groundwork for clinical trials targeting CFH to reduce risk of PGD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (NPC) is a common form of head and neck cancer that is driven by Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) and especially prevalent in South East Asia at a rate of 15-50 cases per 100,000 people per year. In this project, we will study two NPC cohorts, a 51-participant new-diagnosis cohort and a 50-participant longitudinally sampled Phase II clinical trial cohort treated with the combination of anti-PD-1+anti-CTLA-4 (Ipilimumab+Nivolimumab) checkpoint blockade immunotherapy (cICI). With the goal better understanding the role of peripheral EBV-specific and other NPC-associated T cell responses in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) immunopathology, we will use a variety of single analysis methods applied to blood and tumor tissue to test the hypotheses that EBV-specific T cells contribute to tumor control elicited by cICI and that the phenotypic and clonal characteristics/dynamics of peripheral EBV-specific T cells can be useful as indicators of clinical outcomes for NPC patients.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel non-pharmacologic pain management approach of excruciating pain, as in pediatric burn dressing changes, is relevant to public health to prevent negative impacts on the delivery of optimal clinical care and the child’s post-injury recovery processes. The proposed randomized clinical trial of a smartphone VR for pain management during repeated at-home burn dressing changes addresses the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services priority to “advance better practices and cutting-edge research in pain management” and the AHRQ mission to “produce evidence to make health care safer, higher quality, more accessible, equitable, and affordable”.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A Randomized Clinical Trial of Smartphone Virtual Reality for Pain Management During Burn Care Transition

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The goals of the Pregnant Female Reproductive Tissue Mapping Center are to develop three-dimensional multiscale maps of the placenta, pregnant uterine endomyometrium and fallopian tubes, to explore signaling between the placenta and maternal tissues, and to trace the trajectories of cellular differentiation and migration in the placenta across gestation. To do this, we will apply a range of imaging and molecular profiling modalities, including in vivo MRI and ultrasound imaging, and ex vivo extracellular matrix proteomics, formal histopathologic evaluation, imaging mass cytometry, single-nucleus multiomics, spatial transcriptomics and deep morphologic and hyperplex spatial immunoprofiling. The resulting data will be analyzed and distributed to the broader research community in collaboration with the HuBMAP Integration, Visualization, and Engagement (HIVE) Collaboratory. This project is relevant to public health because the resulting 3D multiscale maps of normal pregnant female reproductive tissues will serve as key frames of reference for future studies aiming to discover how perturbation of tissue structure and/or function leads to organ dysfunction in common, yet poorly understood, pregnancy complications, such as preeclampsia and preterm labor.

PHR: Project narrative Early-life risk factors have been implicated in inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) but are not well-understood. There is increasing evidence of intestinal inflammation and loss of gut microbiome diversity preceding IBD. We aim to develop risk prediction models for IBD based on early-life risk factors and apply them toward prediction of intestinal inflammation and loss of microbiome diversity in order to better understand IBD pathogenesis, identify at-risk persons, and guide therapeutic and preventive efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Colon cancer that is associated with a positive family history or early age of onset, and polyposis, the presence of multiple precancerous polyps in the colon, are two common indications for genetic testing for cancer risk assessment. We often cannot interpret DNA changes seen on testing; the goal of the proposed Polyposis /Colon Cancer Variant Curation Expert Panel (VCEP) is to create and maintain a panel of clinicians and scientists with broad expertise in all aspects of colon cancer and polyposis hereditary syndromes. The VCEP will analyze evidence on genetic in genes associated with Polyposis and Hereditary Colorectal Cancer, set rules for classifying the variants as disease-causing (pathogenic) or benign, and classify large numbers of variants that have been found through clinical genetic testing.

PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric Pulmonary Medicine is one of the smallest pediatric subspecialties. Very few pediatric pulmonologists have had adequate training and mentorship in research, and thus lack the skills to perform cutting-edge research in pediatric pulmonary diseases. This training grant will continue to educate a new generation of pediatric pulmonologists and Ph.D. scientists, who can play a role as leaders and researchers in pediatric pulmonary medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a new application for an NCI-supported cancer control training in disparities and equity in South Florida (South Florida C-TIDE). This multidisciplinary program proposes to train postdoctoral fellows in multilevel determinants (e.g., biological, medical, social, psychosocial, health systems) of cancer risk, etiology, progression, cancer prevention and care delivery, health-related quality of life, and other patient-reported outcomes. The primary goal of the program is to train the next generation of researchers with an exceptional training platform that supports postdoctoral fellows across the cancer control continuum as they develop independent, successful, high-impact research targeting cancer disparities and health equity.

PHR: Building on a half-century of innovation in transvascular access and ultrasound image guidance, LXS has developed a novel catheter device and venous access procedure to cannulate and aspirate the thoracic duct under ultrasound guidance. The company is applying for a Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) award to complete development, prepare and submit for FDA clearance, ramp manufacturing, and create sales and marketing strategies in anticipation of commercial use. Completion of this CRP program will place the company in a position to launch sales with an FDA cleared device as a direct competitor to plasmapheresis and the only transvascular access device for lymphocyte collection and depletion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Statement p53 is a foundational mutation in many cancers, with mutations found in >90% of ovarian cancer and >70% of endometrial cancer. However, p53 has proven to be a challenging target in the therapeutic arena. This project will define the deleterious actions of common mutations in p53 and develop novel synthetic RNA-based therapeutics to perturb each mutant's aberrant activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aphasia, a language disorder commonly caused by stroke, affects more than 2 million Americans and interferes with everyday communication, disrupts participation in work and preferred activities, and significantly reduces health-related quality of life. The proposed conference grant will support a set of cutting-edge presentations to help professionals improve the study and treatment of aphasia, with a focus on health disparities. The grant will also support student training in aphasia research and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The complex consortia of bacteria and other microbes carried by all eukaryotic organisms, collectively referred to as the microbiota, has been shown to have critical roles in many aspects of human health and disease including inflammatory bowel disease and cancer. An evolving literature has recently shown that these findings extend to the central nervous system, and disruptions in the microbiota have been shown to alter fundamental processes including fear extinction, experience-dependent synaptic plasticity, and microglial maturation. This research proposal will identify how the microbiota regulate neuron-microglia interactions including synaptic engulfment, and the microbiota-to-brain signals that do so, with the long-term goal of advancing new treatments for dysbiosis-induced cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While females and males have many similarities, both sexes have unique biology with clear differences in disease prevalence, therapeutic needs, and responses. Females, in particular, have not received adequate attention in human health and disease research. We seek to better understand how structural variants and individual RNA isoforms affect disease by helping to characterize them and their roles in human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Nuclear RNA export, an essential process required to use information stored within DNA, is disrupted in multiple diseases and is targeted by viruses to benefit viral replication and survival. The proposed research is focused on understanding the mechanistic basis of RNA export via nuclear pore complexes. This will provide fundamental knowledge necessary for understanding disease, which is core to the mission of NIH and NIGMS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying biomarkers for response to treatment in Diffuse Large B cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is important for public health because there is a strong need to improve patient outcomes through targeted treatment strategies. BCL10 is recurrently mutated in DLBCL and upregulates oncogenic signaling pathways, conferring resistance to key therapies. Elucidating the mechanism of BCL10 mutations in lymphomagenesis and their impact on response to treatment is relevant to the NCI’s mission because it may reveal novel molecular mechanisms and inform therapeutic approaches and clinical decision-making in particular subtypes of DLBCL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia, causing a neurodegenerative cascade from neuronal synapse loss to eventual memory loss, yet there is currently no effective preventative treatment. This proposal will investigate mechanisms underlying prodromal AD cellular dysfunction, and whether restoration of function can prevent further pathology. Ultimately, this proposal aims to create an easily translatable disease therapy to intervene at an early phase in the progression of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dr. Markland is a midcareer physician scientist in the field of geriatrics who has established a federally funded lower urinary tract symptoms/incontinence research program and a record of accomplishment for mentoring early-stage clinical investigators. This midcareer mentoring award will enable Dr. Markland to develop and refine her mentoring skills, continue providing patient-oriented research mentoring to early-stage trainees, and expand her research program in new directions by supporting new patient-oriented research. The proposed projects will build upon an existing mobile health technology platform designed to deliver behaviorally based treatments for lower urinary tract symptoms/incontinence and improve our understanding of factors that impact response to treatments. Mentoring provided should advance the research careers of many early-stage investigators while also improving response to treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will apply a novel dual-layer x-ray detector for calcium scoring to enable early detection and intervention of cardiovascular disease, especially when patients are asymptomatic. Our technology, which innovatively combines material engineering to tune electro-optical properties of chalcogenide alloys, detector structure design, and artificial intelligence-guided image processing, brings much-needed quantitative capabilities to x-ray imaging. This approach will allow accurate quantification of coronary artery calcium from chest x-rays and will have immense impact on proactive healthcare, improving the clinical outcomes of patients, and reducing the number of deaths associated with cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although it is clear that placental damage and dysfunction underlie poor birth outcomes associated with maternal malaria infection, the cellular and molecular mechanisms that underlie this damage remain very poorly understood. Exploration of these mechanisms, in particular the role of innate immune cell-driven oxidative stress in mediating placental cell stress and death in malaria, could contribute to the development of improved interventions that would reduce poor birth outcomes in malaria and other pregnancy complications that share these pathogenic features.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immersed in the two worlds of clinical practice and research, physician-scientists trained in the fields of health policy, economics and social and behavioral sciences have unique perspectives that are key to effectively addressing the healthcare demands of America’s aging population. Harvard University, home to a long established, nationally recognized MD-PhD program as well as world-renowned graduate programs in Health Policy, Economics, and Social and Behavioral Sciences, is exceptionally well poised to train physician-scientists in these areas. With an existing track record of distinguished alumni and a growing cohort of current trainees, made possible by this NIA institutional training grant, we re-submit this competing renewal so that we may continue to build on these accomplishments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative: Endometrial cancer (EC) is the sixth leading cause of cancer death among women in the USA and EC is estimated to increase by 1–2% yearly. The obesity epidemic is implicated in the increase of EC cases in the USA. Advanced-stage EC have limited treatment options with poor prognosis and a clear need exists for the identification of actionable drivers as new targets for treating EC. This proposal is clinically significant, as it will establish the significance of LIF/LIFR signaling in EC progression and test the utility of LIFR inhibitor EC359 as a monotherapy or as a combination therapy for treating EC.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE Care transitions are a vulnerable period for patients, leading to post-discharge adverse events, falls, medication errors, and readmissions. Specific challenges such as poor communication among inpatient providers, patients, and the primary care team, poor quality and timeliness of discharge documentation, and suboptimal patient understanding of care plans can be improved with our proposed Care Transitions App. In a cluster randomized control trial, we will evaluate the App’s efficacy in engagement of patients and families in their health care and the App’s role in the reduction in adverse events post-discharge.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Care Transitions App for Patients with Multiple Chronic Conditions

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To date, most genetic risk factors for complex traits are located outside of known genes. This proposal focuses on developing rigorous strategies for identifying the actual causal variants underlying complex traits using novel and powerful methods. Employing these strategies will lead to a more profound understanding of the genetic mechanisms that drive disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus is a formidable bacterial pathogen capable of causing a diverse array on infections. One of the most devastating of these is osteomyelitis. The ability of S. aureus to cause these infections is dependent on having its virulence factors available in the right amount at the right time. Regulatory control at the level of the production of these virulence factors is important, but it is not the whole story. The hypothesis behind this application is that an equally important part of this story is the ability of control the production of specific extracellular proteases that modulate the turnover and accumulation of S. aureus virulence factors, and that the staphylococcal accessory regulator (sarA) plays the defining role in this regard. Identifying the most relevant proteases, and defining the manner by which they impact the S. aureus virulence factor repertoire to impact virulence and the host response in bone infection are the overall goals of this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Over half of today’s children are projected to have obesity as adults, putting them at risk of an array of chronic diseases including type 2 diabetes and suggesting the critical need to intervene to prevent obesity and improve nutrition early in childhood. While the Child and Adult Care Food Program is a federal policy mechanism that influences the meals served to millions of young children in the U.S. through child care settings, problems with implementation are weakening the program’s potential to have a substantial impact on child health. The proposed study will use implementation science and economic methodologies to explore determinants of successful CACFP adoption in child care settings and develop an implementation intervention strategy to support child care providers in adopting CACFP so that this federal program can improve young children’s diet quality and reduce food insecurity, thus putting children on a healthier developmental trajectory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE We have completed several studies of choline supplementation in children with neurodevelopmental abnormalities resulting from prenatal alcohol exposure (PAE): a feasibility study, a pilot efficacy study, and a long-term follow-up study. The proposed study will continue that work, helping to determine whether choline supplementation during a specific developmental window when the child’s brain remains plastic is able to attenuate the deficits in thinking, memory, processing speed, and behavior that are common in children with PAE and whether these changes are long-lasting. We will also use MRI to measure changes in the trajectory of structures known to be involved in these cognitive functions as well as to examine the development of connectivity in response to choline or placebo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure is a common, costly, and morbid condition affecting over 6 million US adults. A number of medications help improve quality of life and lifespan for these patients; yet, only a small percentage of patients are taking these medications at the correct doses. This project will benefit the public health by describing the reasons why patients do not receive these medications and testing a computer-based intervention to help clinicians prescribe these medications to their patients in a pilot study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Hox genes are important regulators of axial patterning and disruption of their function or regulation in mammals can result in transformations of vertebral identity, as well as limb and genital malformations. Our proposed studies utilize exciting new insights into Hox genes in cephalopods to elucidate the basic rules governing the regulation and function of this developmental gene family. Through its focus on a critical transcription factor family regulating axial identity, our project will contribute to our fundamental knowledge of how embryonic patterning is established and will provide insight into the biology of this transcription factor family that plays key roles in human development and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sulfur mustard (SM), a vesicant and warfare agent, was recently used by terrorists in Syria. No specific therapy for SM-induced ocular toxicity exists currently. Recently, we developed a novel multimodal non-steroidal topical ophthalmic solution, Turbo Eye Drop (TED), and found it highly potent in counteracting SM-induced blindness and ocular damage in rabbits in vivo. This project establishes the most effective treatment regimen, safety, and mode of action of TED, and leads bench-to-bedside translational development of first potent and safe antidote against SM-induced blindness and ocular injury in vivo.

PHR: This predoctoral training program seeks to prepare the next generation of biomedical researchers with the knowledge, methodologic, analytic and leadership skills to become successful future HIV research investigators. To do this, the program proposes to undertake a two-year program of research training that includes a dual mentored research project, education in specific skillsets, research career development and exposure to the needs of communities at risk so that graduates are prepared to lead future independent HIV/AIDS research programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The need for cardiovascular disease training programs focused on clinical and population research is more compelling than ever. This training program, now in its 14th year, is specifically designed for clinical investigators seeking to apply state-of-the-art clinical and population research methods to important cardiovascular research questions. Such clinical investigators are urgently needed to address important aspects of our nation’s cardiovascular research agenda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Across cultures, protein-rich foods are widely considered beneficial to postpartum mothers by supplying energy and cellular building materials; however, it remains unknown whether and how dietary amino acids can directly trigger neuromodulatory signaling to facilitate the restorative effects of protein-rich diets. Using Drosophila as a model, this project identifies a neuromodulatory mechanism by which ingested amino acids stimulate the release of a gut-derived peptide hormone to heighten sensitivity to external social cues and restore critical innate behavior. The mechanistic insights expected from this research will shed light on how macronutrients impinge on particular internal physiological states to influence neuronal function and behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative. This project is relevant to public health because it represents a novel, targeted harm reduction approach to the treatment of Cannabis Use Disorder, a major public health concern in the era of increasing cannabis legalization. This study aims to evaluate the effect of a one-session computerized distress tolerance intervention with just-in-time text message support on distress tolerance, stress-related cannabis use motivation, disordered cannabis use, and psychosocial functioning, representing a highly portable, low-cost solution to the problem of Cannabis Use Disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Impact of Medically Tailored Meals on Obesity, Other Health Outcomes, and Healthcare Utilization under Medicaid Flexible Services Project Narrative  This collaboration will evaluate, in the largest study of its kind to date, the impact of medically tailored meals (MTMs) on (a) obesity, diabetes control, and blood pressure, (b) healthcare utilization and healthcare costs, and (c) food security and nutrition security. This research will develop important, timely, high-impact evidence on the potential effectiveness of this innovative intervention to improve health outcomes and reduce utilization in Medicaid patients with medical and social challenges. The results will help scientists, healthcare systems, payers, and policy makers understand the impact of MTMs on obesity, diabetes, and other clinically and policy-relevant outcomes in low-income Americans; compile evidence on the largest MTM intervention in the US to inform future healthcare delivery; and highlight innovations to improve nutrition security and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), driven by tobacco and alcohol use as well as HPV infection, is the sixth most common cancer worldwide. This debilitating disease presents a significant health care challenge as cases are rapidly rising in the United States and around the world. The proposed studies will decipher the mechanisms driving immune suppression in HNSCC and will develop new therapeutic approaches that can offer new promise for the successful treatment of this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Failure to resolve inflammatory processes elicits chronic inflammation and disease, which in turn leads to impaired barrier immunity and protection against infections. Bystander activated T cells contribute to pathogen clearance, but have also been identified as critical contributors to perpetuating tissue damage in inflamed tissues. The overall goal of this proposal is to elucidate the mechanisms that negatively regulate bystander activation to determine how tissue homeostasis and barrier immunity can be restored.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deciphering the effect of mutations on the function of normal cellular enzymes is imperative for a better understanding of how cancer and other diseases occur. KRAS, a small enzyme that breaks down the nucleotide guanosine-5'-triphosphatate to guanosine diphosphate, is altered in nearly a third of patients with cancer. The proposed work will identify proteins that physiologically inactivate mutant KRAS and provide fundamental new insight for cancer biology and therapy.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The impacts of unmet social needs, such as homelessness, inconsistent access to food, and exposure to violence on health are well-established, especially for cardiovascular disease. A limited but growing body of evidence suggests that screening for and addressing these needs – also referred as social determinants of health -- in clinic settings helps to connect patients to resources to address unmet needs and has the potential to improve health outcomes. Veterans carry a high burden of unmet needs. At present, VA systematically screens for only two unmet needs; homelessness and food insecurity. We propose to assess the efficacy of systematically screening Veterans for eight unmet needs (i.e., housing, food insecurity, utility insecurity, transportation, legal problems, employment, safety, and social isolation), and compare the effect of referral mechanisms of varying intensity on Veterans’ connection to resources, reduction of unmet needs, treatment adherence, reduced preventable hospitalizations, and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a medication that can greatly reduce the risk of acquiring HIV infection; however, PrEP’s effectiveness is reduced by poor adherence. We developed a mobile game that improved adherence to PrEP. In this proposed project, we will further test the game with a larger number of people, and the individual, organizational and structural factors associated with the implementation of the gaming app will be collected through in-depth interviews with patients, staff, and clinic administrators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The pipeline of new antimalarial drugs is promising but the specter of drug resistance is always looming. Hence, we are proposing to develop novel chemotypes against PfATP4 a proven drug target. In this study, we will carry out lead optimization studies for two series of molecules developed in our laboratory and test them in an in vivo model of P. falciparum infection and assess resistance development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The endogenous APOBEC3 enzymes are proposed to cause a large number of mutations found in many different cancer types. Using newly discovered human cancer cell line models, we will determine the causes and consequences of APOBEC3 mutagenesis in cancer with the goals of determining if APOBEC3- mutagenesis represents a disease modifying process that can be therapeutically exploited at different stages of cancer evolution and identifying specific enzymes as putative targets for therapeutic pursuit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall The overall goal of the Skin Biology Resource-Based Center (SBDRC) at Mount Sinai is to accelerate research in skin biology and diseases and promote its translation to benefit human health. To achieve this, we will harness the technical innovations, high-end infrastructure and computing power available at Mount Sinai to specifically advance and innovate skin research by lowering cost barriers for skin researchers to access advanced technologies; embedding gene editing, genomics and bioinformatics experts in skin research labs to break down interdisciplinary communication barriers; and providing in person and virtual venues to facilitate collaboration and exchange of ideas. In parallel we will ensure a vibrant future for skin biology and diseases research by aiding entry of outside investigators through training and financial support; promoting development of junior investigators and physician-scientists; and enhancing the diversity of our research community through targeted recruitment and mentoring of minority scientists and by growing the pipeline of young minority students entering the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and other viral pandemics, including COVID-19, present substantial challenges to public health. The field needs new, talented investigators who can bring innovative solutions to address these continuing crises, a need that will be directly addressed by renewal of our highly successful, postdoctoral training program. The program now incorporates SARS-CoV-2 research, improves trainee productivity, and enhances recruitment of women and underrepresented minorities, with the objective of advancing early-stage investigators to independence so that they can address the continuing challenges of the HIV and other pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This is a comprehensive, prospective, cross-sectional study of brain structure and function in Myotonic Dystrophy type 2 (DM2). MRI measures of white matter integrity are expected to be identified as disease- specific and clinically relevant to clinical (cognitive and motor) endpoints and biofluid markers of brain pathology. This work is critical to inform the development of rigorous central nervous system (CNS) trial designs and plan for a longitudinal study to evaluate MRI measures of white matter integrity as imaging biomarkers for CNS disease progression and therapeutic response in DM2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Image-guided minimally invasive interventions, including targeted biopsy and focal ablation, promise to be safe and effective strategies for the diagnosis and treatment of abdominal cancers, but currently face critical limitations due to inadequate image guidance and procedural accuracy provided by existing technologies. This work will overcome these challenges by creating a new real-time magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) guided robotic system based on synergistic innovations in real-time MRI and computer-aided guidance methods, MRI-compatible robotics, feedback control methods, and interactive user interfaces. The new system will be evaluated in programmable dynamic tissue phantoms and in vivo pig liver models to demonstrate its safety, accuracy, and efficiency for needle placement in moving targets, which will establish the foundation for a new generation of minimally invasive interventions to improve the management of abdominal cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The proposed study, led by a collaborative group of researchers from Kenya and the United States is among the first to test the effectiveness of a mental health intervention for multiple common mental health conditions (depressive, anxiety and trauma symptoms) among adolescents and youth with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa. The study will also evaluate key factors for successful intervention implementation and conduct an economic evaluation to inform future intervention scale-up. Addressing mental health among adolescents and youth living with HIV, who are at highest risk of poor HIV outcomes is key to their overall health and survival, and population-level HIV prevention efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants have a remarkable ability to successfully acquire language after experiencing early left hemisphere injuries like perinatal stroke and early-onset epilepsy, but how white matter tracts connecting cortical language areas mature in response to these injuries remains unclear. This proposal aims to study white matter connectivity in the language network of typically developing infants who are acquiring language, and in patients with histories of early-onset epilepsy and perinatal stroke. Investigating how connectivity arises in the language network in response to the acquisition of language in typical and clinical populations will provide insight into the fundamental mechanisms of cognitive and brain development and guide future intervention strategies in stroke and epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The current study aims to develop and pilot a behavioral parenting just in time adaptive intervention (JITAI) for children with ADHD and academic difficulties utilizing an existing mHealth application. This study holds substantial public health benefit as it will examine the effectiveness of a low-cost, high reach intervention for ADHD—a highly prevalent and costly mental health disorder. The present study will inform the approach used in a subsequent clinical trial and has the potential to reduce child mental health burden.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parents can help protect their adolescent children from experiencing adolescent relationship abuse (ARA), especially through parental monitoring. Hispanic immigrant parents may face challenges monitoring their adolescent children due to differences in how parents and adolescents acculturate, also called acculturation gaps. In this proposal, we apply observation-based techniques to identify which specific acculturation gaps create the most challenges to achieving optimal parental monitoring, and then incorporate those findings to develop a novel parent-adolescent ARA prevention intervention for Hispanic immigrant families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive fibro-inflammatory disorder of the exocrine pancreas that can lead to diabetes and pancreatic cancer. There are no available treatments for this fibro-inflammatory disease and patients suffer with unremitting abdominal pain as the disease progress. This pilot study will test the feasibility of conducting a clinical trial of a potent vitamin D analogue, paricalcitol, to enhance the quality of life and delay disease progression in chronic pancreatitis patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is a chronic infection and airway inflammatory disease with systemic manifestations affecting multiple aspects of our patients' lives. This disease requires lifelong management, as recurrence is common, however our current microbiologic outcome measure is often difficult to obtain and is insufficient to reflect the impact on our patients. In order to facilitate development of a future combined disease activity measure, we aim to identify the core outcome domains and measurement instruments essential to evaluate in future clinical research studies assessing outcomes in patients with pulmonary MAC disease through an international consensus process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Across the biomedical sciences — from developmental biology to cancer research to immunology to epidemiology — there has been an increased recognition that many key questions in these fields can be addressed by tracking the evolution of lineages. My group has a very strong track record of making fundamental methodological contributions that have changed how biologists think about and analyze phylogenetically structured data and finding applications for these methods in new domains. Moving forward, our group’s primary aim is leveraging phylogenetic and other evolutionary approaches to gain insights into the processes that govern the evolution of gene expression, with a particular emphasis on the Immunoglobulin genes, which encode the unique recognition sequences of antibodies.

PROJECT_TITLE: Leveraging phylogenetic approaches to investigate the evolution of gene expression

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual (i.e., MSM) and gender (i.e., trans women) minority populations with a substance use disorder (SUD) have the two highest HIV prevalence rates in the US, which constitutes a call for action to determine scalable behavioral interventions to promote PrEP initiation, adherence and persistence. This study will implement a RCT with a Stepped Care design to determine the optimal (considering effectiveness and cost-effectiveness) intervention for advancement along the PrEP Care Continuum. The public health significance of this study is very high as the application of PrEP among SGM populations with a SUD would generate significant and lasting reductions in HIV incidence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative The aggregation of the huntingtin protein plays an important role in Huntington’s disease, but the exact structures of the toxic species that are formed remain elusive. Using a highly interdisciplinary team, the structures of these species will be determined, thereby providing a foundation for the design of therapeutics. Moreover, means to prevent the formation of the toxic species will be developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The circadian clock helps to align metabolic and physiological processes with changes in the environment - dysfunction in these rhythms contributes to increased risk for cardiometabolic and neurodegenerative disorders. This proposal will use a model system to resolve how circadian regulation of gene expression at the cell level is coordinated across tissues to control a physiological response. This will be achieved by building cell specific models of circadian function to characterize how cellular variation in gene expression influences complex traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the last several decades, state laws governing sales and possession of cannabis products have changed dramatically with minimal scientific evidence available to inform policymakers. Medicaid-enrolled adolescents and young adults have higher prevalence rates of mental health and substance use disorders and poorer physical and mental health outcomes compared to age matched peers; thus they are a large vulnerable population in whom the MML and RML effects are unknown. We will analyze national Medicaid data to determine MML and RML effects on cannabis use disorder, serious mental illness, non-cannabis substance use disorder, suicide-related outcomes, all-cause mortality, and treatment utilization for SU and MH service in American youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioids are potent pain relievers, however they can be addictive and their overuse has produced the opioid overdose epidemic, with hundreds of thousands of deaths. We now report that changes in behavior and in the brain correlated with addiction can be prevented, while analgesia is maintained, when a dual hypocretin/orexin receptor antagonist is given along with morphine. We propose to systematically document the receptor specificity, dose-response, time course and neuronal substrates of this interaction as a first step towards the use of an Hcrt antagonist in combination with opioids as a highly effective, non- addictive pain treatment in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Acute leukemias are the most common form of cancer in children. Many types of acute leukemia are known to initiate in utero, but a comprehensive natural history and epidemiologic study of in utero leukemogenesis is lacking. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many patients with chronic kidney disease develop heart failure, but the underlying causes remain unclear. Animal models of human disease suggest that the inflammasome may contribute to the development of heart failure in patients with chronic kidney disease. An epidemiologic study and a clinical trial will be conducted to improve our understanding of the role of inflammasome activity in the development of heart failure among adults with chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because metastasis remains the major cause of mortality for breast cancer patients, understanding the mechanisms underpinning its progression is crucial for developing drugs that target this deadly process. My research proposal will expand our fundamental knowledge of tumor metastasis by investigating how blood platelets promote the formation of tumor cell-permissive sites, commonly referred to as the “pre-metastatic niche”. The overarching goal is to develop platelet-targeting adjuvant and preventative therapeutic strategies that improve the outcomes of patients at risk of metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative NF-κB plays a causative role in the pathogenesis of various diseases such as lung cancer, the leading cause of cancer-related deaths in both men and women. However, we have been unable to successfully target it for clinical treatment due to its equally important roles in physiology and host defense in particular. The proposed investigations will dissect the differential regulation and action of NF-κB in lung cancer and physiologic host defense against pulmonary infection. These studies may lead to new clinically feasible approaches to selectively target pathogenic NF-κB for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 350,000 anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction surgeries are performed in the US each year [1], and billions are spent on the acute care costs involved in these procedures. STEL Technologies has developed the first fully biologic graft for ACL repair and demonstrated superiority to the standard of care in clinically relevant, large animal model of ACL injury. The CGEM graft is an innovative and paradigm-shifting approach to ligament replacement that facilitates native repair of the ACL and regeneration of enthesis, leading to restoration of normal biomechanics and mobility. We have spent 9 years developing the technology and are now prepared to launch a first-in-human clinical trial to demonstrate improved knee stability and function, and the possibility of a radical improvement in outcomes for patients who suffer acute knee injury including decreased risk of re-injury and arthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bereaved persons are approximately three times more likely than non-bereaved persons to die by suicide. The loss of a spouse during late life is also associated with a felt sense of social disconnection, lack of engagement in pleasant activities, and disruptions in daily routines. The objective of this R01 application is to examine risk and resilience to late-life suicide following spousal bereavement by investigating the extent to which social connectedness influences suicide risk and whether circadian rhythm instability (i.e., inconsistent patterns of social activity, sleep, and meals) helps explain this association. The proposed study uses longitudinal observation and behavioral probe methods to determine whether directly targeting social disconnectedness decreases suicide risk among older bereaved spouses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The melanocortin system represents a fundamental component of metabolic, body weight and glucose regulation, but it is unclear which endogenous melanocortin peptides are required for normal metabolic responses. We will use our newly developed mouse models targeting α-MSH to test whether deletion of α- MSH impairs adaptive response to surviving metabolic challenges and to determine the specific neurons or organs that are responsible for α-MSH actions on metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with hearing loss experience extra effort when listening, which can lead to severe psychological barriers to communication and social participation. Listening effort can lead to fatigue, mental strain, burnout, medical sick leave, and the need for increased time to recover from regular daily activities. This proposal aims to understand effort changes on a moment-to-moment basis during listening, how long the effort lasts, and how the planning and execution of effort is impacted by the experience of using a cochlear implant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Vitiligo affects 0.5% to 4% of the population worldwide and response to phototherapy is often partial. This proposal aims to elucidate why within a single vitiligo lesion there are areas that respond and others that do not. The results will provide new insights on treatment responses to nbUVB and help us understand whether targeting the local environment is sufficient to promote repigmentaiton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral replication requires the formation of infectious particle through the bottom-up self-assembly of each individual virion. Cellular mechanisms are commonly used to guide the process toward the correctly assembled structure. This project aims to exploit this inherent vulnerability in the viral life cycle, and will yield innovative therapeutic strategies to drive the formation of aberrant viral structures using peptides that mimic native initiators of self-assembly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease poses a large public health challenge not only for the nearly 6 million Americans affected but also for their families, caregivers, and communities. To enable better disease detection, this proposal aims to develop a reliable, multimodal, and multiclass classifier for Alzheimer’s prediction of clinical diagnosis and biomarker status. In the long term, achieving the proposed aims will establish a framework for earlier detection of disease risk, improve stratification of patients for more effective clinical trials, and expand our ability to differentially diagnose Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT RELEVANCE Reproductive science and medicine encompasses the study of endocrinology, gonad development, gametogenesis and embryogenesis, and reproductive tract biology and research in this area has implications for fertility, contraception, pregnancy, fetal origins of adult disease, transgenerational epigenetic inheritance, aging, cancers, infectious diseases, and more. This application will fund the Upper Midwest Summit for Reproductive Science (UMSRS), which will coalesce reproductive science and medicine research across 16 institutions in five states in the Upper Midwest region (Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, and Wisconsin). UMSRS will showcase cutting-edge research in our discipline and unify regional institutions to expand collaborative networks while providing trainees with valuable professional development and leadership opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our project is to combine validated polygenic risk scores (PRS) with conventional risk factors and family history to calculate comprehensive risk profiles for 15 common diseases that pose a significant public health burden. We will return risk estimates to 2500 participants (35% non-whites, 200 adolescents) and those at the highest polygenic risk will see a health care provider to discuss risk reduction measures. We will assess clinical, cost/utilization and psychosocial outcomes following return of results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Nemours NCORP will provide the leadership and clinical trial infrastructure to support five geographically distinct community-based pediatric oncology programs in enrollment of children on cancer care, prevention, care delivery, therapeutic and biology trials. Childhood cancer is an ultra-rare disease, and the Nemours NCORP is among the leaders in clinical trial enrollment. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Baptist Memorial Health Care/Mid-South Minority Underserved NCORP is located in the Delta Regional Authority’s catchment area, serving the most indigent population in the US. We have successfully brought clinical trials access to this heavily underserved population, with 39% of our enrolled patients being racial minorities and 17% residing in rural areas, and 34% under-insured. We now seek to expand the reach of our NCORP to cover all of the state of Mississippi, Eastern Arkansas and West Tennessee, thereby providing greater access to the large indigent, racial minority and rural populations within the Mississippi Delta region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The heterogeneity of alcohol use disorder (AUD) may contribute to the limited effectiveness of treatments. Here, I explore AUD biotypes (subtypes determined by biology) derived from MRI data and characterize the behavioral, genetic, and molecular correlates of these biotypes across the lifespan, as well as their correlates with alcohol involvement trajectories. Parsing and characterizing the biological heterogeneity of AUD may lead to improved personalized treatment options for patients through drug repositioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The International Association of Fire Fighters (IAFF) has been a partner with the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Worker Training Program (WTP) since 1995, delivering training to workers on or around the DOE nuclear weapons complex (over 12,451 students trained through delivery of over 586 of classes during that time) to prevent work related harm and improve worker health and safety. The built environment in and around DOE facilities has become more complex due to increased population growth and impingement into the wildland urban interface, and workers face a number of emerging issues including occupational cancer risks, stressors impacting behavioral health and wellness, and an emphasis on improving provider and community resiliency. The IAFF is committed to addressing these issues, by: continuing and improving the training and education of all potential responders (public, private, or volunteer) required to manage HazMat emergencies; utilizing innovative technologies for class delivery; and conducting ongoing quality control and program evaluation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative    The interior of a human cell is organized through a series of chemically and morphologically distinct membrane-  enclosed compartments, the organelles. The proposed research aims to address how these compartments are  structured, and how they interact. Understanding the basic mechanisms that govern intracellular organization is  critical to our understanding of tissue cell function and lays the foundation to address disease phenotypes that  coincide with a loss of organization, such as in neurodegeneration and carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Significance This timely, culturally-tailored intervention study has the potential to markedly improve the standards of overdose and HIV/HCV prevention among at-risk veterans. Peer-led interventions for substance use disorders have proven effective at reaching stigmatized, at-risk populations, and this intervention contributes to the evidence base for remediating the health impacts of opioid use by advancing a tripartite (education, navigation, and support) protocol to reduce risks. The products of this pragmatic trial will be of great interest to the wide range of community-based and civic healthcare organizations committed to reducing opioid-related harms while fostering social and healthcare engagement among veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PPG NARRATIVE The inhibitory receptors PD1 and LAG3 synergize to limit autoimmune disease. However, they are also over- expressed in cancer and chronic viral infections, preventing disease clearance. Although PD1 and LAG3 are now major therapeutic targets, it is not clear how they mediate this synergistic regulation and on which cells types. A greater understanding of these issues could lead to more effective therapeutic strategies.

PHR: CORE NARRATIVE The inhibitory receptors PD1 and LAG3 synergize to limit autoimmune disease. However, they are also over  expressed in cancer and chronic viral infections, preventing disease clearance. Although PD1 and LAG3 are  now major therapeutic targets, it is not clear how they mediated this synergistic regulation and on which cells  types. A greater understanding of these issues could lead to move effective therapeutic strategies. Core A will  provide administrative and statistical support to all projects and cores and is essential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: CORE NARRATIVE Chronic infections with viruses such as HIV, HCV and HBV affect half a billion people and are significant  causes of morbidity and mortality. T cell dysfunction or “exhaustion” is a major immunological defect during  these infections and can be modeled with LCMV infection in mice. The studies proposed will define the role of  the inhibitory receptors PD-1 and LAG-3 in CD8+ and CD4+ T cell exhaustion and provide new insights into  how to reverse and avoid T cell exhaustion and improve immunity during these and other chronic infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inhibitory receptors PD1 and LAG3 synergize to limit autoimmune disease. However, they are highly  expressed on intratumoral T cells and thus limit effective anti-tumor immunity. Although PD1 and LAG3 are now  major therapeutic targets, it is not clear how they mediated this synergistic regulation and on which cells types.  A greater understanding of these issues could lead to move effective therapeutic strategies and biomarker  discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes mellitus (DM) occurs in about 1 in every 4 persons after an episode of acute pancreatitis (AP) making this an important health problem, but the mechanisms underlying DM after AP remain unknown. We will enroll adults with AP into a multicenter longitudinal observational study supported by the Type 1 Diabetes in Acute Pancreatitis Consortium and define mechanisms of DM by: (1) measuring insulin secretion and insulin sensitivity after AP; and (2) determining relative contribution of autoimmunity (type 1 DM) by assessing beta cell autoantibodies and T cell reactivity to beta cell antigens in study participants.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Macular Degeneration is a disease that forces individuals to rely on the low resolution of peripheral vision to perform everyday visual tasks. Understanding how the brain’s visual system adapts to using peripheral vision could potentially aid in the development of behavioral interventions for this debilitating form of visual impairment. Using modern techniques in human neuroimaging, the proposed study will investigate how changes in the structure (neurite density and cortical thickness) and function (functional connectivity) of visual cortex enable adaptation to central vision loss.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Ovulation is a critical aspect of female fertility and is controlled by an interplay between neurons within the brain, including those that produce the hormone gonadotropin- releasing hormone (GnRH), and the ovarian hormone estradiol. We are studying this interaction in normal females and how it is disrupted by factors that influence fertility, such as stress. This information can be used to help treat couples facing infertility.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Premature infants are vulnerable to undernutrition, which negatively impacts brain growth and development with the potential to permanently impair long-term neurodevelopment. This project seeks to clarify the impact that variability in the intake of a specific micronutrient, zinc, during the neonatal period has on growth, concurrent brain development, and later neurodevelopmental outcomes. The long-term goal of this research is to determine optimal zinc intake among preterm infants and identify nutritional intervention strategies to ensure all infants receive adequate zinc intake to support growth and maximize long-term health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative For the millions of bilingual parents around the world, and in the US specifically, one of the most pressing questions in the face of the Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) diagnosis is how to reconcile it with bilingualism. Yet, little is known about early language development in bilingual toddlers with ASD, and how to best support it. This project examines the development of Spanish and English in young Hispanic and Latine children with ASD, promising to yield immediately practical information to parents, caregivers, and service-providers about how to support dual-language development in this under-represented and under-served population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The LIUNA Training and Education Fund (LIUNA Training) DOE Worker Training Program provides the education, training and certification needed to build a qualified, safe and efficient workforce that can support current and future nuclear industry needs, including construction, decommissioning, operation, radiation protection, disaster response and waste management jobs. In partnership with its national network of training centers, LIUNA Training provides workers and staff with the knowledge and skill needed to protect themselves, their co-workers, the community, and the environment when working on nuclear energy projects. This is critical to safeguard the health and safety of workers and the public, to maintain the necessary supply of skilled and competent workers and to preserve the integrity of our environmental resources.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic young adults are known to experience social challenges related to dating and sexual relationships that contribute to a significantly increased risk of depression, anxiety, and sexual victimization compared to non- autistic people, and suicide is a leading cause of premature death among autistic adults. Existing sexual education programs for autistic young adults often encourage them to “camouflage” autistic traits by adopting non-autistic social behaviors that are uncomfortable for them, which ultimately exacerbates risks for poor mental health outcomes. In this participatory action project, we will work with autistic self-advocates to identify what specific social challenges autistic young adults face, determine which of those challenges are most problematic for them, and develop a novel dating and sexual education program that teaches autistic young adults skills to navigate social challenges using social strategies that align with their autistic identities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The development of a noninvasive, nontoxic nanotechnology for early treatment of AD will provide a major new neuroregenerative tool, which would be able to protect brain structures and restore brain functions in AD more effectively than existing treatment methods, while using lower therapeutic drug doses, and causing fewer side effects. This new nanotechnology will serve as a new neurotrophic/ neuroprotective drug-delivery system that can target relevant brain systems and may also have utility as an imaging agent to enhance diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early life sleep disruption has been associated with changes in prefrontal cortical development and social behavior later in life, in both individuals with autism spectrum disorder and in a unique wild rodent model of social affiliation/attachment, the prairie vole. Here we propose to both map the trajectory of behavioral changes from life to adulthood in this model and to measure medial prefrontal electrophysiologic correlates of changes in affiliation/attachment behavior. We also propose to reverse this early life-induced autism-like behavior using optogenetics with the goal of elucidating both mechanistic and therapeutic targets

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE By promoting multidisciplinary team science, fully engaging institutional and community stakeholders in the design and implementation of health research, accounting for adverse aspects of the “sociome” – that is, the social, environmental, behavioral, and psychological factors through which structural racism impairs health – and developing innovative and sometimes disruptive approaches to advance the science and practice of clinical and translational research, we expect to mitigate disease risk, morbidity and mortality, improve the conduct and pace of health research, and ultimately improve the health – and health equity – of Chicago and the nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV and TB remain high among the top ten causes of death in low-income countries. Given the budgetary constraints to conduct the array of ongoing and potential clinical trials, we have developed a Value of Information (VOI) framework to assess a priori which trials might provide the best value, formally comparing courses of action with and without new information – as might be obtained from a trial – to quantify the value of information acquisition, accounting for both the trial benefits and costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Oral candidiasis, also known as oral thrush, is an AIDS-defining fungal infection of the oral mucosa that afflicts individuals on chemotherapy, transplant patients taking immunosuppressive drugs, asthma patients using inhaled corticosteroid drugs or others with compromised immune function such as infants and the elderly. The objective of this project is to understand interactions between Candida albicans and the host immune system, with a focus on cells of the oral epithelium. The long-term goal of this research is to develop better therapies or vaccines for mucosal disease of the oral cavity, and to understand the consequences of therapies that suppress specific immune events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The innate immune sensor NLRP3 responds to environmental and infectious triggers, and can promote acute and chronic inflammatory disease, causing organ dysfunction. NLRP3 activation in myeloid cells is important in many diseases but the roles of specific myeloid cell types remains unclear. This study investigates a dominant role of neutrophils and their precursors in NLRP3-dependent autoinflammation in mouse and human cells.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: The strategy to prevent acute kidney injury (AKI) and its progression relies on clinical interventions provided as a care-bundle to minimize injury to the kidneys. This care-bundle, however, lacks the ability to personalize care for patients. This project will use novel machine learning methods to determine a personalized strategy for prevention of persistent AKI after cardiac surgery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and lethal type of primary brain tumor that is highly resistant to current treatments, indicating that development of new effective therapeutic approaches is urgently needed. Because both glioma stem cells (GSCs) and the tumor-promoting macrophages (pTAMs, M2) promotes malignant growth and therapeutic resistance, synergistically targeting GSCs and reprograming pTAMs into tumor-suppressive macrophages (sTAMs, M1) may significantly improve GBM treatment. In this proposal, we will assess whether redirecting pTAMs into sTAMs through BACE1 inhibition by MK-8931 in combination with targeting GSCs through BMX inhibition by ibrutinib can serve as a novel strategy to significantly improve GBM treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is common and deadly, and no specific medicines treat ARDS. The Meyer research program aims to overcome this lack of therapy by leveraging a robust human molecular cohort study of sepsis, the most common cause of ARDS, and applying genomic tools with deep immune phenotyping to uncover specific patterns of response that may respond to unique treatments. Our goals are to explain individualized ARDS risk, highlight specific patterns of immune response, and test how patterns change over time and with treatment.
