IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Women living with HIV are at increased risk for preterm birth and have altered vaginal bacterial communities. Here we will test the hypothesis that HIV infection leads to an expanded vaginal virome, which either directly or indirectly (through alteration of the bacterial microbiota) is associated with a higher preterm birth risk. Understanding the interplay between HIV, antiretrovirals, vaginal viruses, bacteria and risk of preterm birth is relevant for developing novel diagnostics and interventions for improving birth outcomes among pregnant women living with HIV, and ultimately to decrease infant morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most prevalent autoimmune disease, which affects ~1% of our population, and is largely manifested by episodic flares of joint inflammation, pain and tissue destruction. Based on our findings in mice, and RA patients, we discovered that arthritic flare can be caused by the loss of lymphatic drainage from the affected joint, and that known drugs that can increase lymphatic drainage may be affective therapies to treat RA flair. Here we propose to test this theory in mouse models and RA patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The DNA in our cells is continually at risk of damage that can adversely affect health and disease. The overall goal of this project is to investigate how the Bloom (BLM) DNA helicase prevents damage caused by the presence of difficult-to-replicate repetitive DNA sequences. We will use the model organism Drosophila melanogaster, the fruit fly, and genetic and molecular biology tools to better understand how a lack of BLM protein in human patients leads to the developmental abnormalities, premature aging, and cancer susceptibility seen in Bloom Syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: 8. Project Narrative: Mutations in the mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) are observed in many cancers, but the role of these mutations in shaping cellular metabolism and tumor growth is incompletely understood. Here, we study a disease outlier, Hürthle cell thyroid carcinoma (HTC), in which mtDNA mutations are highly enriched to study the cause and consequences of electron transport chain (ETC) dysfunction in cancer. These findings will be extended to other forms of thyroid and kidney cancer that harbor mtDNA mutations and be of immediate and direct relevance to patients with HTC and have broad implications across cancer types by providing new insights into ETC function in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching goal of this study is to determine whether effective treatment of hypertension impacts brain blood flow, amyloid, and tau, hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), in older adults who are at high risk of dementia. Furthermore, we will determine the impact of hypertension treatment on brain white mater integrity and neural network connectivity and their relationship to brain amyloid and tau deposition. The new knowledge obtained is potentially important for development of multidomain strategies for dementia prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Ketogenic diet is popular for weight management and may help treat neurological disorders, but it may also cause severe bone loss that increases fracture risk. This project contributes to public health by characterizing the effect of ketogenic diet on bone strength throughout adulthood, if KD prevents exercise from increasing bone strength, and investigating if ketone bodies are a primary mechanism driving bone loss. In the long term, the findings can improve understanding of how ketogenic diet contributes to fracture risk and the development of therapies to prevent bone loss on a ketogenic diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores the important question of how oral and gut microbes interact during HIV infection, and how these interactions may alter the immune environment in the mouth leading to inflammation and susceptibility to oral sexually transmitted infections (STIs). We will use longitudinal oral and gut microbiome profiling plus saliva antibody measures to investigate mechanisms leading to inflammation in HIV, and apply machine learning to identify microbiome signatures of STI risk. Results from this study could aid in developing novel strategies and saliva-based monitoring tools to better treat HIV and reduce comorbidities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. As the proportion of the American population over the age of 65 increases, there will be an increase in the number of individuals afflicted with Alzheimer’s disease with neither a complete understanding of the pathophysiology of this illness nor effective, disease-altering therapies. Metabolic dysfunction is a hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease and the master regulator of metabolic homeostasis, adenosine monophosphate activated protein kinase (AMPK), may play a critical pathophysiologic role in this disease. This proposal seeks to measure AMPK in vulnerable regions of postmortem AD brain and manipulate AMPK in neurons derived from AD patient iPSCs, ultimately providing novel pathophysiologic insights and advancing the opportunity to develop new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Simple mastectomy amputates all of the breast tissue, including the third through sixth intercostal nerves, leaving the breast numb. The resulting deafferentation leads to major adverse effects, including a disembodiment of the breasts, loss of touch-based affective communication, abolition of breast-centered erogenous touch, and, in many women, the development of chronic pain. Our objective is to lay the groundwork for a neuroprosthetic solution to the negative sensory sequelae of mastectomy by establishing that touch sensation can be restored to the breast via bionics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive procedures to open arteries supplying the legs for patients with pain and peripheral artery disease (PAD) include risks of complications and uncertainty around individual benefits. Aligning goals and values between patients with PAD and available treatment options requires better evidence of patient-centered outcomes and a deeper understanding of the decision-making process. The proposed work leverages complementary methods in advanced statistics and decision science to address these gaps, enabling clinicians and patients to make more informed, personalized, and goal-concordant decisions about PAD care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HCC represents a growing healthcare burden with very limited therapeutic options and poor survival rate. We have discovered a new role of the cytokine IL27 in HCC development, allowing us to put forward an exciting hypothesis that IL27 suppresses both innate and adaptive anti-cancer immunity and may represent a potential target for pharmacological interventions. In this proposal, we will elucidate cellular and molecular mechanisms by which IL27 mediates its tumorigenic effects on innate and adaptive immune cells in HCC and test how its blockade may be used to reinvigorate anti-HCC immune responses. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kawasaki Disease (KD) is an increasingly recognized, potentially fatal illness of young childhood that is the most common cause of acquired heart disease in children in the developed world. The most likely cause is an infection in genetically susceptible children, but the etiology has eluded 50 years of study, hampering the development of a diagnostic test and specific therapies. We have found that children with KD make antibodies against a specific protein. In this proposal we will identify more proteins that children with KD make antibodies against, determine whether these proteins are all present in one causative agent of KD or in multiple different causes, and develop assays for specific antibody responses to KD. These studies could have a major impact on the field of pediatrics by enabling improved diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of KD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While emerging evidence suggests the heterogeneous nature of cell populations and time-varying signal transduction are essential to determine cellular responses to stimuli, most studies rely on conventional one-time measurements of bulk cells. We will rigorously investigate cellular heterogeneity, dynamics, and inheritability in migration with the help of high-throughput microfluidic single-cell tracking and selective retrieval, focusing on the CXCL12-CXCR4/ACKR3 axis as a model. The technology and paradigm we establish will be widely applied to elucidate cellular heterogeneity and dynamics in other contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Metaplastic breast cancer (MpBC) is an exceedingly rare and highly lethal subtype of breast cancer, and the main therapeutic option for metastatic MpBC remains systemic chemotherapy, despite known resistance to most chemotherapy drugs. Given the current lack of any effective treatment regimens, we propose a multi-center clinical trial to test the efficacy of a targeted approach combining inhibition of two major pathways implicated in MpBC, namely the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K/AKT) and nitric oxide synthase (NOS) pathways. Our proposal will further investigate the mechanism of this treatment, identify biomarkers of resistance, and assess interactions between various cells in the tumor and its environment using specimens derived from the MpBC patients in the trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease of the optic nerve that is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide and will affect 76 million people by the year 2020. Lowering intraocular pressure is the only available strategy to slow the progression of glaucomatous vision loss, but is not always successful in preventing blindness. This proposal will address the role of optic nerve head astrocyte reactivity in glaucomatous axon loss, as well as astrocyte modulation as a novel strategy for axon protection, with the ultimate goal of bringing to light new therapeutic targets to reduce the burden of glaucomatous vision loss worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a major public health problem that is strongly influenced by cigarette smoking and genetic predisposition. The primary objectives of this proposal are to identify new protein biomarkers for COPD by studying large numbers of lung tissue samples, to determine the genetic determinants of these protein biomarker levels, and to integrate protein biomarkers, genetic variants, gene expression levels, and epigenetic marks to identify biological networks related to COPD pathogenesis. Identification and investigation of novel protein biomarkers may lead to new insights into the biological mechanisms causing COPD, suggest new pathways for treatment, and provide tools to select subjects for future clinical trials of COPD medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the overwhelming burden of HIV among Black men who have sex with men (BMSM) in Southern Ending the HIV Epidemic in the U.S. (EHE) jurisdictions, there is a need for innovative, culturally-relevant, and accessible interventions to promote their HIV-related health. The present hybrid type 2 implementation- effectiveness trial will evaluate THRIVE365, a multicomponent HIV intervention designed by BMSM for BMSM living with HIV in the Southern U.S. and facing intersectional stigma and multilevel barriers to HIV care. We will examine the daily and longer-term HIV-related behavioral and psychological health impacts, stigma moderating effects, and the maintenance and reach of THRIVE365 through a 6-month trial with 350 BMSM living with HIV in four Atlanta-area EHE jurisdictions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Respiratory syncytial virus is very common, but for some children born with special health care needs, including congenital heart disease, chronic lung disease of prematurity, and prematurity, infection can lead to significant and costly morbidity and mortality. While a preventive treatment is available to these high-risk infants, approximately two-thirds do not receive it. This research will provide new understanding about factors associated with receiving this preventive treatment and the ethical trade-offs that must be considered in the development of preventive policy, and ultimately will use a mixed methods approach to converge the quantitative and qualitative findings to prioritize barriers and facilitators to implementation of respiratory syncytial virus prevention policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Women who identify as bisexual, lesbian, or queer have lower rates of breast and cervical cancer screening, but no large-scale data is available to understand the implications of these differences on cancer burden. In this project, we will better characterize breast and cervical cancer screening disparities by sexual identity and simulate the expected burden of cancer given current knowledge on risk behaviors and screening patterns. This research will provide much needed estimates of stage-specific cancer incidence and mortality, as well as provide actionable insights on upstream determinants affecting cancer screening use and breast and cervical cancer risk among sexual minority women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HPV infection has been identified as a definite human carcinogen for oropharyngeal cancer, and people with HIV have a much higher rate of oral HPV infection and oropharyngeal cancer than the general population. The proposed research will examine the associations among oral microbiome, periodontal diseases, and oral HPV infection, as well as the immunological underpinnings of oral HPV infection for people with HIV. The findings may indicate new biomarkers and novel therapeutic targets for preventing and managing oral HPV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance use disorders are difficult to treat because they hijack many of the neural mechanisms used in natural reward processing. I propose using recently developed state-of-the-art techniques for recording and analyzing the interactions of large populations of neurons to better understand the computational code behind population neural activity. These finer precision tools will allow us to identify better targets for therapeutic intervention in treating substance use disorders that leave natural reward-seeking behaviors intact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Progress in treatment of impaired muscle function is limited in part by relatively poor understanding of the principles that govern the development of these specialized cells. One unique and dramatic feature of skeletal muscle cell development is the energetically expensive, long range movements of nuclei that establish myodomains with individual nuclei regulating each. The proposed research will identify the mechanisms that drive nuclear movement, the mechanisms that maintain nuclear spacing during muscle growth, and connect these mechanisms to muscle disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health Tumor-infiltrating regulatory T cells (Tregs) suppress effective immunity against breast tumors. We propose to develop a novel morpholino-based drug to direct FOXP3S isoform expression in Tregs and test its efficacy in breast cancer immunotherapy. This research will integrate Treg functions into precision medicine to fuel exciting translational development in breast cancer immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy induced colon toxicity is a significant clinical problem for cancer patients. Current management of ICI-induced colitis (ICI-colitis) is empirically adopted from the management of autoimmune colitis/inflammatory bowel diseases, which has significantly interfered with the course of ICI-therapy. This proposed study aims to define new management strategies of ICI-colitis based on scientific rationales through a perpetual dialog between information derived from clinical sample and novel pre-clinical ICI-colitis animal models. We hope the outcome will help to improve the benefit of ICI therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Childhood hearing loss disproportionately affects low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where up to 75% of cases are preventable due to the high prevalence of infection-related hearing loss. School hearing screening is critical for identification of childhood hearing loss in low resource settings, but most screening programs cannot identify middle ear disease that is widespread in populations with a high prevalence of infection-related hearing loss. This study will develop and validate an mHealth tympanometer with machine learning diagnostic support to transform this technology into a low-cost tool that could be broadly disseminated in LMICs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: AIDS patients lose important T cell populations during the course of disease, making them susceptible to disease from herpesviruses that are normally latent within the patient. This proposal focuses on understanding immune surveillance against gammaherpesviruses, which can give rise to severe disease in AIDS patients. We will uncover the mechanisms responsible for maintaining long-term immune surveillance that may lead to better ways to restore T cell immunity to AIDS patients, thereby preventing gammaherpesvirus-associated disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The prevalence of cigarette smoking among HIV-infected individuals is 2 to 3 times greater than in the general population, and smoking has deleterious effects on the long-term survival of these individuals. Chronic cigarette smoking and HIV infection may lead to additive or synergistic effects on the brain and cognitive deficits. The proposed research will develop a new magnetic resonance spectroscopy scan that allows robust measurements of brain chemicals to investigate the independent and combined impact of HIV infection and tobacco smoking on the human brain and enhance our understanding of the biochemical processes that may contribute to cognitive decline in HIV-infected smokers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Concussion, or mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is a neurological disorder that causes disability in children and predisposes them to significant challenges later in life, though we do not yet have a reliable method of detection. In this program, we use advanced neuroimaging to evaluate the peripheral and central nervous system pathways that that innervate the eye and face with the hypothesis they are sensitive to mTBI. This first- of-its-kind study will provide invaluable information that can be applied towards the diagnosis, monitoring and treatment of persons with an mTBI and helping protect vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In the absence of a cure for neurodegenerative dementias, it is important to develop evidence-based interventions that maximize quality of life and independence with high potential for implementation. This trial will evaluate the efficacy of two interventions for individuals with primary progressive aphasia (PPA) delivered through synchronous videoconference sessions with asynchronous custom web-application activities. Outcomes from this trial will inform clinical guidelines for nonpharmacologic interventions for PPA, which can be adapted for other dementia syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The secretion of fluid is a principal function of the intestine that is altered under conditions of stress, and infections to result in diarrhea. This proposal explores the cellular mechanisms responsible for fluid secretion in the intestine under the condition of stress and infections. This work will increase our understanding of how stress exacerbates diarrhea and identify targets for treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The bacterial pathogens Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus are leading causes of morbidity in the United States; these pathogens co-infect immunocompromised patients, including diabetics and individuals with cystic fibrosis, and cause chronic polymicrobial infections. Transition metals are essential nutrients (e.g. iron, zinc) for all organisms, and the host innate immune system withholds these nutrients from bacterial pathogens to prevent infections. Elucidating how metal-sequestering innate immune proteins, such as calprotectin, affect the availability of nutrient metal ions and the physiology of P. aeruginosa and S. aureus under conditions relevant to disease has the potential to guide novel diagnostic and therapeutic approaches, ultimately improving the care and quality of life in diverse patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurologic post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 (PASC) is an emerging threat. The trajectory and pathophysiology of PASC are poorly understood; however, underlying autoimmunity and persistent immune activation are suspected. This proposal aims to better characterize the sub-phenotypes and clinical course of neurologic PASC and to test for the role autoantibodies, persistent immune activation, and gut microbiota in a longitudinal cohort of COVID-19 survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Macrophages are central regulators of inflammation and tissue repair processes, and their function is tightly controlled by cues in the surrounding microenvironment. The goal of the proposed research is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying how tissue stiffness controls macrophage function. This work may open new strategies to modulate immune function during wound healing and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Overall The Center for Neuroscience-based Mental Health Assessment and Prediction (NeuroMAP) seeks 5 years of support to continue and expand the scientific infrastructure in Tulsa, OK, to help young investigators develop research projects focused on identifying biological causes and predictors of anxiety and mood disorders. Tulsa is still an under-developed region for mental health research even though Oklahoma has the second highest rate of mental illness in the country. The NeuroMAP Center will continue a program to train junior researchers with a pragmatic focus to use neuroscience to improve mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Cross-species transmission of pathogens is a major threat to public health worldwide and accounts for 75% of emerging human infectious diseases. Bats act as asymptomatic reservoir hosts for numerous zoonotic viruses, that are lethal in humans and for which no vaccines or specific therapeutics exist, indicating that the chiropteran immune system can control these viruses. The proposed project will illuminate the role of bat humoral immunity in controlling pathogen infections, identify novel therapeutics against zoonotic viruses and guide the computational design of next-generation protein inhibitors of viral entry.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Our proposed research is highly relevant to NIBIB mission to transform through engineering the  understanding of disease and its prevention, detection, diagnosis, and treatment. Our research goal is to  develop AI-enabled MUSE technology for at-home health monitoring of AKI patients through fusion of urine  biomarkers, ECG and EMR. Our research aligns perfectly with Goals 2 and 4 of NIBIB Strategic Vision by  making healthcare more accessible to all through development of point-of-care wireless and personal health  informatics technology. Our work will lead to new insights into health management of AKI patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is an incurable, fatal disease of an unknown cause, recent studies have shown that the immune system may play a key role in causing this disease. I have previously shown that cells will release their mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in response to injury, and this mtDNA can lead to activation of the immune system. Through our cell, mouse, and human studies, I will investigate the ways in which mtDNA interacts with the immune system as one possible cause of IPF, which can lead to exciting new areas of drug development to combat this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reducing medication errors and improving medication safety are major national priorities. The objective of this conference grant is to host the Geriatric Medication Safety Symposium in the largest medical complex in the world, the Texas Medical Center, to disseminate and implement the evidence-based approaches for medication safety in older adults to improve the quality of geriatric care. This symposium will provide a unique interprofessional educational and research forum to make medication practices safer for older adults in the TMC and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The I-WORC NCORP has a proven track record as an efficient and disciplined team from six strategically located Iowa and Illinois communities. The coalition serves as the link between NCI-approved cancer research and over two million people in the state of Iowa and the eastern portion of Illinois with a history of achieving results in clinical cancer research while being a leader both locally and in nationwide cooperative groups. The I-WORC NCORP fosters quality in its research efforts and collaboration with local resources to promote clinical trial participation, bio-specimen collection, and cancer care delivery research.

PHR: Project Narrative This research will further our understanding of why certain cancer patients respond better than others to immunotherapy. This could result in more frequent therapeutic responses among cancer patients and in more durable remissions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer is a highly fatal malignancy. Our research is designed to identify oral fungi associated with risk for this disease, and to identify related fungal microbial–host tumor immune interrelationships in pancreatic tissue. The study will expand our current limited knowledge on the causes of pancreatic cancer, will help to identify people at high risk for this disease, and may lead to microbial-based prophylactic preventions for pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is characterized by the formation of numerous fluid-filled renal cysts, immune cell infiltration and interstitial fibrosis which lead to a gradual decline in kidney function. As functional nephron numbers are reduced, phosphate excretion by residual nephrons is dramatically increased to preserve phosphate balance, which may promote further kidney injury. Preliminary data from our group has revealed dietary phosphate restriction to slow PKD progression in mice; therefore, we plan to perform experiments using cell culture techniques and genetically altered mouse models to identify the mechanisms whereby phosphate may promote PKD progression.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will optimize a powerful platform of genetic tools for chronic, large-scale, non-invasive imaging of neuromodulation in the brain during behavior. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The cross-species emergence of SARS-CoV-2 from wild, Rhinolophus spp. bats to human hosts highlights the extreme public health, economic, and societal consequences that can result from zoonotic spillover. This proposal leverages tools from mathematical modeling, field biology, and molecular immunology to decipher the mechanisms underpinning the circulation of bat-borne viruses at a population-level, understand the processes which shape their pathology within-host, and eradicate them from reservoir populations to prevent future threats of zoonotic emergence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity, diabetes, high carbohydrate diets, alcohol excess and thyroid disorders all contribute to high circulating triglyceride levels, which are found in more than half of women with triple negative breast cancer. Triple negative breast cancers are specifically susceptible to the growth promoting effects of high circulating triglycerides. Through our studies we will uncover how elevated circulating triglycerides contribute to triple negative breast cancer development and spread, and determine if starving triple negative cancer cells of these lipids will prove to be their Achilles’ heel which can be exploited as a novel therapeutic strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The continued emergence of new pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2, the unacceptable morbidity and mortality due to conventional infections, and the epidemics of antibiotic-resistant bacteria highlight the need for well- trained researchers in infectious diseases. This postgraduate training program in infectious diseases will provide training for investigators capable of harnessing the discoveries in the basic sciences of microbiology and immunology to develop novel interventions aimed at ameliorating the burden of infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The research proposed here will elucidate visual functioning in healthy human populations. Understanding how we build integrated representations of 3D space and objects – and update them across saccades – may offer critical clues for treatment of visual disorders including strabismus, macular degeneration, stereo-blindness, and neglect, and can inform development of effective visual prosthetics for blind individuals. Additionally, better knowledge of these fundamental processes may hold broad clinical applications for aging, autism, schizophrenia, and depression (all accompanied by changes in visual processing).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative This project aims to develop foundational tools for cellular engineering that will enable robust cell-fate programming. Using a combination of stem cell biology, systems biology, synthetic biology, and chromatin engineering, we will define the molecular regulatory rules of cell-fate transitions. Harnessing these design rules will enable the forward design of sophisticated genetic programs capable of robustly regulating gene expression in primary cells to support gene- and cell-based therapies for application in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Components of the epigenetic complex that regulate enhancer function and methylate histone H3 at lysine 4, including KMT2C, KMT2D, and KDM6A are early oncogenic events in urothelial cancer of the bladder and ureters, and can be detected in normal appearing urothelium. We have generated genetic engineered mouse models of urothelial cancers based on mutations of KMT2C and KMT2D. In this proposal, we will characterize the epigenetic mechanisms of tumor suppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trans people are the most severely affected by HIV yet trans people of color are particularly under-represented in science. To move the epidemic to zero new infections, zero AIDS deaths, and zero stigma, trans scientists will have to play a significant and central role in the response to HIV, especially those from under-represented racial/ethnic minority groups. This proposed SHINE Strong training program is led by under-represented minority scientists and will address this urgent need for trans HIV investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The fundamental biology of tissue maintenance and homeostasis directly relates to public health because our tissues are in constant interaction with our environment and respond in healthy and pathological ways. We reasonably understand the cells and molecules involved in tissue maintenance and repair, yet we do not know how they work in complex communities and networks to preserve a healthy state. The work outlined in this proposal aims to understand the fundamental biology of signaling that controls cell fate during tissue renewal and identify new avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the biological underpinnings leading to sex differences observed in heritable human diseases is critical for developing precision medicine approaches that work equally well in males and females. Equally as important are gender-related exposures including socioeconomic position and sexual assault-trauma which have tremendous and widespread effects on disease risk throughout the lifespan. This proposal aims to create new knowledge of how sex and gender-related exposures impact disease and how they modify genetic risk for disease across the entire medical phenome, including over 1,000 clinically relevant biomarkers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The majority of melanomas diagnosed and treated in the US are in early stages, and a significant percentage exhibit a high potential for metastasis. Research on early disease has been limited due to lack of appropriate model systems and relevant human tissues. In this proposal, by overcoming prior limitations through innovation, we will study the determinants of the tumor and the host during non-aggressive to aggressive progression in early disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The goal of the Montefiore-Einstein Minority/Underserved National Community Oncology Research Program (MU NCORP) is to advance the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and management of early and advanced cancer. Our goals are to: 1) accrue at least 80 subjects to trials sponsored by the NCORP research bases (including at least 40 to therapeutic trials), 2) provide scientific and administrative leadership to the ECOG-ACRIN, NRG and Alliance research bases; 3) expand our capacity for cancer care delivery research (CCDR) to include at least 3 active CCDR protocols; 4) train and mentor young investigators in all areas of NCORP research; and 5) contribute expertise in novel methodology to address cancer health disparities, including patient engagement, trial design and outcomes measurement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative One of the most challenging aspects of cancer treatment is the identification of therapies that kill cancer cells, but not healthy tissue. We have found that tumor cells co-opt an energy generation system from human sperm, which is otherwise not found in adult tissues. By studying this mechanism in detail, we will be able to identify a new therapeutic entry point for selectively starving cancer cells of energy while leaving normal tissues unaffected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: We aim to unravel the driving mechanisms and identify potential therapeutic targets underlying lung sequelae post-acute COVID-19. Additionally, we will establish a mouse model to validate predictive biomarkers and/or therapeutic targets of lung sequelae post-acute COVID-19. The successful completion of the study will generate unprecedented insights on clinical, viral and immune traits of pulmonary sequelae, and will identify key causal immune mechanisms and therapeutic targets against chronic lung diseases post-acute COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In lung conditions, such as smoking-related chronic bronchitis, the airways have an abnormally increased mucus production and reduced ability to get it out of the respiratory system. A progression of this process leads to the accumulation of mucus and ultimately plug formation that blocks the airways. We will score mucus plugging in the airways using chest computed tomography images and assess the associations between imaging-detected mucus plugging and respiratory symptoms and future airway disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Principal Investigator/Program Director (Last, First, Middle): Byrd, Lamont FOA Number RFA-ES-19-004 Project Narrative (DOEWTP) The IBT Consortium represents and has ready access to thousands of workers throughout the DOE Nuclear Weapons Complex who remediate hazardous waste sites, transport hazardous wastes, handle, package, transport and warehouse hazardous materials, and respond to hazardous materials releases. The IBT Consortium is staffed by a team of highly experienced worker health and safety training experts who specialize in industrial hygiene, curriculum development, adult education techniques, information technology, and craft-experienced worker-trainers. The combination of access to worker populations and institutional capacities enables the IBT Consortium to deliver high quality model training that complies with the NIEHS Minimum Criteria, applicable standards and regulations as promulgated by the Department of Energy (DOE), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Lynch syndrome is caused by defective DNA repair related to one of four genes, each associated with varying risks of colorectal cancer. In this proposal, we will determine optimal, risk-tailored surveillance strategies by genotype to minimize unnecessary screening tests and reduce overtreatment. These results will allow for broader insights into cancer prevention and control based on genomic data for the advancement of precision medicine initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: For patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) who undergo a peripheral vascular intervention (PVI) to improve quality of life and/or prevent limb loss, there are evidence based, guideline-directed medical therapies that should be prescribed after the intervention. However, adherence to these therapies remain poor among this population of patients, placing them at an increased risk of limb loss, cardiovascular disease, and death. The proposed work leverages complementary methods in qualitative research, implementation science, and clinical trial design to examine the barriers to medication adherence and evaluate a potential tool that may facilitate improved communication between the clinic provider and patient about how to improve adherence to these therapies in patients with PAD who have undergone PVI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural Killer (NK) cell-mediated antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is correlated with delayed progression of HIV disease, but exactly how antibodies regulate ADCC activity through immune complexes is not well-understood. This project will illuminate how the molecular nature of antibody binding to HIV influences NK cell ADCC activity by utilizing cutting-edge fluorescence microscopy to examine antibody receptors at the synapse between NK cells and their targets. The data from this project will form guiding principles to engineer HIV antibody therapeutics and vaccines aimed at eliciting more potent ADCC activity, with potential long-term applications to other human viruses and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mitochondrial protein unfoldase CLPX tunes mitochondrial activity by its selection of protein substrates to unfold and to degrade with its partner protease CLPP. Mutations or misregulation of CLPX and CLPP cause mitochondriopathies, including neurological and blood disorders and drive progression in multiple cancers. Our studies will reveal mechanisms by which CLPX conditionally selects its substrates at the appropriate time or condition, thus describing molecular bases of disease and providing therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: We have established ‘The Chicago Clinical Center’ for Type 1 Diabetes in Acute Pancreatitis Consortium (T1DAPC), bringing together multi-disciplinary team members from major academic centers located in Cook County, one of the most populous, racially and ethnically diverse counties in the United States to help the Consortium to build a diverse clinical cohort. In addition, we propose studies to define the contribution of diet enriched in animal protein and fat and low in fiber, through its interaction with the gut microbiota, to development of diabetes, especially type 1 diabetes following acute pancreatitis. Improving our understanding of these relationships can help to identify novel biomarkers for acute pancreatitis and diabetes that are applicable to general population and to develop effective preventive and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The essential mechanosensitive channels PIEZO1 and PIEZO2 have been tightly linked to multiple channelopathies, however, the underlying mechanisms of PIEZO diseases remain largely unknown. My previous work identified that disruption of pezo-1, the sole ortholog of PIEZO in C. elegans, caused a reduced brood size, which could be used as a readout for genetic suppressor screens to identify molecular pathways or determinants that suppress or reverse these defects. The goal of this research is to identify new genetic interactors and signaling pathways of PEZO-1 that suppress the defective reproduction phenotypes caused by PIEZO disease alleles, which may serve as a basis for other studies investigating PIEZO function and shed light on the potential for novel therapeutical drug target design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Meaning-Centered Psychotherapy (MCP), developed by Breitbart and colleagues at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, is the only empirically-supported treatment that has clearly demonstrated efficacy in improving quality of life and spiritual well-being and in alleviating existential distress, loss of meaning, despair, and physical symptom burden distress in patients with advanced cancer. As a result, there has been overwhelming demand for MCP training from multidisciplinary palliative and cancer care clinicians across settings. The continuation of this R25-supported (R25CA190169; P.I. W. Breitbart) research education program in MCP intervention skills will address a critical growing need to train clinicians in evidence-based interventions and to disseminate MCP to advanced cancer patients in need of effective psychosocial care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: To maintain skin barrier function epidermal keratinocytes undergo differentiation during which the gene expression programs switch from maintenance of cell proliferation to terminal differentiation. In addition, skin homeostasis relies on cytokines, deregulation of which may lead to psoriasis that affects 2%-3% people worldwide. In the current application, we will functionally interrogate FOXQ1, a novel regulator of keratinocyte differentiation and psoriasis-like phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a common and deadly form of genetic heart disease that is often caused by mutations in proteins that comprise structural networks in the cytoskeleton of heart cells (cardiomyocytes), and current treatment options for patients with DCM only delay its progression without addressing the underlying mechanisms. These mutations likely cause disruptions in the way cardiomyocytes sense and distribute mechanical forces generated from the contractile apparatus in the cell and/or mechanical cues from extracellular stimuli, but the role of these mechanosignaling pathways in DCM progression remains unknown. The research I propose here will employ gene-edited murine and human cardiomyocytes that express DCM-causing defects in the cytoskeletal protein Filamin C, which will be used in computational and experimental approaches designed to reveal how Filamin C regulates subcellular structure, the transmission and distribution of intracellular forces, and mechanically triggered gene expression of hypertrophic biomarkers in the cell, with the long-term goal of discovering novel treatments that can prevent or attenuate mechanically induced pathological remodeling in the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research will provide novel Bayesian models and clinical trial designs for developing and evaluating biological treatments, including cell therapies, immunotherapies, and targeted agents accounting for complex clinical and biological outcomes and multidimensional treatment e ects that may vary with disease subtypes and patient subgroups. The aims are to develop and identify optimal biotherapy-schedule-dose combinations tailored to individual patient characteristics, compare biotherapies for each of a variety of di erent cancers and therapeutic settings, and provide freely available user-friendly computer programs for both trial design and conduct to facilitate broad application. The overarching goal is to provide designs including real-time adaptive decision making rules, in order to give practicing physicians ecient decision-making tools for biotherapies in order to obtain greater anti-disease e ects, longer survival time, and optimal patient safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE During this K25 award, Dr Reeves will develop a phylodynamic model of the HIV reservoir—the primary barrier to cure of HIV. The model will be validated using unique virologic, immunologic, and genetic data. The validated model will be used to study creation, persistence, and elimination of the HIV reservoir, filling a crucial gap in the HIV cure field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Multiple sclerosis (MS) diagnostic delay is common and can have severe and life-long consequences with each preventable relapse representing an estimated additional cost of $8,200-$24,180. The problem of misdiagnosis is also significant as approximately 20% of patients referred to an MS center with a previous diagnosis of MS have been found to be misdiagnosed, 2/3 of those misdiagnosed are treated, and healthcare expenditures related to MS disease-modifying therapies (DMT) account for 40% of the total $48 billion associated cost of MS care. We propose the use of the central vein sign as a diagnostic biomarker in MS to allow early and accurate diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer (PDA) is a deadly malignancy characterized by extensive fibrosis and immune suppression. The complex interplay between tumor cells and their surrounding stroma has not been fully elucidated. Since current therapeutic approaches targeting individual components of the tumor microenvironment have failed to benefit patients, the goals of the project are to: 1) define Hedgehog-dependent tumor/fibroblast/immune cross talk, 2) elucidate Hedgehog-dependent tumor/fibroblast/endothelial cross talk, and 3) investigate a novel role for SLIT ligands in PDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Barrett’s Esophagus (BE) is a prevalent disease in the US population. There are cell intrinsic (TP53 mutations) and cell extrinsic (extracellular matrix properties) mechanisms that foster BE pathogenesis. These mechanisms will be investigated in novel human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived organotypic raft and patient-derived 3D organoid culture systems to define how BE dysplasia occurs and to uncover translational therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will test repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) for its ability to 1) normalize functioning in brain circuits that contribute to compulsive behavior, 2) reduce compulsions during ERP, an effective form of behavior therapy for youth with OCD. It will also test whether these are effective ways to improve clinical outcomes. The R61 phase will randomly assign 60 youth and young adults with OCD to receive ERP with sham (“fake” rTMS) vs. one of two different active rTMS regimens. The R33 Phase will randomly assign 60 youth and young adults with OCD to receive ERP with sham or active rTMS. Results of this study will inform understanding of treatment options in pediatric OCD.

PHR: Narrative People living with HIV are at a much higher risk for developing B cell lymphomas, and these are frequently caused by the Epstein Barr virus. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Individuals with a history of interpersonal trauma exposure are at risk for progressive social withdrawal during the transition to adulthood (ages 16-20), and although social withdrawal is strongly associated with detrimental health outcomes, neurobiological processes that contribute to social withdrawal following trauma exposure have not been identified. In line with NIMH Objective 2.2 (Identify and understand risk factors, biomarkers, and behavioral indicators of mental illnesses and of intervention responses across the lifespan), in the short term this study will: (1) identify how connectivity within a specified neural circuit is associated with baseline social withdrawal as well as change in social withdrawal over time, and (2) develop predictive algorithms that can forecast future social withdrawal based on baseline connectivity within the circuit. In the long term, understanding how connectivity within this circuit contributes to progressive social withdrawal may contribute to the development of interventions that target this circuit (e.g. neurofeedback) and may shift the field toward emphasizing the role of reward processing abnormalities in contributing to social withdrawal in trauma-exposed individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The management of pediatric acute respiratory illness (ARI) in resource-constrained settings in sub-Saharan Africa is almost entirely based on clinical symptoms, the non-specific nature of which contributes to both over- and under-treatment with antibiotics. Measuring host immune response gene expression can differentiate between viral and bacterial ARI, but the validation of classifiers based on this methodology has included very little data from sub-Saharan Africa where the burden of ARI is high and co-morbidities that may affect the immune response like malaria and malnutrition are more common. This study seeks to develop and internally validate novel clinical algorithms for pediatric ARI that leverage existing host immune response classifiers for ARI after optimization for use in resource-constrained settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Serotonin and acetylcholine are two “modulatory” neurotransmitters that are critical for normal cognitive function, and disruption of these modulatory signaling systems in the cerebral cortex contributes to a broad spectrum of psychiatric diseases. The proposed research contributes to public health and the core mission of the NIMH by elucidating, at the cellular and microcircuit levels, how these two modulators reciprocally regulate cortical output to cortical and subcortical targets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common neurodegenerative disorder, currently accounting for 60–80 % of dementia cases. This application aims at identifying the mechanisms underlying stress-accelerated aging and AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Women suffer more frequently with Alzheimer's disease than men, and have a more rapid onset and greater symptom burden. We have identified the pituitary hormone FSH, the blood levels of which rise after menopause, as a potential contributor to AD in aging women. In this proposal, we propose to utilize human brain tissue, cultured human neurons, and mouse models of AD to understand the mechanism of FSH action on brain, and determine whether one can prevent or reverse cognitive decline by reducing FSH levels––a prelude to a future FSH–based therapeutic for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Our long-term goal is to improve knowledge and education in clinical laboratory science and public health information technology professions through the implementation of a summer program, a dual enrollment course, and professional teacher development training in rural high schools in West Tennessee. Our unique population compositions in Lauderdale and McNairy Counties in West Tennessee will provide insight into the impact of cultural and social differences in learning acquisition for CLS and PHIT concepts, thereby allowing us to uniquely tailor our experiences to different community and cultural settings. We will use novel outcomes-based educational approaches that apply project-based learning strategies to real-world social determinants of health scenarios and work-based simulation strategies with real clinical data and samples and will disseminate educational curricula, materials, and research outcomes to enhance community health-based literacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In children with brain tumors impacting their vision, physicians have difficulty determining when the treatment is working. We will improve upon the very basic and often inaccurate human measurements of tumor size by developing quantitative imaging tools to make accurate and automated measures of tumor volume and shape. From these measures, we will create methods that will enable clinical trials and physicians to make informed decisions about the treatment’s success and whether the child will recover their vision.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The larynx governs our most basic life-sustaining functions and serves as the foundation of our self-identity. Even the most minor aberration within this delicate and complex structure can result in life-altering or life- ending consequences, disrupting the ability to breathe, swallow, and voice. The goal of this project is to deliver a bioengineered implant for larynx reconstruction, a novel clinical approach to restore a patient’s own voice, normal breathing, and swallowing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long-term reliance on sedative hypnotics is all too common since many hypnotic users find hypnotic discontinuation difficult to achieve. Open-label physician-supervised medication tapering (SMT) combined with cognitive behavioral insomnia therapy (CBTI) produces short-term abstinence but these treatments are difficult to access in primary care where most hypnotic users present. This project will provide primary care providers training in SMT and test a combination of this treatment with a highly scalable digital version of CBTI (dCBTI) so as to provide wider access of these interventions in primary care settings where they are most needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: As many complex diseases, e.g., Alzheimer’s disease, involve multiple cell types, it is crucial to extract cell type-specific information from widely available, low-cost bulk tissue data. The proposed study develops computational tools that can select marker genes and estimate the proportion of each cell type. The outcomes are a key part to understand these diseases and will serve further applications including cell-type specific differential expression and co-expression analyses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurons of the brain age in parallel with the individual and we can model changes in aged and diseased human neurons in a dish. I have reproducible evidence from multiple genetically distinct individuals with Alzheimer’s disease (AD), that shows the metabolic pathways involved in making the DNA building blocks are altered, potentially leading to increased DNA damage and other metabolic dysfunction. With new technologies, we will quantify changes in DNA quality, investigate two key regulators of this metabolic pathway, and profile non-genetic DNA changes associated with age and AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alport syndrome is a rare inherited disease that causes chronic kidney disease, and there are few available treatment options. This proposal investigates an FDA approved drug in a mouse model of Alport syndrome. If this drug is able to delay the onset of kidney disease in the mouse model, it would be the first step in a long journey towards repurposing the drug to treat Alport syndrome in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and schizophrenia are associated with an increased ratio of excitatory-to- inhibitory (E/I) neurotransmission in brains of affected individuals, raising the possibility that therapeutics designed to restore E/I balance could be effective in treating these disorders. Fast-spiking parvalbumin (PV) GABAergic interneurons (PV-IN) are critical regulators of E/I balance and owe their ability to generate high- frequency action potentials in part to the restricted expression and function of Kv3.1 (gene KCNC1) voltage- gated potassium channels, mutations in which are associated with ASD in humans. Here, we propose to employ high-throughput screening, medicinal chemistry, automated and manual patch clamp electrophysiology, and electrophysiological recordings from identified PV-IN to develop a series of potent and specific Kv3.1 potentiators to restore E/I balance in ASD and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overarching goal of the Interactions Core at the University of Wisconsin School of Medicine and Public Health is to foster and support collaborative transdisciplinary scientific research to enhance our understanding of the causes, development, progression, and personal, societal, and environmental impacts of non-cancerous urologic conditions, including urinary tract infection, kidney and bladder stones, prostatic enlargement, lower urinary tract symptoms (pain, incontinence, neurogenic bladder, and other voiding dysfunctions), male reproductive disorders, and developmental (congenital) abnormalities of the urinary tract. We will provide intellectual leadership and logistic support to the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK) Urology Centers and Programs collectively known as CAIRIBU – Collaborating for the Advancement of Interdisciplinary Research in Benign Urology. Specifically, the Interactions Core will identify and facilitate opportunities for cross-CAIRIBU interactions and collaborations with new urology investigators, promote research findings and resources to the broader benign urology research community, and build the community and diversity of benign urology basic, clinical, and population scientists that are actively studying benign urologic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The high prevalence and associated negative impact of trauma (i.e. child abuse, intimate partner violence) on the mental and physical health of people living with HIV and their engagement in HIV care underscore the need for systematically addressing trauma within HIV services. Trauma-informed Care (TIC) is an organizational structure and treatment framework that involves understanding, recognizing, and responding to the effects of trauma, and has shown promise in impacting the mental and physical health of patients and their care providers in non-HIV settings; however, limited published literature exists about methods for and the effectiveness of integrating TIC within HIV primary care (TI-HIV care). Responsive to our prior pre-implementation study that demonstrated critical gaps in staff TIC training and support in TIC provision across Ryan White-funded HIV Clinics (RWCs) in the Southeastern US, the proposed study develops and pilots culturally- and contextually- tailored TI-HIV care trainings and TIC implementation facilitation processes and examines their preliminary effectiveness on provider and clinic-level outcomes at two high-volume RWCs in Metro Atlanta.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell division is an essential process for a cell to produce viable progeny. The proposed research will provide a mechanistic understanding of the control mechanisms involved in the formation of bacterial Z-ring and triggering the onset of constriction. These molecular processes are potent targets for new antibacterial drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive or inappropriate recruitment of immune cells is a major driver of tissue damage in inflammation-associated diseases including atherosclerosis, arthritis, and autoimmune diseases. The migration of cancer cells causes dissemination and metastasis which greatly reduces survival rates. Understanding the basic mechanisms that allow cells to maintain migratory behavior will suggest new therapeutic strategies to improve outcomes in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed studies are relevant to public health because they have the potential to increase the effectiveness of diagnostic mammography and tomosynthesis. Thus, this advance is expected to have a high impact to the health and well being of women because mammography and tomosynthesis are currently the primary diagnostic tools for early breast cancer detection, and over two-thirds of women diagnosed through these imaging modes do not have cancer, resulting in many unnecessary painful invasive procedures. This is relevant to the part of NIH's mission which focuses on the prevention of disease by supporting research in the diagnosis of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Defective electrical signaling of polycystin ion channels is considered the primary cause for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic kidney Disease (ADPKD). The proposed work will characterize the key regulatory mechanisms of polycystin channel activation at the molecular and cellular level. Knowledge generated in this proposal will shed light on the fundamental principles of polycystin channel activation in primary cilia and how this signaling is defective in ADPKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nerve enriched environment and stem cell origin lead to the growth of the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor (MPNST) and promote metastasis. NRG1, ERBB3, and CD44, the three essential genes, typically regulate Schwan cell differentiation in the early developmental stage but form a positive feedback loop to stimulate MPNST tumorigenesis and metastasis. Our work is expected to characterize the interactions and regulations among them and evaluate the therapeutic value by interrupting the feedback loop and ultimately inhibit tumor growth and metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Artificial intelligence methods, particularly deep learning, can be used to improve image quality or synthesize new images from existing data and to predict future imaging. We will apply this to determine its performance for brain metabolic imaging using simultaneous FDG brain PET/MRI in realistic clinical populations, significantly reducing or eliminating the radiotracer dose as well as incorporating non-imaging, clinical data to improve AI-based image synthesis. This will revolutionize brain PET imaging, enable us to examine future disease trajectories in a personalized manner, and lay the groundwork to understand its use for other modalities and in other disease settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite its proposed roles in neuronal function and Parkinson's disease, the Mg2+-transporting protein SLC41A1 has not been well characterized. This study aims to use a three-pronged approach that employs functional assays, cryo-electron microscopy, and cellular assays to define its function, molecular mechanism, and cellular role. This study represents the first steps towards understanding the Mg2+-dependent molecular origins of neurodegenerative disorders and it has the potential to lead to novel treatments of and preventative strategies for Parkinson's disease, a debilitating condition which costs the US health system more than $14 billion each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Between two and five times as many SM people smoke or use tobacco as their heterosexual counterparts, resulting in disproportionate amounts of tobacco-related morbidity and mortality in SM communities. NIH has designated SM people a health disparity population, yet their tobacco disparities are persisting, and in some cases, worsening. Advancing our understanding of the etiology of SM tobacco use disparities and the potential protective effect of SM identity elements would help identify avenues for future targeted and tailored interventions, improving SM tobacco use disparities and improving SM health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The number of people in the U.S. living with lung cancer is expected to increase by 25% (from 571,340 to 724,610) in the next decade, and the majority (95%) of lung cancer patients report experiencing lung cancer stigma (i.e., the perception and internalization of negative appraisal from others attributed to one’s lung cancer)—which is associated with adverse psychological and physical health outcomes. There is an urgent unmet public health need to develop psychosocial interventions to reduce lung cancer stigma and improve quality of life for this understudied cancer group. This project will fill a critical gap in the field of cancer control science by adapting an existing patient-focused, self-compassion intervention to target the unique, disease- specific issue of lung cancer stigma, address anticipated delivery challenges, and pilot test the efficacy of the adapted intervention on reducing stigma for lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth living with HIV (YLHIV) often have difficulty sustaining adherence to daily oral antiretroviral medications, which can lead to poor treatment outcomes and lower quality of life. Long-acting antiretrovirals stand to improve outcomes for YLHIV based on the adherence benefit associated with less-frequent dosing. An improved understanding of biopsychosocial and pharmacologic aspects of their use in youth is essential, and has the potential to enhance durable virologic suppression, lower morbidity and mortality, and lower aggregate community viral load, thus blocking transmission and resulting in greater well-being both for individual youth and for society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although ‘practice quitting’ is an intuitive first step to engage smokers in the cessation process, there is limited understanding of the best treatment strategies to foster practice quitting. The proposed research will test how practice quitting counseling and nicotine replacement therapy sampling impact potential mediators and smoking cessation attempts. The long-term goal of this line of research is to add to the smoking cessation treatment literature, particularly for smokers not yet ready to quit.

PHR: Project Narrative LaGuardia Community College’s “Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program” provides mentored research experiences year round to qualified minority, economically disadvantaged or disabled students. Beyond the research experience, the program features instructional workshops on quantitative literacy (Biostatistics), oral presentation, research paper critiques, bio- instrumentations, research design, data science, mentoring, leadership and management skills, monthly research student seminars, tutoring, transfer and transfer counseling, student presentations at local and national conferences, instruction in Responsible Conduct of Research, Rigor and Reproducibility and the use of e-Portfolios.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, social processing impairment is a common symptom of several neuropsychiatric disorders, including autism spectrum disorders and schizophrenia. This proposal will employ innovative and precise anatomical, physiological, and causal assays to determine where sensory stimuli are assigned social meaning and how neuromodulators affect the processing of socially meaningful sensory information to drive emotional behavior. This will provide circuit-level insight into how these neuromodulators contribute to social processing impairment in genetic psychiatric mouse models, and aid in the development of novel treatments for psychiatric and mood disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are proposing a multi-institution study to address a severe hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HCT) complication called thrombotic microangiopathy or “TMA”. In our first aim we will define incidence, risk factors, phenotypic diversity, temporality between Graft-versus-host disease and TMA and role of markers of complement activation in diagnosis of HCT-TMA. In our second aim, we will identify key mechanisms of endothelial injury and complement activation after HCT that will result in identification of novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the most common sexually transmitted infection and is the primary cause of cervical, oropharyngeal, and anogenital cancers. Despite HPV’s heavy public health burden, there remains a limited understanding of the viral entry pathway. This proposal seeks to clarify the role of the dynein cargo adaptors FIP3 and BICD2 in dynein-mediated transport of HPV, which holds the potential to identify new therapeutic targets to combat pre-existing HPV infections.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast milk has immune regulating activities that instruct the neonatal immune system to become tolerant to certain antigens, and breastfeeding protects against the development of allergy and autoimmunity. This proposal seeks to understand how a common milk protein called butyrophilin can modulate the reactivity of T cells and whether butyrophilin is necessary for breast milk to prevent inappropriate immune responses. Successful completion of these studies will provide important knowledge about the mechanisms by which butyrophilin in breast milk contributes to immune tolerance in neonates, and why breast feeding protects against allergic and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative: Sleep is essential for children’s daytime functioning and health. Poorer sleep hygiene can negatively affect sleep outcomes in children. Urban Latino children are at greater risk for poor sleep hygiene and poor quality sleep due to exposure to higher levels of urban and cultural stressors. We propose to evaluate a novel intervention to improve sleep hygiene and in turn, sleep duration in urban Latino middle school children. We will also identify factors that may enhance the acceptability and reach of the intervention to other Latino children and their families in additional urban areas through feedback from community partners. A culturally and contextually tailored sleep hygiene intervention has the potential to exert greater improvements in sleep hygiene and sleep outcomes for group that may be more vulnerable to poor sleep health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although clinical evidence demonstrates a unique “obese asthma” endotype that disproportionately affects women and is associated with poor health outcomes (treatment resistance, increased risk of morbidity/mortality), the cellular alterations in the lungs that contribute to worsened lung dysfunction remain poorly understood. This application utilizes a novel model of obese asthma in female mice, that more accurately mimics the human condition to interrogate uniquely proinflammatory profile of innate lymphocytes and how they shape asthma severity. These studies promise to spark innovative solutions for the treatment of obese asthma and to advance our understanding of underexplored cell types in the fields of immunology and metabolism.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Hospital-physician vertical integration - namely, hospitals acquiring independent physician practices, directly employing physicians, or having significant financial ties to physician practices - has been shown to be associated with higher healthcare costs with mixed effects on quality and health services utilization; however, no known study has examined hospital-physician vertical integration in the context of patients with multiple chronic conditions (MCCs), who tend to be costly, high utilizers of health care. By evaluating the association between hospital- physician vertical integration and costs, quality, and health services utilization outcomes for patients with MCCs, this research will fill a critical knowledge gap of how hospital-physician integration has impacted integrated providers’ ability to improve outcomes and manage costs for patients with MCCs.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: The Effect of Hospital-Physician Vertical Integration on Costs, Quality, and Utilization for Insured Patients with Multiple Chronic Conditions

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE  The large unmet need for more robust solutions to limb loss in human patients demands innovative solutions, and nature provides the ultimate inspiration in salamanders, which have limbs similar to human limbs but which completely regenerate following amputation. This project is aimed at understanding how axolotls, a kind of salamander, respond to amputation and create a blastema, a transient structure on the stump necessary for regeneration. We hypothesize axolotls coordinate the activity of tissue-resident progenitor cells, the neuroendrocrine system, and the central nervous system for the initiation of limb regeneration and blastema creation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Founded in 1983, Aga Khan University (AKU) is a private, international, not-for-profit institution whose network of medical centres and hospitals throughout East Africa and Central and South Asia grant unique access to populations not served by any other health organizations in the world. AKU’s health networks offer a unique and timely opportunity: to engage some of the world’s poorest and most vulnerable populations and generate the kind of health data that can drive effective evidence-based interventions and policy that can improve the health and bolster the resiliency of these communities. In order to maximize the potential of AKU’s health networks in support of this kind of advanced research and improve health equity globally, AKU seeks funding to build and sustain research administration capacity both within its own institution and at other institutions across Pakistan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on the Frontal Cortex was established in 2022 to provide a forum for researchers interested in the prefrontal cortex, related parts of the frontal cortex and their functions across species. The frontal cortex regulates a wide range of behaviors and cognitive functions and is disrupted in numerous psychiatric and neurological diseases, necessitating an integrative, cross-topic platform to advance understanding of this complex brain system. For the 2024 meeting, we have planned a diverse meeting to include trainees and speakers from multiple research perspectives and career stages and have emphasized participation of under-represented groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Intermediate filaments (IFs) are a family of intracellular proteins involved in numerous functions. Mutations in genes encoding IF proteins cause over 100 human diseases that affect major organs, including skin, skeletal muscle, bone, heart, brain, nerves, and the vasculature, as well as aspects of aging. The 2024 Gordon Research Conference on IFs, together with the accompanying Gordon Research Seminar, will bring together scientists from around the world and across the career spectrum to discuss recent discoveries in the field.
