IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Hantavirus disease is a form of zoonotic viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF) that results when humans inhale excreta from hantavirus-infected rodents, with case-fatality rates exceeding 40% for some hantaviruses. In its natural reservoir host, the brown rat, Seoul virus causes asymptomatic, lifelong infection, posing a persistent threat to humans worldwide due to the global rat distribution. This proposal capitalizes on the functional proteomics expertise of the team to identify host-specific interacting partners of Seoul virus proteins that determine resistance to interferon-mediated viral restriction in reservoir host cells, thereby identifying novel effectors to limit viral infection in humans.

PHR: Project Narrative There is an urgent unmet need to develop methods to promote limb regeneration after congenital or adult amputation. We will here determine the functions and mechanisms of this stem cell to orchestrate multi-tissue regenerative responses, with the ultimate goal of harnessing this cell to enable patient limb regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Maintaining the balance between red blood cell (RBC) production and clearance is critical for maintaining proper oxygenation of the body tissues. Unrestrained differentiation of inflammatory hemophagocytes during Plasmodium infection and chronic Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling can lead to severe anemia. The goal of this proposal is to uncover the role of the anti-inflammatory immunometabolite itaconate in depleting inflammatory hemophagocytes through cell death mediated mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – JOHNS HOPKINS ERC OVERALL Situated in the largest, most highly ranked school of public health in the world, the multidisciplinary Johns Hopkins Education and Research Center for Occupational Safety and Health prepares occupational safety and health professionals in the areas of research, education, practice, and policy development, and provides outreach and continuing education in occupational safety and health. Since its establishment in 1977, the Johns Hopkins ERC has evolved in response to changing demands in the field, as well as to scientific and technological advances that impact occupational safety and health practice, research, and education, while retaining steadfastly its commitment to an integrated, interdisciplinary approach to training researchers and practitioners. The Center addresses ongoing and emerging issues, thereby building the national capacity to provide care, set policy, design and manage safety and health programs, and conduct research to further the National Occupational Research Agenda and advance the body of knowledge in this field—and as the only ERC in federal region III, which includes Maryland, Washington, D.C., Virginia, West Virginia, Delaware, and Pennsylvania —we are dedicated to meeting regional as well as national and international needs, and our center’s Outreach and Continuing Education efforts serve hundreds of organizations each year within our region alone, including private-sector businesses, nonprofit and academic organizations, local, state, and federal government agencies, and the military.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: CROHN'S AND COLITIS FDN OF AMERICA, INC.
PHR: Project Narrative Psychosocial factors and social determinants of health (SDOH) may put African American pediatric and adult patients at a much higher risk for poor outcomes than other populations. Research is needed to delineate which factors play key roles and how to incorporate these findings into effective awareness and educational programming that result in timely IBD diagnosis and management. In the proposed research, we will address this research gap by delineating the key psychosocial factors and SDOH impacting individuals with IBD with a focus on African American adolescents and adults. We will also identify the key barriers and facilitators to health literacy-sensitive care among adult and pediatric IBD patients with a focus on the barriers to African American adolescents and adults. The results from this research will inform the creation of impactful local and nationwide awareness and educational programs for physicians, patients, and caregivers to improve time to diagnose and to receiving management with effective therapy.
PI_NAMEs: CHU, DANIEL I;POLLOCK, JENNIFER S;WINGATE, LAURA DAWN (contact)
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-DP-23-002, Improving Health Outcomes for Patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease through Evidence-based Awareness, Referral, and Education Programs

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will 1) comprehensively evaluate the independent impact of social risk factors on the natural history and outcomes of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD) through a prospective epidemiological study and 2) develop a stakeholder-informed, scalable digital health intervention to enhance IBD management and evaluate its effectiveness in improving patient activation and clinical outcomes and reducing disparities through a pragmatic clinical trial. This project also seeks to translate these findings and other evidence into practice through robust patient and professional education, outreach and awareness programs. Taken together, this work will help to better understand and mitigate health disparities in the treatment of IBD, significantly improving clinical outcomes, quality of life, and health equity and directly informing healthcare policy and clinical practice.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: RFA-DP-23-002, Improving Outcomes and Reducing Disparities for Patients with Inflammatory Bowel Disease through Epidemiology, Enhanced Disease Management, Dissemination, and Education

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Dilated cardiomyopathy of unknown cause (DCM) has mostly a genetic basis, and identifying genetic risk and detecting very early clinical evidence of DCM in at-risk family members holds promise to prevent it. Harnessing emerging innovations in cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging may be an ideal approach to detect the earliest clinical evidence with great sensitivity. Leveraging an ongoing, clinical and genetic study of hundreds of DCM families, we propose to explore and validate CMR approaches in at-risk family members. If successful, the proposed study would greatly help to assess and manage risk in family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this study is to expand measurement-based psychiatric care across 6 early psychosis treatment teams in Minnesota, each providing coordinated specialty care and in total serving 200 individuals per year. We will establish highly reliable measurement-based psychiatric care using state-of-the-art informatics tools, and we will harness the clinical encounter data to perform novel data-driven predictive analyses. We will also perform a research project that will investigate the potential benefits of identifying cognitive functioning and motivated behavior as explicit treatment targets for individuals entering care; and we will study a well-defined 12-week mobile intervention program to address these targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: While in vitro fertilization (IVF) has increased the likelihood of pregnancy for couples facing infertility, it is unknown why up to 40% of embryo transfers with genetically normal embryos do not result in a pregnancy. Host- microbial interactions in the urogenital tract of both the female and male partner could impact fertility outcome, but the mechanisms responsible are unclear. This project will study the female and male urogenital microenvironment in couples undergoing IVF treatment to identify factors underlying infertility and IVF success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this research proposal is to identify modifiable factors associated with different postoperative respiratory failure (PRF) phenotypes in adults following elective surgery and to utilize this information to develop and deploy a predictive model and electronic health record (EHR)-based probability scoring system and dashboard for PRF. The feasibility of a multisource (e.g., real-time, and historic clinical and biomarker data) probability score, embedded in the EHR, will be demonstrated through successful deployment in a pre-production environment. This work will be described in five papers and will enable me to develop preliminary data for a competitive R01 proposal focused on implementing and evaluating a validated, real-time PRF predictive model in a UC-wide multi-center study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The synthesis, delivery, and precise localization of AMPA-type glutamate receptors (AMPARs) within the postsynaptic membrane is essential for basal synaptic function and plasticity. In order to determine how new receptors are delivered to specific synaptic connections at the appropriate time and abundance in large and geometrically complex cells like neurons, we present the use of a novel tool for visualizing and inducibly manipulating endogenous AMPAR synaptic trafficking.

PHR: Preeclampsia and (NAFLD) that prospectively population maternal (PE) is a leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality in the United States there is an urgent ongoing need to identify its risk factors. Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease is the most common liver disease among women and leads to lipid dysregulation may contribute to endothelial cell dysfunction that characterizes PE. This project will evaluate the association between NAFLD and PE in a diverse patient and define relevant NAFLD-associated lipid changes that may contribute to endothelial dysfunction during pregnancy.

PHR: Project Narrative Suicide is the second leading cause of death among youth in the US and has been increasing at an alarming rate among Black youth. Despite the urgent need, we have no interventions with demonstrated effectiveness for Black youth at risk for suicide. With input from a broad range of stakeholders, we propose to develop an integrated intervention, Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Suicide Prevention plus the Youth-Nominated Support Team, that will address youths’ intrapersonal risk factors and needs for adult support and connectedness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Since self-supervised deep learning as an emerging artificial intelligence method has demonstrated great success in many fields, it is expected to become a powerful method in aiding many biological tasks. This project will develop a self-supervised deep-learning framework for biomedical studies and apply it in anti- CRISPR protein prediction, ion and small ligand binding prediction, single-cell data analyses across different conditions, and beyond. The framework and associated software tools will be helpful for gene editing design, drug development, and disease studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is a significant public health burden, with one-third of the world's population infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb), the causative agent of TB. Efforts have been made to fight TB by developing better vaccines and new TB drugs; however, these efforts are impeded by the knowledge gap in understanding the immune responses to Mtb with co-infections. The proposed study will investigate how environmental non-tuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), which are endemic in regions with a high burden of TB, impact the development of humoral immunity in the lungs and contribute to TB immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer is the deadliest form of cancer and is diagnosed by performing biopsies with a bronchoscope; how- ever, this tool is limited in its ability to explore deep into the periphery of the lung, where cancer can remain undetected. This proposal focuses on the design, development, and validation of a novel soft surgical robot to address critical unmet needs within the world of lung cancer. These include increasing the depth of access in peripheral regions and improving navigability within the lungs, enhancing the precision and accuracy of tissue biopsies, and enabling for the first-time rapid diagnosis and simultaneous therapy in a single bronchoscopy pro- cedure to hasten cancer treatment and increase the rate of survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R01 aims to determine the differential impact of flavor and synthetic cooling properties on vaping behavior and toxicant exposure. The proposed study will utilize a comprehensive approach to examine the abuse liability (including the sensory ratings and appeal) of e-liquids with and without the presence of synthetic cooling agents. Findings would immediately inform the evidence base needed to inform FDA rulemaking surrounding the use of synthetic cooling agent additives in EC products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Although all cells have the same collection of genes, what makes them different is which genes are turned on and which are turned off. When genes are inappropriately expressed, cancer can sometimes occur, or the development of an organism can occur improperly. This proposal focuses on understanding links between different steps in turning on a gene, in particular, the relationship between destroying the ﬁnal protein product, making the protein product, and getting rid of intermediate products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Cervical cancer is the 4th most common cancer in women worldwide, with over 85% of cases and related deaths occurring in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is a known risk factor, with women living with HIV (WLWH) having a 5–8-fold increased risk of developing cervical cancer. The AVANÇO Research Consortium is a collaboration between Mozambique, Brazil and the US to advance novel and affordable technologies for the prevention and diagnosis of cervical cancer among WLWH in LMICs.

PHR: PROJECT 1 NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop novel, low-cost and technologically feasible approaches for cervical screening, diagnosis, and treatment in a single visit. The overall goal of Project 1 is to optimize and evaluate the Multimodal Mobile Colposcope (MMC) for a sensitive and specific diagnostic triage test for women living with HIV (WLWH) who screen positive for cervical cancer. The study will be performed in Mozambique and Brazil where the prevalence of cervical cancer in WLWH is high.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) results in an increased risk of mortality and cardiopulmonary and neurologic morbidities including cerebral palsy (CP) in neonates. Currently the relationship between perinatal brain injury, neuromuscular deficits, and functional motor abnormalities in CP is poorly understood. In this project, we will utilize a mouse model of IUGR with/without postnatal hyperoxia exposure to investigate cell specific changes to the oligodendrocyte transcriptome leading to pathologic changes to the corticospinal tract and motor deficits similar to those seen in CP

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE CD4+Foxp3+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) residing in the visceral adipose tissue (VAT) safeguard tissue homeostasis and promote insulin sensitivity but are sensitive to obesity-induced toxicity. This proposal seeks to uncover novel metabolic and cytokine-mediated mechanisms that control the homeostasis of VAT Tregs and determine how these pathways might be dysregulated during obesity. A better understanding of these mechanisms should aid us to devise efficient and long-lasting VAT-Treg-targeted strategies to ameliorate obesity-associated metabolic diseases, including type-2 diabetes, fatty-liver disease, and cardiovascular disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT 2 NARRATIVE There is an urgent need to develop novel, low-cost and technologically feasible approaches for cervical screening, diagnosis, and treatment for women living with HIV (WLWH) in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). The goal of Project 2 is to evaluate a novel optical microscope with a deep depth of field (DeepDOF) which can provide histologic-quality images at the point-of-care and prevent delays in diagnosis and initiation of treatment. The study will be performed in Mozambique and Brazil where the prevalence of cervical cancer in WLWH is high.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the efficacy of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in alleviating symptoms in patients with Treatment- Resistant Depression (TRD), memory impairment remains a common side effect. The goal of this study is to assess the impact of ECT on sleep-wake regulation and efficiency of information transfer in functional networks in different states of arousal. A thorough understanding of the underlying circuit mechanisms by which ECT works will allow enhancement of its utility through improvement of clinical outcomes and reduction of cognitive impairments following this critical treatment.

PHR: NARRATIVE: The Shared Resource Core (SRC) will support the Research Projects of the AVANÇO Research Consortium as well as the Pilot Projects of the associated Developmental Core. The SRC will provide uniform and high-quality methods for the acquisition, storage and analysis of biospecimens and study data, including cervical and pathology images. Centralizing oversight of these operational procedures and processes through the SRC will allow for high-quality and secure data, efficient use of both laboratory and human resources, as well as the creation of a central data repository for AVANÇO Research Consortium investigators across Mozambique, Brazil and the US.

PHR: Alliance NCORP Research Base Project Narrative The Alliance NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) Research Base conducts research in cancer prevention, cancer symptom control, and cancer care delivery with a special emphasis on minority, underserved, and older patients and with a strong commitment to building collegial relationships with NCORP Community sites and Minority/Underserved Community sites. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High medication burden among older adults with multiple chronic conditions including those with heart failure is a growing problem in the United States that can negatively impact the health and wellbeing of older adults. Deprescribing (or medication discontinuation) has emerged as a strategy to improve outcomes in older adults with multiple chronic conditions and high medication burden, but is underutilized. With this proposed project, we will develop an innovative pragmatic patient-centered approach (N-of-1 trials) to medication optimization in older adults, thereby improving the health and wellbeing of older adults with multiple chronic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are now hundreds of thousands of people enrolled in biobank studies, presenting unprecedented opportunities for understanding the genetic basis of vulnerability to disease and other complex traits. Novel computational methods from population genetics allow these vast genetic datasets to be expressed in terms of genealogical relationships among segments of DNA scattered across people, which naturally encodes all historical information available in a set of contemporary genomes, as well as all correlations among genetic variants. We will use these new resources to understand the evolution of complex biomedical traits and better identify genetic variants associated with disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective management of patients on antiretroviral therapy (ART) is essential to improve patient outcomes and prevent HIV transmission, but monitoring life-long ART for over 13 million HIV-infected people has become a challenge, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). In this study, we will evaluate a combined implementation of clinic-based point-of-care HIV viral load testing and task shifting among healthcare workers as a novel and effective strategy for managing chronic HIV care in LMICs. Our intervention will allow the most highly-trained professionals and laboratories to focus on people with new HIV diagnoses, those starting ART, and those with complication of HIV or ART, which will facilitate the expansion of ART to reach the estimated millions people who are eligible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Atrial fibrillation, with prevalence in the United States predicted to increase to 12.1 million patients by 2030, is a powerful risk factor for blood clots and stroke, independently increasing stroke risk 4- to 5-fold. This project aims to improve the stroke prevention treatment for atrial fibrillation by transforming Left Atrial Appendage Occlusion procedures into a first line therapy for a larger segment of patient populations, including, younger patients with 20+ year of life expectancy. The proposed research study aims to achieve this goal by combining novel medical imaging, robotic catheter, and advanced visualization technologies to improve the safety, cost, and workflow of Left Atrial Appendage Occlusion procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stem cells maintain the function of many of our organs and are also highly influenced by our metabolism and physiology, and these processes are often altered in obese individuals. We propose to take advantage of powerful research tools in fruitflies to investigate how stem cells and their descendants alter their preference for different types of nutrients, including sugars, fats and amino acids, and how this process is regulated during normal physiology or under obesity conditions. Because of the high degree of evolutionary conservation of molecules and biological processes between fruitflies and humans, this work will likely provide valuable insights into diseases resulting from metabolic abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The actin cytoskeleton is the structural scaffold that gives cells their shape, and actin remodeling is essential to cell function and tissue building. We are interested in the genetic and molecular mechanisms that regulate actin remodeling in both normal and stressful environments (e.g. in the presence of fever or drugs). Our studies will identify vulnerabilities that precipitate failed actin remodeling, providing clues as to the genes and conditions that underlie birth defects and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Findings from observational studies and randomized controlled trials suggest that weight loss, physical activity, and a healthy diet potentially attenuate the negative effects of obesity and reduce cancer risk and mortality. Evidence-based weight loss interventions in clinical settings showed health benefits, but not generalizable to rural and Appalachian populations due to their unique characteristics. This application carefully designed series of specific aims to provide insight on health behaviors and lifestyle interventions in rural and Appalachian populations, and to design and deliver an efficacious weight loss intervention to reduce cancer risk and disparities for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Sphingolipids from Porphyromonas gingivalis, a key organism in chronic periodontitis which affects up to 42% of adults in the US over the age of 30, are known to limit host inflammation. The proposed work outlined in the training plan for this NRSA Individual Predoctoral Fellowships to Promote Diversity in Health-Related Research (F31) Award will support pre-doctoral candidate Zavier Eure throughout his graduate program at University of Florida. Mr. Eure will investigate the role of microbial sphingolipids on Porphyromonas gingivalis by defining OMV uptake mechanisms and SL-mediated immunomodulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell migration is a ubiquitous process that is critical for human development, wound healing, the immune response, and even pathological conditions such as cancer metastasis. Cell migration is influenced by expression of aquaporins, or water channels, on the cell surface, though the mechanisms by which AQPs regulate cell migration are not well understood. This MIRA proposal’s goal of understanding how AQPs regulate these cell behaviors is especially relevant and fascinating because of AQPs’ location on the cell surface as transmembrane proteins, with potential to regulate many intracellular activities, such as cell volume regulation, intracellular signaling, and cell polarization.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The interior of many organs, such as the lungs and intestines, is line with an extracellular matrix critical to their function. Issues with this matrix contribute to many human diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), ulcerative colitis, and many forms of cancer. This study will provide insight into how the components of this matrix are produced and coat the proper surfaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative Positron emission tomography (PET) imaging with radiotracers is used in hospitals around the world for several applications, including cancer staging and response to treatment assessment, and also is an important tool in biomedical research for investigating a wide range of health and disorders. The raw data collected by a PET scanner does not immediately produce an image and is instead reconstructed from a series of angular views using a tomographic reconstruction algorithm, but theoretically, the physics does allow for directly producing an image provided the detectors are sufficiently fast to determine the detection time difference of the photons with resolution of less than 25 picoseconds. In this proposal we aim to develop ultra-fast instrumentation and supporting computational algorithms leading to the first demonstration of a reconstruction-free imaging system for cross-sectional imaging of radiotracers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Several strategies or contexts help patients with Parkinson’s disease to move more quickly or normally, however the brain mechanisms underlying these phenomena are poorly understood. The proposed studies employ multiple complimentary electrophysiology and neuroimaging techniques to understand the brain mechanisms supporting improved movements. The identified biomarkers may provide targets for future neuromodulation therapies to improve symptoms that are refractory to current treatments, such as freezing of gait.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NARROWS INSTITUTE FOR BIOMEDICAL RES INC
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with autoimmune diseases or even healthy individuals can present with pathogenic antibodies called anti-Ro antibodies, and these antibodies can increase the risk for cardiac abnormal heart rhythm and may cause sudden cardiac death. In this research, we propose to develop decoy molecules that will distract and neutralize these pathogenic antibodies and prevent cardiac arrhythmia. We will use an animal model for autoimmune disease to test our decoy peptides and study the mechanism of anti-Ro elicited cardiac arrhythmia, anticipating that we can translate our findings to preclinical and hopefully clinical testing in the near future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite dramatic improvements in breast cancer (BC) prognosis over the past two decades, major survival differences after diagnosis persist, even within similar stage and molecular BC subtypes. This proposal aims to use what we know about risk of developing breast cancer, including genetics and clinical factors, to improve prediction of outcomes following a BC diagnosis and improve BC survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The research proposed in this ovarian cancer SPORE application requires various forms of fresh human tumor  and normal tissue that has been properly collected and uniformly processed. This centralized pathology core  will work with each project and other core to ensure that appropriate human tumor tissue is collected and  allocated for all proposed research and also deposited in the appropriate tissue banks for later research. In  addition, core pathologists will work with each project to provide expert pathologic interpretation of all human  tissue studies, overall allowing for generation of the most accurate data and experimental interpretation and  maximizing the research that is done from these valuable human samples.
